Alabama

 

Alabama GS Neg

Scouting Report for Bama GS (on the Neg):

Neg against Liberty HH – RPS with warming advantages.

 

1NC

Politics – tort reform – policies dealing with global warming sap political capital, PC is key to get medical     malpractice class action tort reform to pass thru congress, and it's key to help the pharmaceutical      industry so it can develop vaccines against bioweapons; they cause extinction.

Gas DA – natural gas prices high in the SQ; the plan plummets gas prices; hi gas prices key for the                 development of methyl-hydrate which is key to solving water shortages; water wars go nuclear

CP – dispositional; have all 50 states do RPS [no federalism N/B]

Case –

                A.  Sea Levels

                                1.  no evidence of global warming – we've been cooling the past decades

                                2.  warming decreases sea levels

                                3.  higher sea levels will be minimal

                                4.  models are over-simplistic

                                5.  non-climate variables are responsible for sea levels

                B.  Ag

                                1.  Ag can adapt

                                2.  higher CO2 good for plants [Idso]

                                3.  higher CO2 decreases water stress & helps crops [Idso]

                                4.  warming concentrates for nite effects – helps crops [Singer]

                C.  Species

                                1.  species aren't threatened by warming [Avery]

                                2.  habitat expansion – CO2 expands habitats, enables more adaptation [Idso]

                                3.  warming = species adaptation [Idso]

                                4.  higher CO2 = greater species diversity [Idso]

                D.  Solvency

                                1.  Ice Age disad

                                2.  turn; CO2 helps crop productivity [Idso]

                                3.  Turn; soil erosion –

                                                a.  CO2 enhances soil nutrients

                                                b.  soil erosion causes extinction

                                4.  Turn; horseshoe crabs

                                                a.  horseshoe crabs are on the brink and are a keystone species & CO2 helps                                                        their habitat

                                                b.  biodiversity key to the life on the planet

 

THE BLOCK

Kick Politics

Kick the CP

Extend the Gas disad

Extend all the case args

2NC goes for Ice Age for 6-7 minutes; reads new impacts:

                1.  Ice Age will be worse than a nuclear war

                2.  Ice Age will cause a nuclear war [countries will lashout in desperation]

2NC also reads a new Coral Reefs turn on solvency – CO2 key to reef re-calcification

 

2NR

Goes for Ice Age, case turns, and adaptation args

 

MISC:

1.  Bama has trouble with the uniqueness arg that we're warming now & have high CO2 levels now (they never explicitly extend such args for their CO2 turns, because they have obvious tension with their Ice Age disad).

2.  Bama also doesn't address as well as they should the Aff's intricate args about Ag – i.e., Liberty read evidence that said hi CO2 creates more pests which kill Ag, and Bama doesn't answer.  Of course, Liberty doesn't extend that either.

3.  Bama wins the debate on high risk of Ice Age (they will claim that the Aff's turns of "warming causes cooling" are based on a thermal-hailing model [THC] which only accounts for small regional glaciation, not large-scale glaciation which will doom the planet)

 

 

 

 

Alabama GS Neg

 

The 1AC was "the same one they'd been reading all tourney" so banned

consumption of lng and claimed advantages off of lng market bad-US Russian War

based off Iran issues, India/Pakistan, China/US, etc.  I don't remember the

specifics very well because we aren't infvolved in the lit.

 

 

We read our Agamben K

2ac said

1. no link-don't use gov for bad things

2. agamben leaves no room for resistance-hardt 2k

3. ethics before ontlogy-etkins 99

4. perm-do both-krishna 93 coalitoinal politics

5. should think about gov-rorty 98

6. framework a. aff choice b. moots 1ac c. neg conditionality

7. realism is good a. solved coldwar-morgenthau b. inevitable-bleiker c.

reforms itself-mearsheimer

8. terrorism impact turn a. neg is discursive censorship-butler 98 b. must

label terrorists to solve terrorism-card

9. using evil label good-cristhou 2k

10. agamben totalizes camp space-hardt dunn 2k

11. utopian politics bad

12. floating PICS bad

13. democracy good-hussain 2k

14. progressive politics good-agamben 2k (this card was ridiculously out of

context)

15. case o/ws real scenarios of nuclear war

 

 

our block was just an extension/overviews of the k

at this point the db8 was no where remotely close

but we said "fuck" once in the 2nc and 2wice in the 1nr

so

the 1ar extended a lot of args but then conceeded our "racist jokes" standard

in answer to the framework-and read a coupla of cards about how "fuck" and

"fucking" are paitrarchical and sexist and how it personally affected the 1a

since she was a woman.

 

 

2nr i go for the k answer all their args and then go to this fuck issue several

argumetns

1. apologized

2. used their butler censorship

3. made our links outweigh theirs args

4. made args about their understanding of paitrarchy being bad

5. pointed out that the framework didn't say look at racist jokes first but

only discourse k

6. made grammatical/use differentiations

 

 

the 2ar went exclusively for the "fuck" argument

 

 

They won it was a lowpoint win-latter on Varda got really pissed when he

learned they use this argument in an insincere manner since they've run it

before and told people that they didn't care about it as more then an argument.

 

 

I'm afraid i can't be very useful except to say that their responsiveness to

the K is laughable and Varda told them absent this Fuck issue that the debate

was over after the 1ar (notably this fuck arg was like 25 seconds of the 1ar)

so there wasn't much going for them.

 

 

More questions, i've got answers

 

Alabama GS Neg

Vs MSU DT Round 1 NU

Judge: Lundberg

The only arguments of note were a counterplan (against cafe) to exclude european

automakers from the legislation with a WTO net benefit. other than that everything was

pretty standard.

 

They ran T establish is to enact - their interpretation was that to be topical only congress could pass legislation because they're the only ones who "enact law", a PIC to do CAFE but exclude European automakers, tort reform for politix, a credit liquidation DA [ plan decreases oil consumption, means china sells bonds to have money to buy up extra oil, this kills market, econ collapse etc.] and on the competitiveness advantage they ran ice age and functionally the auto DA, just some cards that said fuel efficiency kills automakers etc. on oil their main arguments were merely tech solves, oil increasing now, and your authors have no quals. the block went for everything but politix and the 2nr was T and the counterplan. we ended up losing on the counterplan solving most of case. hope this helps !

- Cat

 

Alabama GS Neg

            Round 6 West Georgia

            Vs Team: Wake CH (Permits)

            Judge: Monte Stevens

 

            Case Args:

AT: Warming – CO2 Ag, Ice Age

AT: Competitiveness – Immigration Kills Comp, US Military Sucks Now

AT: Relations – Interdependence Solves, Alt Caus, Peace Process Bad, Independent Europe Good

 

            Off Case Args:

Bush Good – Class Action Tort Reform Prevents Pharmaceutical Bankruptcy – Bioweapons = Extinction

 

T – Plan Doesn’t Reduce – Must Be Command and Control

 

The United States Federal Government should through congressional legislation establish a cap on non-governmental carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuels used for fuel and the production of petrochemicals, lubricants, waxes and petroleum coke, reducing them to two thirds of present total levels by 2020, and implement the cap through auctioned tradable permits, earned by reductions in fossil fuel consumption.

 

We’ll clarify our intent now: the counterplan excludes the production of road oil, plastic, rubber, and asphalt from the cap while achieving the same reductions as the aff.

 

Chemical industry’s use of Liquid Petroleum Gas to produce plastics accounts for less than 3.5% of the fossil fuel consumption that would be regulated under the plan. Sequestration solves for any deficit they can articulate

Hargrove, 1998 (google)

“fossil energy were used for non-fuel purposes in the US” AND “for example, lubricants”

 

Their trading system will drive up the price of liquid petroleum gas and trigger a shift to PLA plastics

Chemical Week, 1-22-2003

“Industry’s target should instead be” AND “50 years is not that much time.”

 

The shift would increase corn production by 73 billion liters a year

Grain News, August 2003

“The expanding use of PLA plastic also generates” AND “faster than petroleum-based products.”

 

Increased corn production will create a Gulf of Mexico dead zone

Montgomery 2002 (google)

“Now it is October. And farmers” AND “necessary for fish and other animals to live.”

 

Planetary extinction results

Craig 2003 McGeorge Law Review

“Biodiversity and ecosystem function arguments” AND “a few fishers go out of business as a result.”

 

 

            Block Strategy:

Kicks politics and counterplan, reads a lot of new cards on CO2 Ag and Ice Age

 

            2nr Strategy:

Ice Age, Kicked CO2 Ag, Case Defense

Alabama GS

            Round # 5 Shirley

            Vs Team: West Georgia KT

            Judge: Eric Matthews

 

            Case Args:

 

Turn – unchecked rise of CO2 is essential to meet global food needs and prevent destruction of the biosphere through appropriation of new land for agriculture.

Idso and Idso, 5/2/2001, CO2 Science Magazine, “clearly, the hearts” AND “not many years hence”

 

Science promotes environmental rationality and checks stupid policies – even if it fails sometimes, it’s still successful at promoting a social consciousness shift.

Tarlock, 1996, Duke Environmental Law and Policy Forum, “there is a close” AND “light of new information”

 

Science empirically has solved specific problems which could have resulted in extinction and abandoning science has empirically leads to large-scale eco-destruction.

Lewis, 1992, Green Delusions, p. 135-136, “the ecoradical attack” AND “intensify environmental destruction”

 

Science good – it’s better than earth-centered metaphysics, displaces arrogant anthropocentrism without rejecting it outright, and build coalitions to stop ecological destruction.

Barry, 1999, Rethinking Green Politics, “if green politics” AND “secular scientific naturalism”

 

            Off Case Args:

 

Topicality

 

A. Our interpretation – must vote for a topical plan. Affirming the resolution means that the Aff’s advocacy serves a warrant for “federal government requiring a reduction in fossil fuel consumption.” No part of the Aff meets the literal meaning of the resolution because it does not involve the FG requiring an action of a third party.

 

B. Our interpretation provides best education – non-literal interpretation of the topic destroys the value of debating about energy policies. Their decision to divert the discussion away our “national energy policy” devours all opportunity to parlay this specific body of knowledge into actions needed to address the myriad of problems stemming from our current energy policy.

Roberts, 2004, The End of Oil, p. 302-305, “it is tempting” AND “to emphasize supply”

 

C. Key to fair debates

 

1. Non-literal makes resolution meaningless.

 

2. Destroy Neg ground.

 

3. Predictable rules are key to debate.

Bakhtin, 1999, The Discourse Reader, pages 362-369, “erving goffman” AND “how is this accomplished?”

 

4. Suspending rules ushers in more dangerous communicate form.

Benhabib, 1990, The Communicative Ethic, page 34, “this is not” AND “from the moral conversation”

 

5. Debate requires roleplaying to attack one’s convictions.

Muir, 1993, Philosophy and Rhetoric 26:4, A Defense of the Ethics of Contemporary Debate, pages 289-290, “at the individual” AND “reasoned moral identity”

 

6. Muir, 1993, Philosophy and Rhetoric 26:4, A Defense of the Ethics of Contemporary Debate, pages 289-289, “values clarification” AND “position imbued with tolerance”

 

C. Vote Neg

 

Voter

Debates about environmental law and governance solve their offense. It builds our moral capacity, prevents polarization, and motivates people to take action.

Doremus, 2003, 37 UC Davis L Rev 233, “attention to the” AND “used to reach those goals”

 

Kritik

 

A. Aff’s kritik functions as a form of maintenance for the system it criticizes – their discourse is an attack on the status quo. They broadcast that attack in an attempt to be radicals fighting a revolution. But it is a waste of energy – a useless expenditure – that only distracts – it does not spur change.

Mann, 1996, The Nine Grounds of Intellectual Warfare, Postmodern Culture Vol 6 No 2, “as the economy” AND “with these ludicrous gifts”

 

B. This is a unique link and impact to the 1AC – they create no change – the strategy of open criticism dooms it to failure – its suggestion will be coopted, assumed and avoided, corporations, military officials, politicians hear the complaint and make the changes they need to avoid it – criticism as posited can only function to strengthen the system it hopes to combat.

Mann, 1996, The Nine Grounds of Intellectual Warfare, Postmodern Culture Vol 6 No 2, “it would be a mistake” AND “demand that we do so”

 

C. Becoming identifiable is a death warrant – the state will resort to violence

Agamben, 1993, The Coming Community, pages 85-87, “what could be” AND “the tanks will appear”

 

D. Endorse the position and framework of the affirmative from a position of stealth and secrecy –

Mann, 1996, The Nine Grounds of Intellectual Warfare, Postmodern Culture Vol 6 No 2, “consider what” AND “established rights and property”

 

 

            Block Strategy:

 

T, K

 

            2nr Strategy:

 

T

There is something about a major treaty that transcends ordinary congressional votes and on which presidents

 

Impacts

The Washington Times 2/25/2004 p. lexis

Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan yesterday took on the powerful housing industry

 

Regulations prevent economic collapse

Washington Times 2004

The balance sheets of Fannie and Freddie are enormous

 

China DA

 

We are on the brink of a protectionist backlash – China will be the target of a steep across the board tariff increase

Stephen Roach 11/12/2004 – http://www.morganstanley.com/GEFdata/digests/latest-digest.html

The corollary of that conclusion is that the longer the dollar’s depreciation remains limited, the greater the role that heightened trade frictions might play

 

Plan is that trigger

Competitive Enterprise Institute 1998 – “Implementation of Kyoto Protocol Would Curtail U.S. Trade with Developing Countries, Spark Protectionism” CEI Policy Analysts Say” – http://www.cei.org/gencon/003,02700.cfm

Implementation of mandatory curbs on greenhouse gas emissions in industrialized nations – under a Protocol agreed to at Kyoto in December 1997

 

 

US tariff increase will inginte Chinese attacks on Taiwan

Philip Bowring 8/17/2004 – “China’s New Power Can Be Contained: Northwest Asia” – International Herald Tribune

National sentiments are sprouting in Northeast Asia

 

Terminal impact is nuclear holocaust

Johnson 2001 – The Nation 4/15/2001 – “Time to Bring the Troops Home” p. ebscohost

China is another matter.  No sane figure in the Pentagon

 

CEA CP

 

The United States Congress should approve the Kyoto Protocol as a congressional-executive agreement and should implement it through tradable permits.  The President of the United States should ratify the treaty.

 

Counterplan solves the case – CEAs are interchangeable with treaties under domestic and international law

John C. Yoo 2001 – “Laws as Treaties?: The Constitutionality of Congressional-Executive Agreements” – Michigan Law Review – 99 Mich. L. Rev. 757

According to most international law scholars and authority, however, both presidents easily could have evaded the Treaty Clause by submitting their international agreements as statutes.

 

Senate supermajority process undermines US leadership.  Only the CP breaks the precedent requiring its exclusive use and bolsters leadership.

Phillip R. Trimble and Alexander W. Koff 1998 – 16 Berkeley J. Int’l L. 55

For the United States to play an optimum leadership role in an increasingly interdependent world, the President must prevail over the conservative, isolationist minority in the Senate that has

 

Majority approval of climate change agreements avoids that political struggle of the two-thirds process

Harold K. Jacobson 2002 – “Climate Change: Unilateralism, Realism, and Two-Level Games” – Multilateralism and U.S. Foreign Policy p. 427

Differences in political systems also help explain the divergences between the position of the United States on climate change

 

Empirically, CEAs require less political capital than treaties

Robert Dalton 1999 – http://www.asil.org/dalton.pdf

If the President decides a particular international agreement should be handled

 

Senate treaty ratification is a contentious process that requires much political capital

Donald M. Snow and Eugene Brown 2000 – United States Foreign Policy: Politics Beyond the Water’s Edge – p. 175-6

We should also note the requirement for an extraordinary majority

 

 

 

 

Ratification Specification

 

There are three modes of treaty ratification

John K. Setear  – Journal of Legal Studies January 2002

The mere fact that the executive does not always prevail in a domestic political struggle

 

Topicality

 

A. Our Interpretation – the Affirmative Must Require a Direct Reduction in Fossil Fuel Consumption:

 

1.  Incentives are distinct from requirements

Major Garrett 2002 – CNN Live Event/Special p. lexis

The administration looks at that track record and says it simply doesn’t work.  And a lot of this policy

 

2.  Consumption is distinct from production

David A. Grossman 2003 – 28 Colum. J. Envtl. L.

Governments and other institutions often portray emissions of carbon dioxide solely in terms of consumption

 

B. Violation – upstream permits only require a decrease in production

Congressional Budget Office 2003 – “Issues in the Design of a Cap-and-Trade Program for Carbon Emissions” – Economic and Budget Issue Brief – http://www.cbo.gov/showdoc.cfm?index=4861&sequence=0

Alabama GS Pre Shirley

 

HEIDEGGER K

 

 

A)      The 1AC's desire to act upon the natural world is part of a

managerial utopia guided by the seductive logic of Enframing. This

mode of revealing the world transforms everything in nature to a

stockpile of commodities robbed of all worth.

McWhorter 92, Assistant Professor of Philosophy at Northeast Missouri

State University

[Ladelle, Heidegger and the earth, p. 5-7] bg

Every academic discipline...existence in our age

 

 

B)      Loss of Being brought about by technological thought obliterates

the value of life and is a fate worse than nuclear annihilation

Zimmerman 94, Professor of Philosophy at Tulane University      [Michael

E., Contesting earth's future, p. 119-120] bg

Heidegger asserted... "disclosed" by humanity.

 

 

C)      The Alternative: We must relinquish our will to mastery and refuse

the technological drive to act as the world's savior. Only when we

meditate and let things disclose themselves external of Enframing can

we free ourselves from the totalizing grasp of technology

Sikorski 93, Modernity and Technology

 

 

GREEN CONSUMERISM

 

 

We are approaching the precipice of imminent ecological collapse. At

the heart of the crisis is our metaphysical faith in

industrialization. The urgency of the current ecological crisis could

rupture the productivist discourse that weds us to industrialization.

It also has the potential to cast doubt on the entire system.

Unfortunately, their advocacy of Green Consumerism functions to suture

these ruptures and reinforce a belief system that has us on a road to

Apocalypse.

Toby Smith, The Myth of Green Marketing, p. 3-7

It is with some uncertainty...sustainable community"

Iraq Polls Conclude" Google News wbw

Low Oil Prices risk a violent Saudi Civil War

David 1999 (Steven R.; Professor of Political Science "Johns Hopkins,

Foreign Affairs Jan/Feb l/n wdc/wbw)

"Fabulous oil wealth...major conflagration".

Weapons of Mass Destruction: a Threat to Peace" March

accessed 8/6/04 wdc/wbw)

 

 

Meanwhile, the existence...Trigger a world conflagration." (44)

CONSULT BRAZIL

 

 

Text: The United States Federal Government should enter into prior

binding consultation with the Federative Republic of Brazil over the

mandates of the affirmative plan. The outcome of the consultation

should be implemented.

 

 

CP Solves the Case and Boosts US-Brazilian ties

 

 

Framework for environmental consultations already exists: discussion of

energy issues is uniquely key to US-Brazilian cooperation

United States-Brazil Common Agenda for the Environment 95

[Embassy of Brazil, Oct 23,

http://www.brasilemb.org/environment/environ_brasil_usa_agenda.shtml]

"Recognizing the importance...mutual concern."

 

 

Consultations are key to ensure long-term sustainability of

US-Brazilian relations and prevent an adversarial shift. Genuine

consideration of Brazil's opinions is essential and ensures they'll

ultimately go along with the US agenda.

Hakim 04, President of Inter-American Dialogue

[Peter, "The Reluctant Partner," Foreign Affairs, Jan/Feb, Academic

Search Elite]

This mostly encouraging...specific circumstances.

 

 

Adversarial shift in relations will cause Brazilian nuclearization and

will create multiple scenarios for nuclear conflict

Shultz 00, Research Professor of National Security Policy at US Army War College

[Donald, Research Professor of National Security Policy at the

Strategic Studies Institute of the U.S. Army War College THE UNITED

STATES AND LATIN AMERICA: SHAPING AN ELUSIVE FUTURE, March, pg.

uslatin.pdf]edlee

While we are in a speculative mode...military for answers.  pg. 26-29

 

 

INDO-PAK PIPELINE DA

 

 

A.  US energy policy to reduce fossil fuel consumption will plummet

global oil prices

Business Week 03          [John Carey, "Taming the Oil Beast:  A Sensible,

Step-by-Step Energy Policy is Within Our Reach. Here's What To Do.,"

February 24, pg.

http://www.globalexchange.org/campaigns/oil/722.html]edlee

B.  High oil prices will force India to embrace an Indo-Paki-Iranian pipeline.

Pachauri 00, President @ Asian Energy Institute         [RK, "Not a

pipedream: back to Iran gas pipeline option," The Times of India, 17

August pg. http://www.teriin.org/features/art78.htm]edlee

OPEC is in the news...energy policy.

 

 

C.  The pipeline will serve as Confidence Building Measure preventing

a conflict over Kashmir

Daily Times 04  [ "'Progress on Iran-Pakistan-India pipeline in a

year'" Oct 29, pg.

http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=story_24-10-2004_pg1_1Exclusive]edlee

ISLAMABAD: Prime Minister Shaukat...realistic approach."

 

 

D.  The Kashmir dispute risks Nuclear winter and extinction

Fai 01, Executive director @ Kashmiri American Council.         [Ghulam Nabi,

"The most dangerous place," The Washington Times, July 08, Pg. B4

The foreign policy...Fissile Material/Cut-off Convention.

 

 

POLITICS - SOCIAL SECURITY GOOD

 

 

A)      Bush election victory generated momentum that will ensure social

security privatization

Financial Times 11 / 4 / 04

Mr Bush's victory...Refuge more likely.

 

 

B)      Link

HEIDEGGER K

 

A)             The 1AC's desire to act upon the natural world is part of a

managerial utopia guided by the seductive logic of Enframing. This

mode of revealing the world transforms everything in nature to a

stockpile of commodities robbed of all worth.

 

McWhorter 92, Assistant Professor of Philosophy at Northeast Missouri

State University

[Ladelle, Heidegger and the earth, p. 5-7] bg

 

Every academic discipline...existence in our age

 

B)             Loss of Being brought about by technological thought obliterates

the value of life and is a fate worse than nuclear annihilation

 

Zimmerman 94, Professor of Philosophy at Tulane University [Michael

E., Contesting earth's future, p. 119-120] bg

 

Heidegger asserted... "disclosed" by humanity.

 

C)             The Alternative: We must relinquish our will to mastery and refuse

the technological drive to act as the world's savior. Only when we

meditate and let things disclose themselves external of Enframing can

we free ourselves from the totalizing grasp of technology

 

Sikorski 93, Modernity and Technology

Text: The United States Federal Government should enter into prior

binding consultation with the Federative Republic of Brazil over the

mandates of the affirmative plan. The outcome of the consultation

should be implemented.

 

CP Solves the Case and Boosts US-Brazilian ties

energy issues is uniquely key to US-Brazilian cooperation

http://www.brasilemb.org/environment/environ_brasil_usa_agenda.shtml]

"Recognizing the importance...mutual concern."

US-Brazilian relations and prevent an adversarial shift. Genuine

consideration of Brazil's opinions is essential and ensures they'll

ultimately go along with the US agenda.

Critical Affs:

Framework topicality (cheating)

Whatever you say is bad, we’ll say it’s good and that you can’t solve it even if it’s bad.

 

 

 

 

 

 

can't get to the tubs right now, but here is a list of negative
arguments we typically run.

Generics:
Politics (recent scenarios we have run include social security reform
good, Palestine aid good, and space funding bad)
CO2 fertilization
Oil disads (most are all price-based, country-specific oil disads. We
typically run either Russia or Nigeria; we also have an India-Pakistan
oil argument. High oil prices force India and Pakistan to build a
pipeline that will institute CBM's and solve war)
NMD disad (some NMD inevitable, plan is a concession to Europe to get
them on board for robust NMD, which will cause space weapons)
Clean coal disad (alt NRG kills clean coal; clean coal solves case and econ)
States CP
Consult UK CP
Consult Brazil CP
Topicality (substantial, total= all 4 sectors; require=command and
control only; consumption is not emissions)
ASPEC

Against critical affs:
Framework topicality (we say that you should have to defend your plan
text and its implementation)
Then we usually either run a Derrida K or run disads that link to the
resolutions, and defend consequentialism, utilitarianism, etc.

AT: advantages everyone reads:
competitiveness--compet not key econ or heg; trade turn; new tech
can't last in market

warming--it doens't exist (alternate causalities, feedbacks), CO2
fert, night warming, warming policies are too small

oil--no peak coming, oil price DA's

Free trade--non-unique free trade is up; trade doesn't solve war;
trade bad (hurts enviro, causes damn-building and war, causes poverty)

Case arguments we read against specific affs:

Natural gas affs: Russian NG DA, NG good--solves warming, LNG tankers
and ports are safe,

Coal affs: coal key economy, pollution is decreasing, pollution isn't
harmful, pollution good,

RPS: renewables can't compete; renewables bad

Permits/Kyoto: haven't debated

Nuke Power: can't build plants, accidents, waste, terrorism, nuke
power already growing

CAFE: CAFE can't solve oil/warming; traffic accidents turn; no tech;
bizcon; HIghway Disad (plan guts funds from fuel, destroys HTF and
highways, highways key econ/heg)

Nanotech: Nano-->weapons/war, nano too far away, nano sucks generally
and can't do anything, your authors are freakin' wackos

            Militarism & T

 

            Militarism: - You have to reject the concept of inevitability; Specific Breeds

 

Cites: Cuomo Ev.:

 

Militarism K

                1NC Shell: Links Link The Plan allows the USFG and the military to remain exempt from env. regs.: This means that the American War Machine will continue to attack the planet & its people, Feldman ’04 (Bob, Dollars & Sense, March-April, p.24) “the U.S. war machine bombards civilians. . . and the Pentagon will continue its “war on the earth.”

 

Link: Discursive Violence: War is not an “event that can be predicted or controlled; peace cannot be defined as “the absence of war”; rather, militarism and discursive justifications for war are omnipresent in our everyday lives; the aff. ignores the everyday effects of militarism on women, non-humans, and the env., Cuomo ’96 (Chris, Hypatia, Fall, v11 n4, p.30-46, “War is not just an event: reflections on the significance of everyday violence.”) “Philosophical attention to war has typically appeared in the form of justifications. . . because they justify the destruction of natural nonhuman entities and communities during peacetime.”

 

B. Impacts & Implications: American militarism is the most lethal byproduct of capitalist imperialism; the realist aff. assumption that military force is “justified” or that wars are “winnable” is wrong, and will lead to planetary annihilation; militarism must be rejected at every turn, Meszaros ’03 (Istvan, Monthly Review, Jan., author of Socialism or Barbarism: From the “American Century” to the Crossroads.”) “No matter how monstrous the damage inflicted by . . . make Hitler’s irrationality look like the model of irrationality.”

 

Militarism is embedded in everyday life and discourse and must be rejected b/c it is at the root of racism, sexism, capitalist oppression and the destruction of non-human ecosystems

Cuomo 96

is Key to Economic Growth”

Nuclear Power, and pretty much any other case on the topic.

Natural gas use and transactions are increasing – have grown four-fold since 2002.

“Two main publishers of  natural gas  price”

oversupply.

Clean Coal DA
UNIQUENESS - Bush’s Clean Coal Initiative is pushing coal-fired power construction in the SQ – 280
million being provided now.
Power Engineering, 03/01/2004
“A number of new coal-fired power projects”

B.  LINK - Clean coal and renewables trade-off – increased support for one locks the other out of
the market.
Environment and Energy Daily, 11/24/2003
“U.S. PIRG and other environmentalists”

C. IMPACT – TURNS CASE - Clean coal will solve climate change concerns from use of dirty fossil
fuels.
Regulatory Intelligence Data, 11/14/2003
“While DOE's Fossil Energy budget encompasses”

Backstopping DA
A. LINK – Climate policies will lower the demand for oil worldwide. Faced with declining revenues
oil exporters will flood the market to lower prices and regain market share

ASPEC

 

Kritik: Risk Management Society

 

Contention I:

 

The affirmative’s discussion permeates the fields of scientific and expert knowledge. Their call for de-development produces an institutionalized reality that dominates the dilemma of industrial society

Ulrich Beck, World Risk Society, 1999 p. 29-30

“The social-ecological approach thus” and “reality-in-itself is produced.”


The “reality-in-itself” that they construct is based on contested risk definitions. This constrains actions to risk-based rationality

Ulrich Beck, World Risk Society, 1999 p. 3-4

“As the bipolar world fades away” and “contradictory certainties (Schwarz and Thompson, 1990).”

 

Contention II:

 

Rational management of env issues creates sys of organized irresponsibility. All-around guilt becomes acquittal, very basis of rational control. Must stop conceiving of these issues as “environmental problems.” Instead, engage in reflexive self-definition of the basis of rationality itself.

Ulrich Beck, World Risk Society, 1999 p. 32-33

“This circular movement between symbolic” and “can be ‘forged’ (see the next section).”

 

As long as impose risk defs, risk society will be char. By the paradox of more env. Degredation coupled with expansion in regs. The plan will not solve harms. Risk reentrenching problematic meta-norms.

Ulrich Beck, World Risk Society, 1999 p. 149-50

“The concept of organized irresponsibility” and “scientific legal and political means.”

 

Alternative entails transforming concept of risk from purely neg phenomenon. Instead, risk can be conceieved of in terms of community that takes responsibility for production of risks. First step is to debate these issues in forums like college.

Ulrich Beck, World Risk Society, 1999 p. 14-16

“In the age of globalization” and “afflicted with the same risks.”

 

 

Contention III:

 

Alt: rejected forced imposition of a schemata of risk. Discursive construction of risk defs is a power game with political mobilization at stake. Challening dominant discourse can induce long term trans in power of risk game pols.

Ulrich Beck, World Risk Society, 1999 p. 4-5

“In a world risk society the” and “manufactured uncertainties.”

 

Contention IV:

 

Luke, 1997, The (un)Wise (ab)use of Nature: Environmentalism as globalized consumerism?, http://www.cddc.vt.edu/tim/tims/Tim528.htm

“All of these environmentalizing” and “degradation in our terraformed nature.”

 

Depiction of risk as a threatening shadow is magic wand that politicize previously closed issues at the heart of society’s current constitution. An example is globalization – by invoking potential horrors, fw of welfare st. can be in question.

Ulrich Beck, World Risk Society, 1999, p. 137-138

“Believed risks are the whip used to keep the present day” and “both the bad good life and the threats to it.”

CP – Voluntary

 

The United States Federal Government should establish a depreciation period for capital investment in nuclear power plants of seven years. The USFG should declare its intentions to require that nuclear power constitute fifty percent of non-government electricity by2015 unless electric utilities and other relevant industries voluntarily commit to a self-regulatory scheme that ensures that nuclear pwer constitutes fifty percent of non-governmental electricity generation by2015 meeting this requirement through the construction and us of all needed gas turbine-modular helium reactors. Compliance will be determind by an accredited priveat 3rd party auditor, th USFG should offer public recognition to compliant industries and engage in informational support if requested by industry . the USFG will preempt any contradictory citing decisions.

Iraqi Reconstruction impact

 

High oil prices key to Iraqi reconstruction and government stability – Alhajji 2004 – Prof Buisiness @ Ohio Northern University, The Edge Malaysia, July 26 - “Maintaining the flow of funds into the Iraqi oil sector is essential, not only for its growth, but for it very survival”

 

Failure of Iraqi reconstruction causes global war and terrorism and devastates US leadership – National Review 7-28-2003 - “Shiites will smell opportunity that will only advance their organizing energies.  The Kurds will see no choice but to circle the wagons and begin thinking”

 

Iran Economy Impact

 

High oil prices key to prevent Iranian economic collapse – Economist 9-4-2004 - “Iran has benefited hugely from the high oil prices of the past five years, with its GDP growing at about 6% a year.”

 

Economy is the lynchpin of a stable Iran – Zahedi et al 2004 – Visiting Scholar @ US Berkeley and Law Student @ UC Berkeley, Newsday, November 24 - “History suggests that economic and not just social development must antecede political development, and the key to a peaceful and sustained transition to stable democracy is a propertied middle class.”

 

The impact is massive terrorism, instability in Iraq, and nuclear wars with North Korea – Defense and Foreign Affairs Daily 11-4-2004 - “The response of both the Iranian clerics and the bin Laden networks will be to escalate terrorist, guerilla  and military operations inside Iraq and elsewhere to hold the US at arm’s length, Iran’s response will include even closer coordination with the DPRK (North Korea) leadership of Kim Jong-II”

 

T – Emission not consumption

 

Distinction between emission and consumption – Richardson and Chanwai, 2003, Env Law 2003.15(39), lexis - “The resulting Lord Marshall report recommended that both taxation and tradable emission permits”

 

Energy efficiency is not intrinsically linked to reduced consumption - E Parliament Climate and Energy Action Network 2k3 http://www.e-parl.net/energy/learn/energy-more.htm - “it leads to an energy efficiency imporvment of almost 30% but still has about the same fossil fuel consumption, and, hence, CO2 emissions as today.

1NR-

 

Russia, warming, oil, CP , disad

 

Inevitable US attack

 

They have a Harvard 1NC

 

Each of the 50 states of the united states should establish a primary fuel producer cap and trade system for non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels within each state based on potential emissions requiring a minimum 2-% reduction within 15 years and a minimum 45% reduction within 45 years using 1990 levels in each state as a baseline.  Each state should allocate permits through an annual auction.  Each state should create a registry, if one does not already exist, to register all emissions and emissions trading within the state, based on the EPA’s sulfur dioxide registry.  All relevant actors should defer to the mandates of the counterplan.  Funding and enforcement are guaranteed through all necessary means. 

 

Observation 1- Solvency

 

First- States can do upstream auction tradable permit  policies similar to the FG’s SO2 program! – McKinstry, Maurice K.  (12 Pen St.  Envtl. L. Rev. 15) Winter 2004  “An Alternative approach that would deal effectively include the transportation sector in a climate change strategy without running afoul of challenges based on preemption would be one relying upon price mechanisms.”

 

Second- State policies to reduce GHG emissions don’t violate the doctrine of pre-emption, they are key to innovation.  Hodas, (David, 21 Pace Envtl. L. Rev. 5)

“Generally, from a federalism perspective, it is hard to imagine any argument that state and local GHG initiatives are constitutionally offensive.  They do not conflict with an federal statutes or regulations.” 

 

Third- State registries solve for reductions, enforcement and accuracy.  McKinstry, Maurice K.  (12 Penn St. Envtl. L. Rev. 15) Winter 2004

 

“A final component of the CCAP’s overall vision for state action with respect to reduction in emissions of greenhouse gasses includes a registry for keeping track of and “scoring” the reductions that result from the state’s emission reduction strategy.”

 

Observation 2- Net benefit

 

Avoids politics- state action is below the political radar.

Celli, Chief of civil rights Buereau, 2001

(Andrew, G.  64 Alb, L. rev. 1091)

 

“I also saw that state enforcement officers, like me and like peter lehner, with our small and agile offices operating below the national political radar, that we can use these federal laws in creative and aggressive ways and perhaps a way that is insulated.from the kinds of political pressure that, say, the civil rights difvision of the justice department faces.

International climate politics are about the costs and alternative ways of reducing CO22 emissions.

With legistlation on social security and taxe still in the early stages of development, malpractice is likely to be on eo fhte first of bush’s campain issues.

Whilee steel company execs say they can adapt to a “flexible” program for reducing emissions and still remain globally competitive, the coal industry is digging in for what it is portraying as a life-or—death struggle against mandated reductions in the use of carbon-based fuels.”

Negative Cites

 

 

 

Topicality – Energy Policy = DOE 1NC

 

 

 

A. The Department of Energy is the only topical agency of action

 

US Department of Energy – 2004 (do google search) “The United States Department of Energy (DOE) is a Cabinet-level department….United States Secretary of Energy.”

 

 

 

B. Violation – the Affirmative plan does not implement through the DOE

 

 

 

C. Negative Interpretation is Superior

 

 

 

1. Limits. Only our interpretation gives meaning to energy policy.  The affirmative interpretation conflates energy policy with policy that deals with energy opening up the floodgates of any federal agency.

 

 

 

2. Ground. Our interpretation locks in core negative round linked to the Department of Energy.

 

 

 

D. Voting Issue – Fairness to the negative.

 

 

 

Federalism DA

 

 

 

Federalism is on the brink – the next term will determine whether state rights or federal rights will be preferred

 

CSM – 5-19-2004 “It isn’t that O’Connor has changed her mind….all eyes will be on O’Connor.”

 

 

 

Regulation of electric utilities for retail purposes is a violation of the doctrine of federalism – RPS and other electricity energy policies should be left to the states

 

Public Utilities Fortnightly – 8-2004 (“Leave Green-Power; Quotas to the States”) “Federalism and Electric Power….power quotas to the states.”

 

 

 

Federalism solves many scenarios for wars

 

Ornstein – 1992 (American Enterprise, Jan-Feb) “No word in political theory….forms of federalism.”

 

 

 

2NC Federalism Outweighs

 

1. Risk

 

World Policy Journal – Spring 1999 “The defining mode of conflict in the era ahead….dominant causality.”

 

 

 

2. Magnitude

 

LAT – 2-26-1993 “It is federalism and confederation….Indonesia start disintegrating.”

 

 

 

3. Systemic

 

World Policy Journal – Spring 1999 (“There is usually a multiplicity  of actors and factors…..future of civil wars.”

 

 

 

States CP

 

 

 

The 50 States and all relevant authorities should enact [insert 1AC plan text].  All relevant actors will defer to the mandates of the counter plan.  Funding and enforcement are guaranteed through all necessary means.

 

 

 

Solvency

 

 

 

First – environmental solvency – environmental regulation is too fragmented in the status quo – it makes it vitally important that states have control over environmental policies

 

Smith – 1997 (INSS Occasional Paper 14, Environmental Security Series) “Environmental regulation enforcement and oversight….players in environmental regulation.”

 

 

 

Second – energy solvency – state action on energy policy is necessary to encourage federal reduction of emissions as well as curb CO2 nationally

 

Energy compass – 7-2-2004 “With US President George W. Bush reluctant….require such improvements.”

 

 

 

Third – avoids politics – state action is below the political radar

 

Celli – 2001 (64 Alb. L. Rev. 1091) “I also saw that state enforcement….federal civil rights laws.”

 

 

 

Fourth – solves federalism – states are better actors to enact energy regulations – they are more efficient and effective

 

State Government News – 4-1-2003 “As the battle over the regulation of energy markets continues…..regional energy markets.”

 

 

 

2NC Solvency for States CP

 

 

 

RPS has been enacted in 14 states already – diverse implementation makes state judgment necessary and effective

 

Public Utilities Fortnightly – 8-2004 “The States have experimented with green power….adoption of the green-power quota.”

 

 

 

State RPS policies lead to federal adoption of RPS policies

 

Public Utilities Fortnightly – 8-2004 “The adoption of an RPS by more than a dozen states…5 percent for 2004.”

 

 

 

The states can implement renewable portfolios or tax schemes to downplay GHG emissions

 

Mallory – 1999 (Colorado Journal of Environmental Law and Policy) “Environmentally progressive states….cleaner power production.”

 

 

 

States solve for RPS and greenhouse gas emission reporting

 

US Newswire – 11-14-2002 “Measures that have proven….states want to achieve.”

 

 

 

States can do RPS and GHG policies with no backlash where the federal government can’t act

 

Claussen – 2002 (do a google search) “The current level of state activity surrounding the issue of climate….often with little dissent.”

 

 

 

States solve better – federal RPS will include a dirty definition of renewable energy

 

Energy Justice Network – 2004 (www.energyjustice.net/rps/) “On the national level, the only RPS….lobby for the energy bill.”

 

 

 

A2: renewable energy credits are not transferable

 

 

 

Renewable energy portfolio credits are tradable between states under the counter plan

 

Engel – 1999 (Kristen, Ecology Law Quarterly) “Unlike state-issued marketable emission permits….renewable portfolio standard.”

 

 

 

The court will strike down the law of any state that attempts to prohibit interstate trades

 

Engel – 1999 (cited above) “Under the landmark case Philadelphia….Commerce Clause challenges.”

 

 

 

CLEAN COAL DA – 1NC

 

 

 

A.UQ – Bush’s clean coal initiative is pushing coal-fired power construction in the SQ – 280 million being provided now

 

Power engineering, 03/01/2004

 

“A number of new coal-fired…coal-based power plants”

 

 

 

B.Link – Clean coal and renewables trade-off – increased support for one locks the other out of the market

 

Environment and Energy Daily 11/24/03

 

“US PIRG and other…PIRG in a statement”

“While DOE’s Fossil Energy budget…global climate change”

 

 

 

 

 

NATURAL GAS ADV ANS

 

 

 

The probability of their impact is extremely low – LNG has been transported across the ocean thousands of times, there have been no fatalities and even when antiship missiles hit a tanker it didn’t explode

“Since 1959…occurred on land”

 

 

 

Natural gas is a bridge – it independently decreases CO2

 

Business Wire, 03/13/02

 

“Natural gas is the cleanest fossil fuel…efficiency and renewable energy”

 

 

 

Natural gas is key to fuel cells – results in no emissions

 

http://www.naturalgas.org/, 05/19/98

 

“lastly, fuel cell technology…pure enough to drink”

 

 

 

Natural gas will cause a 40% reduction in emissions

 

The Houston Chronicle, 03/07/02

WARMING ADV ANS

 

 

 

A. Satellites

 

Essex and McKitrick 2002 Taken By Storm, p. 132-133.

 

“The thermometers in white boxes…there is no upward trend”

 

 

 

B. Cities

 

Michaels and balling 2000 The Satanic Gases p. 76-78

 

“These considerations aside…it will grow exponentially”

 

 

 

C. weather stations

 

Essex and McKitrick again, 138-140.

 

 

 

Humans don’t cause warming

 

a.Sunspot cycles cause climate change

 

Idso 2003 Center for the Study of Carbon Dioxide and Global Change, Volume 6, Volume 37: 9/10

 

“In a recent discussion published…of the last quarter century”

 

 

 

b.Causes cooling now

 

Idsos again

 

“With respect to the future…already-in-progress, global cooling”

 

 

 

No consensus

 

a. Mainstream scientists dissent from warming hypothesis

 

Essex and McKitrick again, p. 42-43.

 

“Another selection strategy of the media is the lack of attention…as has been charged”

 

 

 

Uncertainty

 

a. Temperature based predictions have no scientific basis

Berkeley RS Neg

            Round # 6  Shirley

            Vs Team: Mary Washington PW

            Judge: Jason Russell

 

 

            Off Case Args:

Productionist Metaphysics

 

The plan’s managerialism of “natural resources” forces us to conceptualize the things on the earth as standing reserves or sets of commodities.  This is a mode of scientific thought that is obliterating other typs of being by enforcing an evacuation of mystery from the world. Mcwhorter, Heidegger and the earth, 1992, pg. 4-7

 

At the very pinnacle of this technological culture a fundamental reversal of traditions subject/object dichotomy sets in. Machine technology now rebels against us.  We become slaves to a technological mode of being that uproots us from earth in an infinite quest of magnification of power.  Social hierarchies and disciplines are produced in order to master humanity and make us amenable to the demand of technology’s call to master the earth. Zimmerman, 1990, Heidegger’s Confrontation with Modernity, pg. 199-202.

 

Ontological damnation outweigh nuclear war. Zimmerman 1997, Contesting the Earth’s Future: Radical Ecology and Postmodernity, 199-20

 

Security link.  Der Derian 1993, “The value of security: Hobbes, Marx, Nietzshe, and Baudrillard,” The Political Subject of Violence, 101-5

 

Reason is complicit in the form of international life that has brought about the prospect of extinction by setting the parameters of the political to fuel violent practices.  Campbell and Dillon, “The political and the ethical” The Political Subject of Violence, 1993, 163-4

 

Framing famine as a “failure of development” depoliticizes the discussion of hunger.  Famines are a symptom of modernity.  Embracing technical solutions reinscribes the very politics that create the conditions for famine in the first place. Edkins, 2000, Whose Hunger? Concepts of Famine, Practices of Aid,  xv-xvi

 

Modern agriculture is built on a shaky foundation of technology and control conditions that make famine more likely.  Edkins again, 35-7

 

Text to the alternative: reject the affirmative.

 

We must reflect upon the strangeness of being to retrieve possibilities of thought that allows the world to show itself on its own terms. The call to do nothing is a paradoxical path that reveals new possibilities by challenging the bimodal logic of activity.  Mcwhorter again, p. 1-4

 

Devotion to the Other before devotion to myself is a responsibility without limits that reconfigures our understanding of subjectivity because our subjectivity is constituted by our relationship with the Other. Campbell and Dillon again pg 169-71

The USFG should do plan except within regards to working poor

There is no alternative for lower class workers- the CP justly puts the burden in the wealthy. “Some of the most innovative” and “poor workers who have no alternative”

www.ppionline.org/documents/far_from_home.pdf

 

Automobiles gurantee personal autonomy- “As the automobile enters its second century” and “because it is inherently good” www.cei.org/pdf/1437.pdf

Kritiks of autos risk totalitarianism Cite above “Rather, I am convinced that the automobile’s” and “to leave the cars in the garage”

Violence is never an act of resistance

NEGATIVE ARGUMENTS:

 

Violence 101

The arg – Structural analysis of violence is bad. We must interrogate personal will to violence by politicizing the way we think.

Main cite[s] – Susan Kappeler, The Will to Violence

                Jayan Nayar – the law review article everyone reads

 

Superpower Syndrome

The arg – Hegemony is basically a quest for empire. Empathy is the alternative.

Main cite[s] – Robert Lifton, Superpower Syndrome

 

Political Subject of Violence

The arg – This is a threat construction/security/realism bad criticism. The alternative is aesthetics + Levinas’ arguments about responsibility.

Main cite[s] – David Campbell and Michael Dillon, The Political Subject of Violence

 

Productionist Metaphysics Bad

The arg – Managerialism is bad. Buys into tech mode of being. Ontological damnation. Do nothing is the alternative.

Main cite[s] – Ladelle McWhorter, Heidegger and The Earth

Boston College SS Neg

            Round #  Shirley

            Vs Team:  Cornell BF

            Judge: Kerry Coleman

 

            Case Args:

 

 

            Off Case Args:

Text:  The United States Supreme Court should rule through necessary means that Federal Government energy policy that bans the use and production of synthetic fertilizers and pesticides in the United States is an inappropriate use of federal power, thus a violation of the 10th amendment, and that state governments should have the authority to ban the use and production of synthetic fertilizers and pesticides in the United States.  The fifty state governments and necessary authorities should establish an energy policy that requires a substantial reduction in total non-governmental fossil fuel consumption by banning the use and production of synthetic fertilizers and pesticides in the United States.  Funding and enforcement as necessary.

 

 

 

aff PLAN: THE UNITED STATES FEDERAL GOVERNMENT SHOULD ESTABLISH AN ENERGY POLICY THAT REQUIRES A SUBSTANTIAL REDUCTION IN TOTAL NON-GOVERNMENTAL FOSSIL FUEL CONSUMPTION BY BANNING THE USE AND PRODUCTION OF SYNTHETIC FERTILIZERS AND PESTICES IN THE UNITED STAETS.  ENFORCEMENT THROUGH NORMAL MEANS.

 

 

            Block Strategy:

Business Confidence and Politics cites:   (these full cards because Alex Foster found the cards during the round- we didn’t type up the whole texts or anything)

PRODUCT BANS DESTROY BUSINESS CONFIDENCE

Segal 03 – Clean Air Act: Alternative Fuels and Fuel Additives” senate hearing March 20 -81-82

While Congress has acted to ban certain toxic chemicals, it has never done so without an extensive scientific record and, in some cases, with an opportunity for the appropriate administrative agency to revisit the prohibition based on additional factual information. Congress has enacted only one statutory prohibition on a toxic chemical, a ban on PCBs in the Toxic Substances Control Act, enacted in 1976. But even this prohibition allowed EPA to permit the use of PCBs where it could be shown that there was no unreasonable risk. Furthermore, while EPA has taken regulatory action before to take chemicals out of commerce, such as asbestos, lead, and a few major pesticides, EPA only exercised its authority after substantial scientific analysis and an opportunity for public review and comment. Contrary to this precedent, S. 2962 neither allows EPA to make additional findings concerning the actual risk to human health nor allows EPA to exercise its regulatory expertise to provide for exceptions or changes based on changed circumstances. In this respect, the ban of MTBE is both arbitrary and unprecedented.

The ban of MTBE in also objectionable because it is to be implemented in 4 years or less. In other parts of the Clean Air Act, Congress has taken action to prohibit the sale of certain chemicals or change the design of certain products, but never according to such an abrupt schedule. In Title VI of the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments, for example, Congress mandated a phaseout of Class I chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) over a 10-year period, and a phaseout of Class II CFCs over a 30-year period. Likewise, in Title IV of the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments, Congress ordered a reduction in emissions of sulfur dioxide over a 10-year period. Title II of the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments provides for a tightening of standards for automobile emissions that extends in a two-step process over 11 years. Indeed, the investments required to make the Clean Air Act RFG work were substantial enough to warrant a 5-year planning and implementation period. It is hard to understand the rationale for banning the use of MTBE in 4 years or less.

The ban on MTBE in 4 years or less raises issues of both workability and fairness. MTBE constitutes approximately 3 percent of the total national gasoline pool, and approximately 10 percent of the gasoline pool in areas of the United States using RFG. It is unlikely that gasoline markets can adjust to this lost volume without significant price increases and supply disruptions. And even as more crude oil is used to meet the demand for motor vehicle fuels, the supplies of crude oil necessary to produce home heating oil are reduced.

Finally, the ban on MTBE in 4 years or less is unfair to those who took risks and committed significant resources to make the RFG program successful. As Chairman Smith has stated on several occasions, Congress created the market for fuel additive oxygenates for an important purpose--to address serious air quality problems in many areas of the United States. MTBE producers, especially petrochemical companies, made significant investments to provide the necessary volumes of oxygenates. The ban on MTBE in 4 years or less deprives these producers of a reasonable return on their investment and may threaten their economic well being and the economic well being of their shareholders.

The ban on MTBE not only harms MTBE manufacturers, it also sets a dangerous precedent that could inhibit the success of federally mandated environmental programs in the future. While Congress can establish conditions for participating in interstate commerce, it cannot compel a business to produce a particular product. Thus, to encourage the development of such products, Congress must ensure that the rules for participating in markets are clear and fair, and that the participant has a reasonable expectation to earn a return on an investment. The proposed ban on MTBE in 4 years or less sends a disquieting message that Congress can arbitrarily change the rules at any time, with potentially ruinous consequences for those who have taken risks and made good faith investments.

-not

COMPETIVENESS LINK – PEST. KEY TO COMP

Biz con 1NC link

 

Biotech increases genetic diversity

 

 

 

ECON U

RISE IN INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION AND HOME OCNSTRUCTION PROVE ECON STRONG

NYT 11/18/04

Industrial production and new home construction rose sharply last month, suggesting that the economy is overcoming high energy prices and rebounding from the summer slump. But a spike in consumer prices is also stoking worries that inflation might spread more broadly as the economy heats up.

The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that industrial production rose 0.7 percent in October, the fastest pace since July. In addition, the Commerce Department reported that new housing starts had recovered from a September dip to rise 6.4 percent last month.

Investors in financial markets seemed encouraged by the emerging panorama of economic strength, as prices of stocks and bonds rose sharply on the news.

''The manufacturing recovery continues to build broad momentum, evidenced by the fact that 16 out of 19 manufacturing sectors increased production last month,'' said John Engler, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.

 

 

 

3.5% GDP GROWTH PREDICTED OVER THE NEXT 5 YEARS

 

Perryman 11/14/04

In fact, from 2000 to 2003, the pace of U.S. productivity growth was the fastest in more than a half century. What can we expect for the next five years? Healthy economic growth.

Specifically, the U.S. economy is forecast to see expansion in real gross domestic product (GDP) over the next five years at a pace of 3.47 percent per year with an annual growth rate of 1.46 percent.

Of particular note is strong projected expansion in defense, semiconductors, food processing, and building products, as well as industrial and transportation equipment.

While manufacturing is highly important to America's economy, service-related activities will play the dominant role in producing jobs.

America's payrolls have seen steady increases during the past year with about 2.1 million jobs created. The unemployment rate has dipped to9ts lowest level in three years, even while the available work force has gradually expanded.

Small businesses, which create about 70 percent of new jobs and generate over half of the nation's economic output, are well positioned to flourish in the future.

Productivity has grown in every quarter since the second quarter of 2001. These gains are expected to continue and will enable economic growth while maintaining price stability.

These gains stem primarily from greater incorporation of technology and enhanced efficiency.

 

 

A2: DOLLAR CRASH

-good economic reports will reverse the dollar slide

Reuters 11/18/04

“some analysts said the market will eventually wake up and” AND “dollar to reverse”

 

FOREIGNERS WON’T DUMP US DOLLARS

Pittsburg Post Gazette 11/18/04

Even with such negative factors potentially at work, there is no chance that foreigners would dump their dollar-backed holdings entirely. That would drive up the value of their currencies and cause big portfolio losses.

 

FALLING DOLLAR WILL IMPROVE US ECON

Pittsburg Post Gazette 11/18/04

“and there are plenty of economists who believe the sinking dollar is good news” AND “current account and trade deficits”

 

JAPAN WILL INTERVENE TO PROP UP THE DOLLAR

Washington Times 11/18/04

Japanese authorities indicated yesterday that they might intervene as the dollar breached 104 yen, saying they were watching closely.

Their support has prevented the dollar's fall from spilling over into the U.S. bond market and driving up interest rates. Japan is the largest foreign holder of U.S. Treasury securities with $722 billion as of August, according to the Treasury Department.

 

A2: INFLATION

OCTOBER INFLATION IS A ONE TIME EVENT

WMRC 11/18/04

“likely top rove a largely one-off event” AND “moderating influence on the CPI”

 

CORE INFLATION RATE SHOWS NO THREAT FROM INFLATION

MENAFN.com 11/18/04

“excluding food and energy costs” AND “during the first 10 months of 2004” AND “smallest gain in four decades”

 

A2: DECLINE IN LEADING ECONOMIC INDICATORS

 

Declines don’t point to economy entering recession

AP 11/18/04

“recent declines in the index have not been large enough or persistent enough” OR “election and high oil prices”

 

A) BUSH WILL GAIN INCREASED FUNDING FOR NASA

Space Politics 11/16/04

Recent news accounts suggest a tone of cautious optimism about the fate of NASA's FY2005 budget, as Congress reconvenes today for a brief lame-duck session. CongressDailyPM reported late Monday that while a budget cut of 0.75 percent is in the works for non-defense, non-homeland security agencies, NASA may be exempt from this cut and instead get an additional $800 million. The article doesn't specify, though, from what baseline this money would be added to: if it's the President's original budget it's good news, but less so if it's from the House version of the budget, which cut $1.1 billion from the President's request back in July.

 

PASSING ENERGY POILCIES DRAINS POLITICAL CAPITAL

Fox News 8/8/03

Legislatively, Congress has long been resistant to changes in energy policy, in part because it means making hard choices that are sure to annoy constituents from environmentalists to suburban homeowners who don't want power lines and electrical facilities in their neighborhoods.

To get anything done, however, Bush will likely need to employ his political capital and may find himself looking for compromises with Democrats as he has done before.

 

BUSH POL CAP KEY TO SPACE FUNDING

LA Times 11/16/04 In an initial trial of the fresh "political capital" that he said he earned in winning a second term, President Bush will try to persuade the lame-duck Congress that convenes today to approve money for a host of spending initiatives -- from helping community colleges to exploring outer space.

In an initial trial of the fresh "political capital" that he said he earned in winning a second term, President Bush will try to persuade the lame-duck Congress that convenes today to approve money for a host of spending initiatives -- from helping community colleges to exploring outer space.

 

C) IMPACTS

 

FULL FUNDING OF BUSH’S SPACE PLAN KEY TO PREVENT A DECLINE IN US GLOBAL COMPETITITVENESS

Donohue 9/9/04 (Thomas J-President and CEO of the United States Chamber of Commerce) http://www.space-exploration.us

President Kennedy’s vision in the 1960s—and strong congressional support of NASA and the space program in the ensuing years—helped produce a “pipeline” of technological talent for the private sector workforce in the form of scientists, engineers, and mathematicians. Early U.S. space programs energized Americans, enabling the federal government to invest in new technologies and industries, recruit the best young minds, and exploit the scientific and economic benefits of space. These programs also provided the underpinning for a robust industrial base that led to U.S. industry dominance of the global high technology marketplace. For the past 40 years, NASA scientists and engineers helped create entire new industries and transferred more than 10,000 NASA-developed technologies to the private sector. Nearly every U.S. industry has benefited from NASA discoveries, especially key industrial sectors such as transportation, public safety, and health and medicine. GPS (Global Positioning System), smoke detectors, and special biopsy needles are just a few examples of real-world applications of NASA-developed technologies. Clearly, Americans have gotten a huge return on their modest investment in our space program. It vindicates those who bravely and painstakingly pursued a vision that skeptics once called unaffordable, foolhardy, and wasteful. Even as America’s high-tech workforce is aging—more than 27% of the aerospace workforce is expected to retire by 2008—and our nation’s global competitiveness hangs in the balance, the naysayers are at it again, dismissing the president’s plan as too expensive and unimportant. Their voices must not prevail. Instead of gutting NASA’s budget and discarding the president’s bold plan, Congress should seize the opportunity to make an investment in our economic and technological future. NASA’s FY 2005 budget will be the first spending plan to have a direct impact on the Vision for Space Exploration. It is essential that Congress provide NASA its full funding request so that the Vision can become reality.

a) bush space plan key to maintaining mil supremacy against china

Reuters 1/14/04

b) Chinese space dominance leads to Taiwan invasion

Li Thian-Hok Tapei Times 11/1/03

“by far the most important justification” AND “objective is to subjugate Taiwan and secure a fiat”

T Requiring

 

 

A.  Definitions

 

 

1.  Policy means definite action

Words and Phrases 1956 (Permanent Edition, Volume 32A) p. 486

Ordinarily, Legislature’s distinct statement

 

 

2. Requiring means mandatory or compulsory action in the nature of a command

Michael J. Smolenski, Judge, Court of Appeals of Michigan, 9/8/1995 (Samuel

Indenbaum, M.D., and Felix J. Liddell, M.D. v Michigan Board of Medicine and

Michigan Department of Licensing and Regulation Court of Appeals of

Michigan, 1995 Mich. App. LEXIS 412) p. lexis

Unless defined in the statute, every word or phrase

 

 

 

States CP 1NC

States can enact energy policy in every sector we solve 100% of the case

Barry G. Rabe, Professor of Environmental Policy, University of Michigan,

and Director, Program in the Environment, University of Michigan, 2004

(Statehouse and Greenhouse: The Emerging Politics of American Climate

Change) p. xiii

Collectively, these policies may point to an alternative policy

 

 

Net Benefits

 

 

Extending the Court enforcement of federalism is critical to continued

consolidation of international federalism and thereby induce future peace,

free trade, economic growth, and protection of human rights

Steven G. Calabresi, Professor of Constitutional Law, Formerly Law Clerk,

Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia, Court of Appeals Judge Robert H. Bork,

and Ralph K. Winter, and Served in the Reagan and Bush Administrations,

December 1995 (“A Government of Limited and Enumerated Powers: In Defense of

United States v. Lopez” Michigan Law Review) p. lexis

The conventional wisdom is that Lopez is nothing more than

Concordia FC Pre Shirley

 

Our negative arguments

 

Technological Focus Argument-

 

Focusing on changing technology precludes focus on transforming self.  Production changes trade off directly with consumption changes.

Thomas from Global Environmental Governance on Academic Search Premier in 2004

 

There is no escape through technology- Jenny Edkins from Whose Hunger in 2000 p. 145-156 (several cards)

 

Drivers Ed counterplan- do drivers ed.   Saves the environment and avoids the technology argument.

Hayworth and Simmons in 2001

 

Zizek-

Main argument is that there is an ongoing soft revolution where all changes are swept up into a culture of constant change.   Only opposing the system of constant change, capitalism, can initiate transformation.

Badiou

 

Value positions are espistimological, they directly effect how we predicate action in the world

Rothberg 2001 Criticism 43.4

 

Affirmative fixes external evil, this is symptomatic of the larger problems of modern ethics.  Finding external evils to resolve prevents challenges to the structure of the system.

Alain Badiou from his interview in Cabinet Magazine in 2002

 

Alternative is to embrace radical vision of the good, unconditional advocacy of a particular truth event can be revolutionary.

Alain Badiou again from Cabinet Magazine

 

Desire politics

 

Political systems hide the functions that create desire in the first place, manipulating the symptoms furthers the antagonisms in the subject that produce desire in the first place.

Jenny Edkins 1999 p. 138

 

The antagonism will burst forth, the question is how.  Allowing the fantasy to collapse on its own leads to violence.

Stavrakakis 1999 p. 100-101

 

Start with the causes of desire deconstructing fantasy structures

Jenny Edkins 1999 p. 142

A2: GMOs Solve

“Are there legitimate… reactions in humans.”

 

GMOs are bad killing beneficial insects, contaminates the ecological system and contaminates food

Gyco-Shim 2003 “Intellectual Property Protection of Biotechnology and Sustainable Development in International Law” North Carolina Journal of International Law and Commercial Regulation Lexis

“Criticisms against agriculture… contaminated human bodies.”

 

Energy is not sexy for November’s election – despite rising gas prices, no one cares

Resolutionality Position

Radical Democracy Position

Against Macalester CM

 

Counterplan- declare a no fossil fuel day each year.

Solves consciousness raising with out killing people.

 

Derrida critique- affirmative is a blood sacrifice, trades one life for another, this is always wrong regardless of the universal context, derrida 1995 p 84-87

 

This blood sacrifice precludes openness to the other, which is a higher political priority then the affirmative

Fashing 1993 p 10-11

Stuff from other tournaments

 

Foucault/Agamben position

The tags of this position change from round to round depending on what the affirmative says, the tags here should lay out what our position basically tries to do.

 

Politics have been forever trapped in the conflation of zoe and bios, the beautiful day of the affirmative is forever trapped in the bloody politics of bare life.

Agamben 1998 p 10

 

Police action/enforcement utilize notion of life as biological

Luke “discourses of evnvironment”  ed darier, 1999 p 197

Technological Focus Argument- This argument has not changed all year.

 

Focusing on changing technology precludes focus on transforming self.  Production changes trade off directly with consumption changes.

Thomas from Global Environmental Governance on Academic Search Premier in 2004

 

There is no escape through technology- Jenny Edkins from Whose Hunger in 2000 p. 145-156 (several cards)

 

Will To Power

 

A.       The will to power is omnipresent.  Individuals thinking about the environment is predicated upon notions of control, finding the world to be a machine to be more effecently controlled.

Adrian DelCaro 2004 Environmental Ethics (Journal) p. 317

 

B.       the affirmative holds onto desire to change the world, an act which will destroy that world

Matthews 1999 card includes the phrase “tear down the old”

 

C.       Zupancic 2003 p. 47-49 Religion and belief are configured around fantastic calls to save your soul and the fallen world, this is the tactic of a world destroying belief

D.       Alternative- reestablish relationship with the environment based on being animal, not upon being human.

DelCaro 2004 p. 320

 

Extension evidence- the Zupancic 2003 p. 53-57, the champagine-xanax conflation argument, affirmative enjoyment is for the status quo world destroying ethics.

 

Zizek- Revolutionary Grace

We read a sampler of cards.  Main argument is that there is an ongoing soft revolution where all changes are swept up into a culture of constant change.  Only opposing the system of constant change, capitalism, can initiate transformation.

Badiou- the truth-event

 

Value positions are espistimological, they directly effect how we predicate action in the world

Rothberg 2001 Criticism 43.4

 

Affirmative fixes external evil, this is symptomatic of the larger problems of modern ethics.  Finding external evils to resolve prevents challenges to the structure of the system.

Alain Badiou from his interview in Cabinet Magazine in 2002

 

Alternative is to embrace radical vision of the good, unconditional advocacy of a particular truth event can be revolutionary.

Alain Badiou again from Cabinet Magazine

 

Extension will include indictments of fear appeals to create environmental action, this is utilized as a case turn.   Often read evidence from this article: http://trumpeter.athabascau.ca/content/v14.2/brown.html

 

Desire politics

 

Political systems hide the functions that create desire in the first place, manipulating the symptoms furthers the antagonisms in the subject that produce desire in the first place.

Jenny Edkins 1999 p. 138  (we read from the book “post structuralism and international relations” not sovereignty and subjectivity, although that is a good book)

 

The antagonism will burst forth, the question is how.  Allowing the fantasy to collapse on its own leads to violence.

Stavrakakis 1999 p. 100-101

 

Start with the causes of desire deconstructing fantasy structures

Jenny Edkins 1999 p. 142

 

New Additions to this position in 2nd semister:

 

The critique has been expanded to argue that notions of “root causes” are attempts to sublimate the real with objects of desire.  The evidence we read here is from Badiou in his 1999 article; “one divides into two” http://www.lacan.com/divide.htm

 

We will make two claims from this article:

A.       The affirmative attempts to free politics from the constraints of the real is the cause of massive violence, analysis of a root cause attempts to free politics

Badiou 99

The card starts with …But the acts of violence, often so extreme? The hundreds of thousands of dead? The persecutions, especially against intellectuals? One will say the same thing about them as about all the acts of violence that have marked the history, to this very day, of any expansive attempts to practice a free politics….ends at the end of the paragraph

 

B.       The act of finding the root grasps for semblance, not the real itself. 

Badiou 99

The card has this sentence in it, just that paragraph, it’s a long paragraph

Thought, precisely because what drives it is not the ideal but the real, must seize hold of appearance as appearance, or of the real as pure event of its own appearance.

 

The role of the intellectual is to offer critique that draws out the concealment of the real, the act of critique alone is enough to justify a ballot

Edkins 1999 p 118; card uses the phrase “the role of”

 

Constant skepticism of claims that bring closure to the real is the most productive political act

Edkins 1999 p. 120

 

Interesting Extension Card;

Omission is Commission

Raymie Mckerrow 1989 Comm Monographs Card starts at “Principle # 6”

 

Western Knowledge Critique

 

The knowledge we arrive at in debate is not value neutral, language is us, it is Western thought

Vine Deloria p.101, 1999)

Disciplining effects of the language of resolution

Vine Deloria p. 135, 138-9

Conceiving physical reality as a machine squeezes out emotion

Vine Deloria 139

Conceptual thinking crowds out way of thinking, cause and effect strategy

Vine Deloria

We need new capacities for knowing, can such new capacities be generated

Douglas Sloan 2002, 29-33

Baum describes a new concepts

We believe the we can only be who we are and experience language as event

 

We also read evidence from Deloria’s associate Ann Waters, however I never carded it, and I lost the evidence, it was a handout from a class, so I don’t have the memory of researching it.

We read extension evidence, the Rahnema actomaina card, Post-Development reader 1997, I believe it’s on page 342-3.  

Binghampton

Authors:

AT: COMPETITIVENESS

No evidence supports enacting regulations to spur growth

Adam Jaffe and Robert Stavins, Journal of Economic Literature, March 1995

“Overall, the evidence we have reviewed suggests” AND “breed of market-based approaches.”

 

Aff authors assume regulation has no cost—any tech generated by regulation will be worse than tech businesses would have found on their own

Morris Altman, Ecological Economics, 2001, Vol. 36, p. 35-6

“The traditional models used to critique the” AND “will incur additional costs to the firm.”

 

Short term costs outweigh the risk of long-term benefit

Karen Palmer and David Simpson, Resources, Summer 1993, p. 18

“We must also note that being a leader” AND “used for other purposes today.”

 

Competitiveness screws over developing countries

Tech Central Station, 11-13-2003, l/n

“In doing the cost-benefit analysis on government” AND “they have comparative advantage.”

 

 

AT: WARMING

Plan won’t solve warming—even with full compliance, there’s no measurable difference

Boston Phoenix, 7-9-2004

“Despite the high financial costs for abiding” AND “ground-based temperature gauges.”

 

Even Kyoto is too small—all countries must make big cuts

IAEA, 2002, Beyond Kyoto, p. 12

“However, even with ratification” AND “participate in the Kyoto agreement.”

 

Must reduce emissions 80% to solve

Ian Rowland, Alternatives Journal, Vol. 30, Issue 1, Winter 2004, ebscohost, p. 19

“But energy efficiency gains will only” AND “no limits upon global emissions.”

 

No impact to warming until 2100

Stephen Gardiner, Ethics and International Affairs, 2004, Vol. 18, Issue 1, ebscohost, p. 29-30

“Carbon dioxide, the main anthropogenic” AND “for wanting that pollution to stop.”

 

Warming impacts will take centuries

IAEA, 2002, Beyond Kyoto, p. 13

“Climate change is also a long-term issue” AND “than in decades or centuries.”

 

No impact to waiting

Jerry Taylor, 1-16-1998, Cato Speeches

“Assuming even the worst about” AND “changes to Western civilization.”

 

CO2 and methane decreasing—IPCC ignores

Patrick Michaels, 7-29-1998, http://www.cato.org/testimony/ct-pm072998.html

“Dlugokency et al” AND “other atmospheric reactants” AND “emphasis) has increased.”

 

GHG increase is slowing

James Hansen and Makiko Sato, Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 12-18-2001

“Fig. 4 shows the growth rate of GHG forcing” AND “by the Montreal protocol” AND “injection into the deep ocean.”

 

Strong neg feedbacks overwhelm CO2

Idso and Idso, 2002, http://co2science.org/about/position/globalwarming.htm

“Strong negative climatic feedbacks prohibit” AND “increases in the air’s CO2 content.”

“Indonesia’s hydrocarbon resources” AND “production-sharing agreements.”

 

Any shock would capsize fragile American LNG investment
