“What could capsize LNG” AND “industry will not develop along a” AND “ups and downs of a commodities market.”

Dartmouth BrMa Neg

Rnd #3

Vs. Wake CH

Judge: MacCartney

 

1NC

Death Cult

Agenda – the affirmative frames the ballot in strategies to avoid death, this turns debate into a death cult and terminates the joy of living. Lumley 1998

Vote Negative – you should reject the affirmative because they use the plan to avoid death.

We agree that we should use the best policy option, but we first should establish limits. This is a theory argument about how we should debate that sets limits on how we justify actions

 

We wont make cross-apps from other flows to prove the link

 

Permission Slip

Permits are liscenses to pollute 0 this socially legitimates environmental destruction behavior by making pollution just one more item to be bought and sold

Goodin 1994 “Selling Environmental Indulgences”

 

Permits make the environment into an object for control and domination. The plan’s use of commensurability reinforces the hegemony of the market values displacing social and ethical questions in favor of technical debates about efficiency

Levin and Espeland 2000

“commensuration facilitates transformations of” and “object of domination”

 

The reduction of all choices to commensurable value justifies the elimination of the invaluable

Dillon 1999

“zero point of holocaust”

 

Permit systems reduce all values to individual gain. This threatens ecological collapse turning the case

Tokar 1996 “Trading Away the Earth”

 

Policy choices structure our cultural and symbolic understanding of the environment and social choice. The affirmative’s permit scheme frames the environment as a commodity subject to the logic of the marketplace and people as purely rational actors. This framing crowds out alternative values that cannot be represented in terms of cost-benefit analysis

Levin and Espeland 2000

 

Relations

No risk of nuclear terrorism

Kamp 1999 “WMD Terrorism: An Exchange”

“these anxieties aside, religious zealots or political extremists” and “seems very unlikely”

 

Common values means the US and Europe will always cooperate on terrorism Schily 2003 “Even if some aspects of transatlantic cooperation may change” and “ contacts at very high levels”

 

CP

CAP without trade sends the social message of restraining the operation of the market

Goodin 1994 “Selling Environmental Indulgences”

 

Competitiveness

Domestic regulations not key – US Firms can still sell technology to other countries. IF renewables are the “market of the future,” strong demand internationally should compel US Companies to develop them inevitability.

 

No internal link to heg

a.              Oil disproves –importing renewables from Europe or Japan is infinitely beter for our hegemony than importing from Saudi Arabia.

b.              Growth won’t allow others to catch up

Ferguson 2003 “But GDP doesn’t stand for great diplomatic power” and “Suffering serious social growing pains”

 

No Challengers

Liberman 2001

“With the disappearance of the Soviet Union” and “engage vital US interests”

 

Businesses know better than government – if they can use new tech to increase competitiveness and profits, they’ll do it. Only a risk the plan will hurt their profits

 

Innovation wont solve competitiveness – tech will just diffuse to low-wage countries

Blecker 2000 Competitiveness Matters 54-55

 

Takes out the other advantages – if markets for renewables are inevitable, that means solving climate/oil is inevitable

 

Competitiveness doesn’t affect economic growth

Krugman 1994

 

Turn Plan hurts competitiveness

a.              Fossil Fuel reductions devastate competitiveness through prices and leakage

Long 1995

“reductions in energy-related greenhouse” and “lower energy taxes”

b.              Aff studies underestimate costs by excluding 6 key variables

Esty and Geradin 1998

“ economic literature may have systematically underestimated pollution” and “productivity losses”

 

Warming

Even if we completely cut emissions, developing countries will overwhelm

Gardiner 2004 Ethics and International Affairs

 

Climate stabilization is impossible without developing countries

Podesta 2003

“greenhouse gases are growing faster in poor countries than in rich ones”

 

2NC

Goes for the all case arguments, CP and the K. 2NC CP Cites

Impact turns for the deficits cites

 

Main CP arguments

Permits undermine long term efficiency and investment

Deter innovation t/s risen 1998

Same incentive to cheat under the plan

Markets are more coercive than the government

Commodifying nature is bad

 

Spending is key to Economic Recovery

Navy News week 9-30-2002 “Grasso rejected arguments that” and “more realistic valuation of stocks”

Dartmouth CS Neg v Northwestern @ Dart RR

 

Northwestern read previously read PP AFF

Dartmouth ran T-require, Vagueness, CP, DA and framework ethics of PP

 

“CP – The USFG should use the precautionary principle as the criteria for formulating and implementing regulations on the non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels in the US except when they are used in the production, dissemination, and implementation of renewable energy technologies, in the US such that precautionary measures apply even if some cause and effect relationships proving harm to present or future human or non-human communities cannot be established scientifically we’ll clarify.”

 

PIC’s good

 

NB

A.  The plan’s massive cut in fossil fuel use prevents transition to alternative energy.  Energy shortage would cause social catastrophe and massive starvation

 

Jesse Tatum ’95.  Energy Possibilities: Rethinking Alternatives and the Choice-Making Process p. 18-20

 

  1. Our Disad Turns their advantage – develping a legitimate environmental ethic means avoiding revolutionary shocks that cause totalitarianism.  Thei advantage author concedes there is no possible advantage to the plan’s shock therapy.

 

Nicholas Low And Brendan Gleason ’98 Justice, Society and Nature: An exploration in political ecology p. 20

 

E. The plan I s counterporoductive for developing a precautionary ethic.  Incremental application of the precautionary principle is superior to the plan’s immediate 90% reduction in fossil fuel consumption.

 

Timothy O’Riordan and James Cameron ’94  Interpreting the Precautionary Principle p. 293

 

  1. Puishing the precautionary principle too fast destros democratic input—this turns the case solvency

 

Oriordand and Cameron p. 27-28

 

Our Net-Benefit – the counterplan avoids our disad and prevents backlash against a precaustionary environmental framework.

 

                Economice hardship and starvation produced by the plan would cause a massive backlash against environmentalism.  The transition to alternative energies that break the link between economic hardship and environmental regulation is crucial to the legitimcacy of environmental ethics

 

Low and Gleason p. 212

 

Evaluate Our Disad. DA turns

 

  1. Enviromental ethics must consider environmental consequences, economics, and social economic consequences.  This is the best way to balance short term and long term consequences.

 

Alyson C. Flournoy ‘3  Enviorns Envtl. L. & Pol’y J. 1 L/N “Decions or policies are deemed sustainable only if they incorporate consideration of three co-equal factors: ecology, economics and social equity

 

  1. Environmental ethics demand we evaluate the economic consequences of the plan.  Economic questions are crucial for perceived legitimacy

 

Barton Thompson Environs Envtl. L. & Pol’y J. 175 L/N “Those who believe in a strong code of environmental ethic…see the prevalence of economic analysis in current environmental policy debates as an error.”

 

  1. Our ethical framework creates ethical stepping-stones instead of imposing a new revolutionary environmental ethics

 

Alyson Flournoy 1 L/N.  “Philosophers must help us to create a discourse that describes ways of valuing the environment that build on people’s current values…”

 

  1. Balancing environmental consequences, future generations, non-human interests, and socio-economic consequences prevents dogmatic ethics.  The plan’s failure to balance these concerns puts all of our eggs in one disastrous ethical basket.

 

Christopher Barrett ’99. Environmental Ethics Vol. 21 Spring “We argue the importance of pluralistic stewardship, invoking the economic concept of path dependene, which emphasizes that there exist multiple paths society can follow in environmental ethics and polic…”

 

  1. Environmental Ethics cannot be wepearated from political context, evaluating the socio-economic effects of environmental positions is crucial for their legitimacy.

 

John Barry ’99 Rethinking Green Politics: Nature, Firtue and Progress p. 41

Lets them spike out of DA and CP

            Counterplan – do feebates to the transportation sector

The United States Federal Government should establish an energy policy requiring a substantial reduction of non-governmental non-transportation sector fossil fuel consumption by establishing a tradable permits regime requiring a decrease in non-transportation sector consumption of fossil fuels so that non transportation sector emissions decrease 7% from 1990 levels in the United States by 2012 and establish an auction system for permit distribution.

 

The United States Federal Government should institute a feebate system for non-governmental transportation sector fossil fuel consumption. This system should be structured to achieve a 7% reduction from 1990 levels in transportation sector emissions by 2012.

1nc:

 

ASPEC

 

T- Energy Policy Means RE Development

 

Management K

 

Environmental management is a fantasy – the drive to control the environment rest s on the assumption that the achievement of control is in fact desirable. This fantasy has at its root western metaphysics and rationality. The attempt to remedy environmental harms through the requirement of a policing love is what renders environmental catastrophe inevitable.

McWhorter, 1992 (Heidegger and the Earth, p. vii-viii)

 

The fantasy of management is what sustains our belief that we can avert annihilation. This thinking reveals the world exclusively through calculative thought, at the expense of other ways of knowing rendering the environment fit for our destruction. This humanistic drive for object manipulation is the root of the “environmental crises.”

McWhorter, 1992 (Heidegger and the Earth, p. vii-viii)

 

Constantly thinking apocalypse preconditions us to accept that any level of violence is necessary to avert it. The consequence of a lust for total control is a total war against alterity.

Coviello, 2000 Queer Frontiers p. 40-41

 

Questions of ontology must be asked and answered first since the inform all relevant knowledge and conceptions of the “problem.”

Dillon, 1999, Moral Spaces, p. 97-98

 

Our alternative is to resist the calculative thought of the 1ac’s – the Affirmative’s conception of the world is shaped by technologicali ordering and must be interrogated or there is no hope of solvency

Korous, Become What You Are 1997 p. 22-25

Kritik

 

Security is a construct – claims of war and conflict create a false dichotomy between the good us and the evil them ignoring our role in provoking the aggression.

Mack, 1990, The Psychodynamics of International Relations, pages 58-59, “attempts to explore” AND “with our adversaries”

 

These fantasies of control contain the seeds of their opposite because elements that don’t fit are violently eliminated.

Stavrakakis, 1999, Lacan and the Political, pages 99-100, “our age” AND “its horrific side”

 

The alternative is to adopt the role of the analyst – instead of asking what the Negative should do instead you should limit your decision to what the Affirmative should do differently. Voting Negative is not a mattere of saying yes or no to the plan, but a matter of analyzing the psychological investment that the Affirmative has in the politics of the status quo, and their attendant structures of exclusion and depoliticization. Only by analyzing these structures do we clear the way for authentic political acts that can transform the entire ideological system.

Zizek, Contigency, Hegemony, Universality, pages 124-127, “now I can” AND “fantasy towards the Real”

Environmental Reps Bad

 

1NC Kritik:

Disaster is back- ecological horror stories are offered as the justification for environmental protection. Thinking apocalypse, however, is an ineffective means of achieving environmental policy. The failure of Caldicott and Ehrlich are proof that society does not respond to chicken little’s claims that the sky is falling.

Holly Doremus Professor of Law, University of California at Davis Washington & Lee Law Review  Winter, 2000

George Perkins Marsh suggested in his 1864 book that unbridled human exploitation of nature could threaten human survival. n45 After lying dormant for nearly a

 

The affirmatives representations are analogous to a modern disaster film. An emphasis on the aesthetics of destruction privileges spectacle over content, voiding the academic value of their claims. The metaphor of the disaster film is less about how the environment is and more about who we are.

Stephen Keane, Disaster Movies 2001 p.    13-15

Scenes of metropolitan destruction represented a very suitable extreme in the 195os, a metaphorical extreme that was entirely in keeping with the   hyperbolic war of words, technological

 

Our desires for more prolonged and accurate depictions of disaster are destructive. The narrative of disaster slowly eats away at all other elements of the plot. The way pornography now comes with no story, no wrongly delivered pizza, no pool boy knocking on the door of a home that has no pool, just straight to sex, is the same way disaster depiction has monopolized 1AC construction. Instead of a few well constructed advantages, affs attempt to cram in as many poorly constructed impact scenarios as possible. The metaphorical money shot of disaster has turned simulation into spectacle.

Stephen Keane, Disaster Movies 2001 p   114-118

In an industry that spends almost as much time and money in promoting its seasonal blockbusters as it does in getting them made, the scope moves   far beyond the films themselves

 

This rhetoric is politically bankrupt. It instills in us the belief that we need not worry about the environment until the very second before its destruction. The stylized depiction of the gravity of the problem paralyzes local decision making that has a better chance of dealing with environmental problems

Holly Doremus Professor of Law, University of California at Davis Washington & Lee Law Review  Winter, 2000

In recent years, this discourse frequently has taken the form of the ecological horror story. That too is no mystery. The ecological horror story is unquestionably an

 

Our Framework: The affirmatives representations should be evaluated prior to consideration of policy desirability.

 

Our Alternative: Say no to the representations of disaster and apocalypse in the 1AC

 

In The end, Disaster films are not really about death and extinction at all, they are about redemption. The point of the film is that when the chips are down, no matter how grim the situation seems, American heroes will save the day. In a dramatic inversion of common debate speak, its not extinction that is inevitable, but survival.  The longer the odds, the greater the success at overcoming them. Desire for greater stories about salvation go hand in hand with greater depictions of disaster.  Perhaps the reason we haven’t acted on problems like global warming is because they just don’t seem dire enough to warrant a response. The impact of numbing from environmental disaster cinema is massive

Stephen Keane, Disaster Movies 2001 p.   120-121

It looks likely that after such a concentrated and crossbreed flurry of activity, 'disaster movies' will now sit back and let 'disaster' take over   again. On

 

Disaster cinema devolves literally into an ideological pissing contest. Attempts to reach the largest magnitude of impact ignore remote possibilities and blatantly illogical internal links. We should recognize that we’ve seen it all before and resist the allure of spectacle.  Andy Warhols Film Skyscraper is 6 hours in length and consists exclusively of a single shot from a stationary camera of a building. After 4 hours or so the sun goes down and the lights in the building all turn on simultaneously. At this point the viewer has become so bored that the simple act of lights turning on appears magical and is instantly mesmerized. The point is that each small step away from Size matters can work to reverse the process of numbing constant bombardment with disaster results in. A negative ballot symbolizes that even though in some instances size may matter, its more important what you do with it.

Stephen Keane, Disaster Movies 2001 p   100-103

Although Godzilla added a monster to the developing pattern of science fiction disaster movies, by the time the film came out it found itself   located

WARMING NOW 1NC + 2NC

 

 

1 Satellite and balloon data proves models fail warming is hardly

occurring and its slow plus surface temps don’t adequately describe the

climate

that the climate we see today is not unusual at all”

Emory AP Neg vs Iowa - Georgia State Octofinals

 

 

Negative Cites

 

 

Ideology is sustained through establishing a safe critical distance.

Attempts to protest the symbolic order are in actuality what sustain it. It’s

the enjoyment gained in the process, not a desire to tear down the symbolic

that motivate these protests. They fail b/c they were never intended to be

effective. You don’t play first person shooters like halo to actually kill

anyone, seince all characters constantly respawn an actual murder is

impossible, you play pleasure the process entails. The statement “I do not

believe in this, deep down I am resisting” is what makes ideology function

Carlson ’99 (david gray, Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law Columbia law

Review November

Schlag presents a dark….to be abolished

 

 

Ideology is sustainted b/c we gain political enjoyment from protesting it.

Attempts to break down the system from the private reclusion of a debate

tournament function as the ultimate act of conformity, sinc e nothing is at

state, this resistance remains apolitical and empy. Resistance makes

ideology fun. We make an infinite number of change to the law without ever

distrurbing te fundamentl fanstasty that makes it function.

Zizek ’95 (university of Ljubljana cardozo law review)

Emphasis should be laid on the inherent….but we can never be rid of it

 

 

If distance sustains ideology, what is there left for us to do? We must

eliminate the distance b/w ideology and ourselves. Overidentification

renders visible the obsecene dominant nature of ideology that had previously

remained hidden

“How are we to combat effectively this id-evil….shift from desire to drive”

 

 

engaging in activism through debate is the classic case of liberal leftist

irresponsibiltity- they can have all the fun of a protest without taking on

any of the responsibility of a decision. Though they want to win the debate,

they know that since a ballot does not mean their project is enacted, they

will never have to answer those damaged by their narcissistic demands. A

true revolutionary is one who not only acknowledges these consequences but

embraces them. By refusing to accept the mantle of responsibility the

affirmative is comforted by the no-risk venture of their “politics”, and

ideology is sustained.

Zizek ’99 (Ticklish Subject p. 234-238

This criticism should not be misread as relying on the….it is there all the

time as the condition that actually sustains every Order of being

            Counterplan – Unfunded Mandates

THE UNITED STATES FEDERAL GOVERNMENT WILL THREATEN TO DO THE PLAN IF THE RELEVENT INDUSTRIES DO NOT VOLUNTARILY CREATE STANDARDS THAT ENSURE A TRADEABLE PERMITS REGIME REQUIRING A 7% REDUCTION OF EMISSIONS FROM THE CONSUMPTION OF FOSSIL FUELS FROM 1990 LEVELS.  COMPLIANCE WILL BE DETERMINED BY AN ACCREDITED 3RD PARTY AUDITOR.  THE UNITED STATES FEDERAL GOVERNMENT WILL OFFER PUBLIC RECOGNITION TO COMPLIANT INDUSTRIES AND ENGAGE IN INFORMATIONAL SUPPORT IF REQUESTED BY INDUSTRY.  THE PASSAGE OF THE PLAN WILL BE CONDITIONED UPON NON-COMPLIANCE.   WE’LL CLARIFY.

Emory CG Neg

            Round # 5 Shirley

            Vs Team: Fullerton KA

            Judge: Neil Blackmon

 

            Off Case Args:

Global Local

China DA

Framework

Ideology

Ideology is sustained through establishing a safe critical distance. Attempts to protest the symbolic order are in actuality what sustain it.  It’s the enjoyment gained in the process, not a desire to tear down the symbolic that motivate these protests.  They fail because they were never intended to be effective.  You don’t play first person shooters like halo to actually kill anyone, since all characters constantly respawn an actual murder is impossible, you play pleasure the process entails.  The statement “I do not believe in this, deep down I am resisting” is what makes ideology function.   David Gray Carlson, Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law Columbia Law Review, 1999, “shows nothing but the unconfronted depth to which the cynic is actually”

 

Engaging in “activism” through debate is the classic case of liberal leftist irresponsibility – They can have all the fun of a protest, without taking on any of the responsibility of a decision.  Though they ant to win the debate, they know that since a ballot does not mean their project is enacted, they will never have to answer those damaged by their narcissistic demands.  A true revolutionary is one who not only acknowledges these consequences but embraces them.  By refusing to accept the mantle of responsibility the affirmative is comforted by the no-risk venture of their “politics”, and ideology is sustained.  Zizek 199 Ticklish Subject p. 234-8

 

 

 

 

 

 

Emory CG Neg.

            Judged by: Blank

  3. Oil is inexhaustible- constantly renews
  4. Supply ahead of demand

Emory CG Neg

            Round 2  Shirley

            Vs Team: Mary Washington GR

            Judge: Atchison

 

            Case Args:

Species Loss Frontline:

  1. Claims of ecosystem destruction are false – ecosystems empirically recover – Boucher, Center for environmental and Estuarine Studies, 1996, Douglas, Science and Society, Fall, “the political danger of catastrophism…we value by those we do not like”
  2. Even if they’re right, the timeframe is enormous – Jane Kay, Environmental Writer, June 26, 2001, San Francisco Chronicle, pg l/n “The collapse of ecosystems often occur over a long period…fewer seals and lions to eat”
  3. Alternate causalities – out-competition from invasive species destroys biodiversity – Africa news, 11/17/1998, pg l/n “the worldwatch institute says bioinvasion…may undergo a population explosion”
  4. Cryo-preservation solves species loss – Michale Cannell, October 10, 1999, Washington Post, pg l/n “with his beard and khaki safari shirt…injecting genetic booster shots into isolated groups”
  5. All of their threshold arguments are false – we’re well passed what would be the “threshold” – World News Connection, 9/15/99 “The united nations warned Wednesday…can never be replaced it warns”
  6. No impact and turn – biodiversity is no key to ecosystem survival and high biodiversity slows recovery from environmental damage – Calgary herald – 8/30/1997 pp l/n “ecologists have long maintained…against ecological collapse”

No Warming

  1. satellite and balloon data proves climate models fail – warming is hardly occuring and it’s at a slow rate – plus, surface temp. data doesn’t accurately describe the climate – john Christy (professor of atmospheric science and director of the earth system science center at the university of Alabama and alabama’s state climatologist – c02 science magazine, 5/28/03 “will increase in c02 affect the climate…not unusual at all”
  2. negative feedbacks outweigh warming – all the idsos (Sherwood, keith, and craig, c02 science magazine, vol 7, number 11, 3/17/04, “since this point is so important…to be of essentially no significance”
  3. multiple studies prove that natural oscillations and solar variation and not c02 determine global climate change – all the idsos, 8/25/04 (c02 science magazine vol 7, number 8) “the signal accomplishment of the scientists’ study…return to climatic conditions akin to those of the medieval warm period”
  4. there is no consensus – csm, 3/19/01 “I disagree with one point…the so-called consensus is largely manufactured”
  5. more than 18,000 scientists agree that global warming isn’t occuring – john f. mcmanus, the new American, 9/8/03 “the sky is falling! Or is it? – “a petition signed by more than 18,000 scientists…and disruption of the earth’s climate”
  6. Warming will occur at night and have no negative impacts – Robert c balling, jr. director of climatology at Arizona state, the true state of the planet, ed. By Ronald bailey, 1995, pg. 100-1 “although we rarely hear about greenhouse…potential benefits must be examined”
  7. warming will only occur in the winter which means it can’t get too hot – avery, director of the center for global food issues at the Hudson institute, 02 p 114-115 “the medieval experience with global warming…relatively little added stress on crop plants or trees – and on people”
  8. cultivation of methane hydrates ready to proceed in Alaska – inside energy/with federal lands, 11/18/02, p 12 “Johnson and other board members…become more profitable”

C02 Ag/Additional

  1. C02 is the lifeblood of plants – solves worldwide starvation – all the idsos, c02 science magazine, vol 6, number 37, 9/10/03 “in a broad review of the scientific literature…and will be, sharing equally”
  2. renewables cause intense land wars and food price increases – bioscience 1994 (vol. 44, no 8, sept., david Pimentel, http://dieoff.org/page84.htm) “renewable energy technologies…future land conflicts could be intense

        b. 1.1 billion will starve – tampa tribune 1996 “us food prices may rise more than 4 percent…who live on a dollar a day or less”

3. wind power hurts the environment and will collapse without reinvigoration – Bradley, 1997 (prev cited on caselist)

Biomass

  1. biomass pollutes the air and erodes soil – Bradley 1997, Robert, aug 27, renewable energy: not cheap, no green, cato policy analysis, no 280, www.cato.org “biomass is not environmentally benign from the energy…”

 

 

            Off Case Args:

  1. Consult Japan
  1. Text: The United States Federal Government will enter into binding consultation with the government of Japan on whether or not to do the plan… and will implement the outcome of the consulatation. We’ll clarify.
  2. Obs. I – Competition – The affirmative is immediate, guaranteed plan action. You can’t enact the plan unconditionally and condition it on japan’s acceptance. First, fiat, assumes the plan happens no matter what; otherwise the 1ac could spike out of all negative offense by saying the plan is delayed or unenforced
  3. Second, there’s no solvency for non-enforced plan action; congress would roll back the plan absent enforcement.
  4. Net Benefit:

        First, the alliance will inevitably collapse in a crisis, kicking the U.S. out – Mike Mochizuki (Senior fellow at brookings) 19997, brookings review, march 22; “the time has come to strike a new strategic bargain”

        And, US withdrawal causes Japan to go nuclear, resulting in arms races, proliferation, and world war – Khalilzad, 1995

  1. Solvency – Genuine and binding consultation prior to the implementation restructures and strengthens the alliance – they’ll say yes – Mochizuki 1997 “as the alliance becomes more reciprocal”

 

  1. China
  1. Chinese economic growth is slowing – limited supplies of oil are forcing the gov’t to scale back its rapid rate of growth to reduce domestic demand – USA Today 9/2/04 “Li may be the CEO of an established electronics manufacturer…trim 2% from growth in power demand”
  2. Export fill-in- any reduction in uS oil use will be offset by China to rapidly expand its economy – Stanley, LA TIMES, 11/13/04 “signs of an accelerating global economy…couldn’t find a home anywhere else”
  3. Continued massive growth rates in china causes US/China war – Mearsheimer – prof at university of Chicago – 9/20/04 (federal news service, john) “the question at hand is simple…join with the united states to contain china’s power”
  4. Causes global nuclear holocaust – Chicago Tribune, 2/16/96 “a PLA analysis…global nuclear holocaust”

 

 

  1. Blair DA

IN CASELIST

 

  1. Petrodollars Good
  1. OPEC is building support for a switch to the euro – saltmarsh, 2003 (matthew, the main wire, 11/10, lexis) “iran, the world’s fifth largest oil exporter…are revising their strategic relationship with the united states”
  2. The most qualified analysis says that if the US decreases its oil imports, OPEC will switch oil trading to the Euro – Looney, prof of economics @ the naval postrgraduate school, march 22, 2004, Robert, middle east policy, no 1, vol. 11, page 26, issn: 1061-1924, lexis, “while clark’s and henderson’s scenarios are plausible…more oil and petroleum products than the united states”
  3. This will collapse the US economy – Mardiros, former mining geologist, 2003 (charles, san Antonio express-news, 10/12, lexis) “oil is by far the most important commodity in international trade…reminiscent of the Weimar republic of the 1920s”
  4. Mead 92

 

            Block Strategy:

Japan Extensions

  1. Japanese rearm would be rapid and cause India/Pakistan arms races – business week 2003 “if japan could get beyond the hurdles…into an ever more perilous future”
  2. now is key – arms racing will ruin Indian dtente and cause nuclear war – dallas morning news, 5/15/04 “yet Indians aren’t disadvantaged…the united states in their sights”
  3. this causes extinction – wash times 2001, july 8
  4. A strong alliance deters china from invading Taiwan and ensures regional stability – yukio okamoto, spring 2002, wash quartlery, japan and the united states, “regardless of whether china’s development takes the bright path”
  5. us-japan alliance prevents china-taiwan conflicts – chin chu-kwang, sen fellow at the atlantic council, 1998, world affairs, vol 160, number 3, winter, p 161 “the primary purpose of the us-japan security alliance…”
  6. Chinese military spending and economic growth guarantees conflict without a stronger alliance – okazaki, 2002, the yomiuri shimbun, daily yomiuri, mach 4, lexis “there can be no doubt that china’s military spending…”
  7. china wants a strong alliance bc it keeps Japanese militarism in check, they don’t see it as hostile – Donald zagoria, and Benjamin rivlin, may 1997, www.ciaonet.org/conf/bun03/bun03d.html “officially, the chinese scholar said, the Chinese government…”
  8. a strong alliance deters chinese aggression and ensures Taiwanese stability – self, senior associate at the henry l stemson center, 2001, csis.com “the allies have available to them a wide range of tools”

 

AT: No Reform

  1. This doesn’t answer our alliance impacts – even if japan doesn’t go nuclear, lack of consult will still end the alliance
  2. their evd doesn’t assume a breakdown in the alliance – the Japanese political situation would be radically different without the protection of the us nuclear umbrella
  3. japan has the technology and desire – they’ll rearm without the alliance – Jeffrey moag and gogichaisvili, 1999, august 9, “japan has the technical and economic means”
  4. perception of rearm causes an arms race – Mochizuki, 1997

 

Economy Net Benefit

  1. Alliance collapse would destroy the global economy – kazuya 2001, japan quarterly, april-june, “the security treaty also provides a basis…important trading partner”
  2. Impact is the Mead evd – Us-Japan economies are interdependent and can bring down the world economy – ito 2002 – consul general makoto, speech @ wayne state university, school of business “as I’ve mentioned, japan and the us have solid security ties”

 

Say Yes: Environment

  2. consultation matters more than policy specifics – japan willl comply – doug struck, wash. Post foreign service, 2-8-2001, wash post, lexis “furthermore, japan is eager to court American approval”

  2. timeframe perm – they delay consult until after the impelementation of the plan – moving target – get out of our offense
  3. no solvency – prior consult is key, our 1nc evd. Says it’s the only way to make good on promises in the security pact – junior partner – the japan times, 1999, july 7 “the dpj regards the japan-us security treaty…more independent position”
  4. prior and genuine consultation key to saving the alliance – bersten et al, 2001, new japan – united state economic relationship, p 262-3 “programmatically, making the alliance work…in a modern and normal direction”

Boundary affirming project

            Counterplan – Courts

The United States Supreme Court should recognize and enforce common law environmental property rights, and recognize that consumption of fossil fuels creates tort liability for any property harmed by that consumption. The Court should use the IPCC’s studies about global warming as a benchmark to judge the risk of fossil fuel consumption in clearing harm to environmental property rights. The Court should strike down any conflicting regulations that would prevent the enforcement of this ruling.

 

Net benefits: Coercion, Trade DA (Not inflation/business confidence), Solves the case better (perm would preempt tort liability), potentially politics

 

Tort law would solve environmental harm better

Taylor, 3/12/97, www.cato.org/speeches/sp-jt031297.html

“An alternative environmental”…”from illegal environmental aggression”

 

Government regulation = more environmental damage

Madden 1998 http://home.earthlink.net/~rdmadden/webdocs/Government_vs_the_Environm.html

“Yes, as in many other areas”…”property rights would end”

 

Regulations cause industry backlashes

Steinzor 1998, Harvard Environmental Law Review

“In some instances, the critics”…”undertaking minimal enforcement”

 

Torts solve fossil fuels

Grossman, Columbia Journal of Environmental Law, 2003

“Coastal states, islands, the”…”threaten property”

 

Causality for warming cases easy to prove

Grossman again, “The entire global community”…”to global warming”

 

Torts make alternative energy cost competitive

Grossman again, “Unlike the consumer public”…”minimize these costs”

 

Force manufacturers to switch to alternative energy

Grossman again, “As a general rule”…”weight of these benefits”

“The erection of a massive federal”…”permit compliance at trial”

            AT “Competitiveness”

Emissions trading will inevitably collapse because of allocation uncertainties

and enforcement

David G. Victor, Robert W. Johnson, Jr., Senior Fellow in Science and

Technology at the Council on Foreign Relations, Fall 1999 [10 Duke Env L &

Pol'y F 147]

~This would be a persuasive approach if it were realistic to implement. But

trading is hobbled by other problems that probably ~[*175]~ make it infeasible.

 

 

Companies will buy permits instead of innovating.

David M. Driesen, Associate Professor at Syracuse University College of Law,

Fall 1998 [26 B.C. Envtl. Aff. L. Rev. 1, “Free Lunch or Cheap Fix?: The

Emissions Trading Idea and the Climate Change Convention”]

Broadening the analysis to include all of the pollution sources eligible to

trade casts grave doubts on the theory that emissions trading encourages more

innovation

 

 

The permit scheme will be too tight to chill innovation.

Jennifer Yelin-Kefer, Stanford Environmental Law Journal, January 2001 [20

Stan. Envtl. L.J. 221]

David Driesen further contends that emissions trading chills innovation by

encouraging countries to forego domestic reductions

 

 

Emissions trading is unenforceable and will decrease innovation

David M. Driesen, Associate Professor at Syracuse University College of Law,

Fall 1998 [26 B.C. Envtl. Aff. L. Rev. 1, “Free Lunch or Cheap Fix?: The

Emissions Trading Idea and the Climate Change Convention”]

 

 

Emissions trading in the climate change context may constitute a cheap fix,

because it delays innovation

 

 

Failure to ratify boosts competitiveness relative to the EU

Hans H.J. Labohm, “Blair's Blunder,” Netherlands Institute of International

Relations 'Clingendael,' February 9, 2002,

http://www.clingendael.nl/cli/publ/media/periodicals/2002/labohm_2002_02_09.htm

The Third World has been excluded from the obligations of Kyoto, while the US

has decided to opt out with Australia in its wake, while Japan and Canada are

still having qualms. If the European Union will be the only party that will

implement Kyoto

 

 

Competitiveness isn

 

 

Paul Krugman, Professor of Economics at the Massachusetts Institute of

Technology, March/April 1994 [Foreign Affairs, “Competitiveness: A Dangerous

Obsession”]

Unfortunately, his diagnosis was deeply misleading as a guide to what ails

Europe, and similar diagnoses in the United States are equally misleading. The

idea that a country's economic fortunes are largely determined by its success

on world markets is a hypothesis

 

 

Focusing on competitiveness undermines the economy and causes trade wars.

~

Paul Krugman, Professor of Economics at the Massachusetts Institute of

Technology, March/April 1994 [Foreign Affairs, “Competitiveness: A Dangerous

Obsession”]

THINKING AND SPEAKING in terms of competitiveness poses three real dangers.

First, it could result in the wasteful spending of government money supposedly

to enhance U.S. competitiveness. Second, it could lead to protectionism and

trade wars. Finally

 

 

RAPID RENEWABLE GROWTH WILL CAUSE A DOT-COM STYLE BURST AND TANK THE ECONOMY

Wood 2003 <Elisa, US Energy issue writer, Renewable Energy World, “How to

Sustain the Green Energy

In some respects, growth itself could become a problem for renewables. Should

the industry expand too quickly, it will, according to Taub, face major

production, labour, equipment and transportation challenges.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

EMORY GP (Neg) v. DARTMOUTH CS @ Dart RR

 

1NC K

The affirmative is trapped within the logic of globalization.  Their call to the state is a ‘think globally, act locally’ mentality that obliterates our ability to think and act locally.  This is doomed to failure and is a cause of prior environmental destruction.  Esteva and Prakash 1997 The Post-Development Reader p.277-278 “Think globally, act locally… the watchdogs in the global environmental movement”

 

Ecological extinction is inevitable because of social hierarchies enforced by the state.  The affirmative’s piecemeal reforms hasten extinction by deflecting efforts away from challenging the social institutions that are the root cause of their harms  Bookchin 91 Defendiong the Earth: Debate Between Murray Bookchin and Dave Foreman p.75-77

 

Global approaches to environmental protection mask our personal roles in consumption and reinforce environmental destruction – Bobertz 95 73 Texas LR 711 “To date, explanations for the intellectual bedlam of environmental…  creating the appearance of reforming”

 

Their appeal to the state as a source of salvation is the root  cause of war and genocide Beres 94 Arizona Journal of International and Comparative Law Spring “The state requires its members to be… corpses of others”

 

Shocks 1NC

No supply shocks – diversity, efficiency and trading solve Gorak 99 www.heartland.org/Article/cfm?artId=13011 “Oil shortages like those experienced… Bradley writes”

 

Prices increases are always short term – no impact LeVine 2004 (8/29) St. Louis Post-Dispatch “The best the producers can hope… industrialized world does”

 

Peaks 1NC

Tech solves Newsweek 9/20/4 “For years most such firms ignored… run out any time soon”

 

Reserves grow – 46 years of oil left Gorak 99 (same as above) “Fossil-fuel availability has been increasing… usage, respectively”

 

TORTS 1NC

Class action reform will despite democratic criticism BestWire 1/11/5 “Not long after congressional Republicans… doomed its passage”

 

PC key to pass class action before Congress becomes swamped in judicial nominations Financial Times 11/15/4 “Bush won a close election and his party gained four seats… he turned out to be right”

 

Energy policies destroy capital – The Hill 2004 “pro-energy-production Republicans solidified… aren’t easily passed”

 

Impact – Reform prevents destruction of pharmaceutical industry – New York Sun 12/20/4 “The American pharmaceutical industry, for all its faults… their case to the public”

 

Pharmaceutical countries key to combating bioweapons Bailey 01 www.opensecrets.org/alters/v6/altertv6_33.asp “With fears of bioterrorism on the rise… development of new cures”

 

Bioweapons attack results in global extinction which outweighs all else OCHS 2 www.freefromterror.net/other_articles/abolish.html “Of all the weapons of mass destruction… the game is over.”

 

1NC IRAN DA

EU successfully resolving the Iranian nuclear threat Newsday 11/17/4 “may have to take Iran off the… stringent UN economic sanctions hanging like Damocles’”

 

Reducing GHG emissions key to US-EU relations Gelbspan 2004 Boiling Point p.94-95   “Nine days after his announcement… USA and the EU”

 

Weak relations with Europe are key to the success of European efforts at stemming Iranian proliferation Meland 2004 www.gcsp.ch/e/about/News/Faculty-articles/Smeland.pdf “All of these proposals are more easily described…charting its own course”

 

Iranian Prolif leads to Israeli preemption – Salema and Rister 9/9/4 http://cns.miis.edu/pubs/week/040812.htm “In Israel, planning and rhetoric appear to have progressed… consequences of any preemptive action”

 

BUDGET 1NC

Plan’s massive spending sends the signal  that Bush’s vow to fiscal responsibility is hollow destroying the pubic support necessary for budget cuts Sarasota Herald-Tribune 2005 (1/2) “Bush and his allies in Congress may finally reacquaint… contributed to our huge deficit”

 

Presidential leadership is the only way to restore international confidence in the economy and prevent the most  dangerous economic decline in decades 12/8/4 “Foreign investors, who have been the biggest buyers… most dangerous decline in decades”

 

T Require a Cap

 

  1. Interpretation

1.        Requirements must mandate a uniform cap on consumption levels Bownes 1981 Carlos Romero-Barcelo, Etc., Et Al., plaintiffs-appellants, v. Harold Brown No. 79-1626 1/26 “The key issue, therefore, is the definition of… This type of control relies on relatively precise standards capable of uniform application”

2.        Total means net reduction – Encarta World English Dictionary 2004 http://encarta.msn.com/encnet/features/ditionary/DictionaryResults.aspx?refid=1861721047 “Overall: with all elements added or considered together”

  1. Violation – the affirmative might claim to reduce consumption, but they don’t create a legal cap on total consumption levels
  2. This is a voting issue –

1.        Its key to negative ground – our consumption good links depend on actual net reduction in overall consumption – given that consumption is increasing, affirmatives that don’t cap it can claim that existing increases overwhelm their plan

2.        Its key to limits – our interpretation excludes cases that eliminate certain types of technology but allow consumers to expand their consumption in other ways – their aff justifies regulating SUVs, or banning gas-powered lawnmowers that don’t address overall levels of consumption

3.        Extra T – they say what they replace consumption with – It’s a voting issue, otherwise it becomes a no risk option for the affirmative to put extra topical planks in their plan – it also underlimits

 

T Fossil Fuels

 

  1. Definitions –

 

Fossil Fuels is a count noun because of “s”

Using English 2002 www.usingenglish.com/glossary/count-noun.html “A Count Noun is a noun that has both a singular and a plural form.  Plurals of Count Nouns are normally made by the addition of ‘-s’”

 

Lack of an article preceding fossil fuels means the resolution refers to the whole class – Gillett 99 www.uefap.co.uk/accuracy/accfram.htm

“The indefinite article is used with singular countable nouns… rather than an individual”

 

Fossil Fuels is a collective term

Sharp 99 http://rockhoundingar.com/geology/energy.html “Coal, oil and gas are collectively called fossil fuels… (living) matter”

 

  1. Violation – The affirmative only limits consumption of one fossil fuel

 

  1. Reasons to prefer –

 

    1. The grammatical distinction between count and non-count nouns is important

Guide to Grammar 2004 http://webster.commnet.edu/grammar/noun_exercize.htm “It is this fourth column of nouns that confounds many writers… count or non-count form”        

 

    1. Limits – there are 6 core fossil fuels Demets 2002 www.geology.wisc.edu “Fossil fuels are derived from the remains of dead organisms… natural gas”

 

There are 10 derivatives of natural gas an oil Basurto 28 U. Miami Inter-Am. L. Rev. 479 1996 “In response to this crisis… or any such combination”

 

The aff makes the resolution bidirectional because there can be a shift to another fuel after the plan Santa 2003 Public Utilities Fortnightly “While fuel-neutral on their face… lead time technologies for new generation”

 

D. Voting issue – fairness, education, jurisdiction

 

CP text – The 50 states and all relevant sub-national actors should, through an interstate compact, establish a system of oil conservation vouchers for ground transportation vehicles, phased in to achieve a 25 percent reduction in non-governmental consumption within 15 years.  The 50 states and all relevant sub-national actors should allocate vouchers so as to minimize negative economic impact.  They should devise implementation systems.  They should fund the mass commercialization of thermal depolymerization as a ay to eliminate oil dependence, providing incentive, subsidies and loans for the creation of up to 1000 thermal depolymerization plants.  To fund the counterplan, they should deploy electronic lotto machines.   If more funds are needed, they should make .5% across the board cuts.  All actors will defer to the counterplan.  We’ll clarify.

Impact: Global Nuclear War  - Mead 92

(New Perspectives Quarterly, Summer)

What if the global economy stagnates or even shrinks?  In that case we will

face a new period of conflict: South against North, rich against poor, Russia,

 

 

 

The affirmative’s demand that we act as managers of the environment and

therefore avert ecological catastrophe locks us into a fantasy of control.

This ignores that control is never possible and forgets that the thoughtless

deployment of technology is what brought us to the brink of ecological

catastrophe in the first place

 

 

McWhorter, Professor of Philosophy at Northeast Missouri State, 92  (LaDelle,

Heidegger and the Earth, ed: McWhorter, p. vii-viii)

 

 

PARADOX IS THE TITILLATING OTHER OF ALL LOGICS rooted in the law of

non-contradiction. It is Other because it is unassimilable; it is titillating

because it is transgressive. Most of us enjoy

 

 

Our critique is not about using technology; rather, it’s a critique of the idea

that we can survive environmental destruction through proper management.  The

affirmative claim to be a “hands-off” approach still buys into the myth of

control—that by setting aside one part of an ecosystem, we can survive despite

our domination of another. The race to find solutions excludes deeper

reflection of what Heidegger calls the ‘mystery of Being’ that makes all life

meaningful.

 

 

McWhorter, Professor of Philosophy at Northeast Missouri State, 92  (LaDelle,

Heidegger and the Earth, ed: McWhorter, p. vii-viii)

 

 

Today, on all sides of ecological debate we hear, with greater and greater

frequency, the word management. On the one hand, business people want to manage

natural resources so as to keep up profits. On the other hand, conservationists

want to manage

 

 

Aside from their inevitable failure, these fantasies of control have a dark

underside.  Fantasies contain the seeds of their opposite because elements that

don’t fit are violently eliminated.  For example, the fantasy of National

Socialism was not borne out and so the Nazis had to find a scapegoat and the

result was a horrific genocide 

 

 

Stavrakakis, teaching fellow at the Department of Government at the University

of Essex, 1999  (Yannis, Lacan and the Political, p. 99-100)

 

 

Our age is clearly an age of social fragmentation, political disenchantment and

open cynicism characterised by the decline of the political mutations of modern

universalism - a universalism that, by replacing God with

 

 

The most stubborn part of the fantasy, the notion of humans as agents who can

finally set things right if only we hear the correct call to action, is a

tempting appeal to our favorite notions of ourselves.  We must deny this urge

to manage and open ourselves up to new ways of thinking that can shatter the

Western selfhood that is driving the earth, and ourselves, to extinction.

 

 

McWhorter, Professor of Philosophy at Northeast Missouri State, 92  (LaDelle,

Heidegger and the Earth, ed: McWhorter, p. vii-viii)

 

 

Guilt is a concept whose heritage and meaning occur within the ethical

tradition of the Western world. But the history of ethical theory in the West

(and it could be argued that ethical theory only occurs in the West) is one

with the history of technological thought.  The revelation of things as

to-be-managed and the imperative to be in control work themselves out in the

history of ethics just as surely as they work themselves out in the history of

the natural, and human sciences. It is probably quite true that in many

different cultures, times, and places human beings have asked the question: How

shall I best live my life? But in the West, and in relatively modern times, we

have reformulated that question so as to ask: How shall I conduct myself? How

shall I behave? How

 

 

The fantasy that ecological solutions are within our grasp reduces all life to

meaningless standing reserve and obliterates other ways of knowing the earth

 

 

McWhorter, Professor of Philosophy at Northeast Missouri State, 92  (LaDelle,

Heidegger and the Earth, ed: McWhorter, p. vii-viii)

 

 

In order to approach the world in a manner exclusively technological,

calculative, mathematical, scientific

 

 

Hence, our alternative: reject the affirmative’s call to action.

How is it possible to do nothing when the urge to do good is deeply engrained

in our culture and, hence, the debate community?  Because deliberately

affirming the choice not act represents a break with the will to power that

created our present situation in the first place.

 

 

McWhorter, Professor of Philosophy at Northeast Missouri State, 92  (LaDelle,

Heidegger and the Earth, ed: McWhorter, p. vii-viii)

 

 

Heidegger frustrates us. At a time when the stakes are so very high and

decisive action is so loudly and urgently called for, Heidegger apparently

calls us to do - nothing. If we get beyond the revulsion and anger that such a

call initially inspires and actually examine the feasibility of response, we

begin to undergo the frustration attendant upon paradox; how is it possible, we

ask, to choose, to will, to do nothing? The call itself places in

 

 

Ideology K:

 

Ideology is sustained through establishing a safe critical distance. Attempts to protest the symbolic order are in actuality what sustain it. It’s the enjoyment gained in the process, not a desire to tear down the symbolic that motivate these protests. They fail because they were never intended to be effective. You don’t play first person shooters like halo to actually kill anyone, since all characters constantly respawn an actual murder is impossible, you play pleasure the process entails. The statement “I do not believe in this, deep down I am resisting” is what makes ideology function

David Gray  Carlson    Professor of Law, Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law Columbia Law Review  November, 1999

Schlag presents a dark vision of what he calls "the bureaucracy," which crushes us and controls us. It operates on "a field of pain and death."  n259 It deprives us of choice, speech,  n260 and custom.  n261 As bureaucracy cannot abide great minds, legal education must suppress greatness through mind numbing repetition.  n262 In fact, legal

 

Ideology is sustained because we gain political enjoyment from protesting it. Attempts to break down the system from the private reclusion of a debate tournament function as the ultimate act of conformity, since nothing is at stake, this resistance remains apolitical and empty.  Resistance makes ideology Fun! We make an infinite number of changes to the law without ever disturbing the fundamental fantasy that makes it function.

   Slavoj  Zizek   Philosopher and Psychoanalyst, Institute for Social Sciences, University of Ljubljana. Cardozo Law Review  1995

Emphasis should be laid on the inherent political dimension of the notion of enjoyment or on the way this kernel of enjoyment functions as a political factor. Let us probe this dimension through one of the enigmas of cultural life in postsocialist Eastern Europe: the fate of Milan Kundera. Throughout the sixties and the seventies, Kundera's

 

If distance sustains ideology, what is there left for us to do? We must eliminate the distance between ideology and ourselves. Overidentification renders visible the obscene dominant nature of ideology that had previously remained hidden.

   Slavoj  Zizek   Philosopher and Psychoanalyst, Institute for Social Sciences, University of Ljubljana. Cardozo Law Review  1995

How are we to combat effectively this id-evil which, on account of its "elementary" nature, remains impervious to any rational or even purely rhetorical argumentation? Racism is always grounded in a particular fantasy, which by definition resists universalization.  n29 The translation of the

 

Engaging in “activism” through debate is the classic case of liberal leftist irresponsibility- They can have all the fun of a protest, without taking on any of the responsibility of a decision. Though they want to win the debate, they know that since a ballot does not mean their project is enacted, they will never have to answer those damaged by their narcissistic demands. A true revolutionary is one who not only acknowledges these consequences but embraces them. By refusing to accept the mantle of responsibility the affirmative is comforted by the no-risk venture of their “politics”, and ideology is sustained.

Zizek, Ticklish Subject p. 234-238 1999

This criticism should not be misread as relying on the traditional Hegelian opposition of abstract and concrete universality: against the assertion of radical negativity as the obverse of universality - of the logic of the Ought that indefinitely postpones its actualization - I am not advocating the necessity of embracing the `concrete' positive order as the

 

cannot assuage guilt- Instead our conscious assumes the role of a loan shark. The more we pay it off by acting due to guilt, the more we end up owing.  The ever increasing weight of our guilt removes critical consideration from our actions making error replication inevitable.

   Slavoj  Zizek   Philosopher and Psychoanalyst, Institute for Social Sciences, University of Ljubljana. Cardozo Law Review  1995

    This directive, however, in no way implies that, in the ethical domain, the tension between the law and the superego cannot be avoided. Lacan's maxim of psychoan

Florida WC Pre Shirley

Negative Arguments:

 

We have read a delay CP

 

FREE-MARKET CP:

TEXT: PURSUANT TO AN OPTIMAL POLICY IMPLEMENTATION, THE UNITED STATES FEDERAL GOVERNMENT SHOULD RECOGNIZE AND ENFORCE ALL COMMON LAW PROPERTY RIGHTS.  THIS WILL SUPERCEDE ALL CONFLICTING LAWS.  
FURTHER SPEECHES WILL CLARIFY INTENT

OBSERVATION 1: THE COUNTERPLAN IS COMPETITIVE BECAUSE IT SOLVES FOR THE HARMS OF THE CASE WITHOUT LINKING TO OUR ARGUMENTS INDICTING CENTRALIZED GOVERNMENT POLICIES.  YOU CAN NOT SIMULTANEOUSLY PROMOTE AND DENIGRATE A FREE-MARKET BASED APPROACH.

OBSERVATION 2: WE SOLVE.  PRIVATE MARKETS ARE THE BEST MEANS OF ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AND EVERY EXAMPLE PROVES THAT
Adler, ?01 (Jonathan, Law professor @ Case Western Law School, ?Free and Green: A New Approach to Environmental Protection,? Harvard Journal of Law and Public Policy, 24 Harv. J.L. & Pub. Pol?y 653)
?If private markets were?? ?solutions to environmental concerns.?

 

COERCION:
A) CENTRAL PLANNING IS DOOMED BECAUSE OF A LACK OF CENTRAL KNOWLEDGE
Cordato, ?97 (Roy, E., Professor of Business Philosophy @ Campbell University, ?Market-Based Environmentalism and the Free Market: They?re not the Same,? Independent Review, Winter, v.1;n.3)
?Both the subjective-cost problem…available to all producers"
B) MUST WORK TO MAXIMIZE LIBERT BY REJECTING CENTRALIZED POLICY
Cordato, ?97 (Roy, E., Professor of Business Philosophy @ Campbell University, ?Market-Based Environmentalism and the Free Market: They?re not the Same,? Independent Review, Winter, v.1;n.3)
?Hayek (1967) argued that…labeled "market-based."
C) GOVERNMENT REGULATION AND VOLUNTARY COOPERATION ARE ZER SUM ? THE PLAN DESTROYS INDIVIDUAL RIGHTS AND JUSTIFIES GOVERNMENTAL INTRUSIONS AT ALL LEVELS OF LIFE ? THIS MUST BE RESISTED
Younkins, 2000 (Dr. Edward, Professor at Wheeling Jesuit University, ?civil Society: The Realm of Freedom,? n.63, http:www.quebecoislibre.org/000610-11.htm)
?Recently (and ironically), government projects…run our lives.?

Aside from politics, we read the following args on the neg:

 

Topicality: Requiring means present action, DOE is the only topical actor, Establish means create (against CAFE)

Disads: Oil disads including Russia, Mexico, and Canada

Counterplans: Free Market, XO, and Competition Statute (this one is only used against Permits, and it says that companies who don't create efficiency measures have to pay a fee to innovative companies)

K's: Confession, Coercion, and a Psychoanalysis argument that says critical affs end up locking in the status quo

Fort

NEG arguments

Reassess space:
We begin with an epigraph from Thomas Dumm in Foucault and
the Politics of Freedom about the necessity to reassess
space in discussions of freedom as space has been assumed in
liberal theory to be neutral and dividable.  Spatially
conditionally, we argue multiple overlaying and intersecting
counter-sites that oppose the 1ac: 1st countersite:
re-assess the 1ac sites as spaces -spaces inform most
basic debate formulations but also politics in general, and
it is necessary to re-assess space if we are to accomplish
the political tasks at hand. 2nd countersite: the aff treats
the topic, specifically "in the us" as a spatial
container to be filled, this homogenizes and
de-differentiates the topic and destroys its difference. 3rd
countersite: politics of space treated differently - and
understanding that politics operate within given spaces of
identity and ignore space: we find William Spanos' concept
of Identityless-Identities to inform a style of politics
that shifts strategically to attend to particular power
asymmetries. 4th countersite: affirm the entire 1ac as a
heterotopia, included is a quote from Foucault's "Of
Other Spaces"
http://foucault.info/documents/heteroTopia/foucault.heteroTopia.en.html
that heterotopias represent contest and invert culture that
it is found as a part of- this dislodges their spatial
assumptions of debate by responding to the givenness of
debate spaces.

Foreground spaces
We begin with an epigraph from Thomas Dumm in Foucault and
the Politics of Freedom about the necessity to reassess
space in discussions of freedom as space has been assumed in
liberal theory to be neutral and dividable.  While Dumm
indicts most of liberal political theory, Edward Soja in a
quote from Thirdspace: Journey to Los Angeles and Other
Real-and-Imagined Places (1996) indicts most current
scholarship as failing due to taking for granted space and
spatiality. Also from Soja, we strategically foreground
space as a needed corrective.  Debate practices as well as
the line by line treat speeches as containers to be filled
with argument, we also counter the IAC's politics of space
and spatiality- space and spatiality matters in this epoch
(as indicated by Foucault's "Of Other Spaces")  We
also examine debates orderings of its words and things
(Foucault The Order of Things)- treat politics of space
differently - and understanding that politics operate
within given spaces of identity and ignore space: we find
William Spanos' concept of Identityless-Identities to
inform a style of politics that shifts strategically to
attend to particular power asymmetries - and if you decide
that both the aff and neg need to be included as the ballot
then include the entirety of the IAC in our negative space
in order to represent, contest, and invert their affirmative
space and politics- advocating in an other space that
represents contests and inverts the political agenda of the
affirmative, Foucault again in "Of Other Spaces"

Spatial Identity Politics
The New York Times april 14, 1996, Debbie Gallant - we
begin with a story of a hate crime in billings, Montana -
a stone was thrown through the window of a jewish family's
home in order to destroy the menorah that had been there -
soon thousands of their christian neighbors had displayed
menorahs in their windows as a sign of solidarity - this
is a powerful political strategy - temporarily effacing
strict identities in order fight a common enemy - a
similar strategy of invisibility was carried out by the NLF
and NVA during the american occupation of vietnam (Spanos,
Heidegger and Criticism, p. 205) - identity politics
fragmented and ultimately collapsed post-vietnam activism
- spatial identity politics is a necessary corrective to
the failings of past political movements - as a part of
this strategy we install the room as political art with a
gps receiver - the dislocation that results from the
technological revolution: every inch of the planet has been
precisely mapped such that we can locate a debate as point
devoid of content: of identity (
www.princeton.edu/~kurgan/urhere/html/frame.htm ) - and
with a radio frequency id chip - by passing the chip
around we necessarily pass around an identity effectively
eschewing traditional notions of identity as fixed,
singular, positively ascertainable (
www.subtletechnologies.com/2003/nisbet.html ) - since most
notions of advocacy, competition, really most of debate rely
on fixed static notions of identity and location, we call
for a ballot that affirms the art installation as a
political strategy

Art Installation
We change the spaces of the debate - hang posters and set
up computers that display information relating to gps and
rfid (see above:
www.princeton.edu/~kurgan/urhere/html/frame.htm,
www.subtletechnologies.com/2003/nisbet.html) - we
encourage all the participants (judges, aff, others) to come
out of their seats, interact with our art installation -
we engage the debate/aff differently - we don't engage
the flow or refutation, instead we engage the debate in our
installation - in the space of the debate -most of our
speech time is devoted to participation and interaction
by/with the others  in the debate - most of that time is
usually spent discussing the gps technology, how it changes
the space/location of the debate and the "advocacy" that
are parts of the round as well as the rfid chip which serves
to challenge advocacy and identity in the round including
the spaces of the ballot - we then install the aff site
and the judge site (in addition to the gps and rfid sites)
to complete our installation

Indigenous Neg

Western ways of knowing the world are incomplete, violent and must be challenged
Deloria, For This Land, p. 101-7,
We cannot approach knowledge or the topic in the same ways, as we have
for centuries in the west, we must re-arrange our topical body of
knowledge- The history of America must be viewed through the lens of
US/Indian relations-Ward Churchill, Acts of Rebellion, xiv-xvii- the
politics of the aff open within a horizon of US imperialism, that must
be examined in making decisions about us policy- we must unlearn our
privilege of occupation as jayan nayar explains that we destabilize
the ground upon which we stand and reorder our worlds (Nayar, "Orders
of Inhumanity", Transnational Law and contemporary problems, 628
vol:9:599 1999)
All communications in the world employ metaphor.  Metaphoric language
is produced reductively in scientific discourse and instead an
intersubjective perspective in indigenous knowledge – we must argue
from intersubjectivity
Valerie Kuletz, The Tainted Desert, 235-6
and some evidence from Whitt, Roberts, Norman, and Grieves in
"Belonging to the Land: Indigenous Knowledge Systems and the Natural
World" 26 Oklahoma City University Law Review 701 (summer 2001), about
the value of genealogies as a way of relating to the land and
understanding a notion of beholdneness. This also included phil's
genealogical background.

Districts Neg

This INC starts with president bush in an interview from
http://www.whitehouse.gov/news/releases/2001/09/20010917-3.html, then
from http://www.whitehouse.gov/news/releases/2003/07/20030702-3.html,
then from quotes in
http://www.j-bradford-delong.net/movable_type/2005-3_archives/000161.html
about the idea that words and language have consequences in making
policy decisions: Pat Gehrke "Critique Arguments as policy analysis"
Contemporary Argumentation and Debate (vol. 19) 19-39 confirms the
importance of this in the way that we debate and learn in debate
rounds - the topic is written in a certain way and the aff responds to
that topical hail, we on the negative respond differently by saying no
to it as an attempt to examine the way the topic is written: we agree
with much of the 1ac, except its relationship to the topic: we found
some major formal changes in the ways that the topics have been
written including: resolved becoming part of the topic, quotation
marks being eliminated in 99-00, that stops being capitalized in
01-02, and disappears all together in 03-04 (we discerned this from
http://www.wfu.edu/organizations/NDT/HistoricalLists/TopicsNational1921-present.htm).
How do these formal changes alter the context of our debates?, how
does this change the affirmative relationship?- these changes are not
innocuous and must be engaged and debated before next years topic is
formulated.  We are in the age of discursive imperialism according to
Raka Shome (from "Postcolonial interventions in the Rhetorical Canon"
Contemporary Rhetorical Theory, eds. Lucaites, Condit, Caudill 1999,
593-600 ) and vote negative for much of the 1ac but to negate the
topic because discourse matters

 

Fort br Neg

            Round #  Octas WGA

            Vs Team: Emory GP

            Judge: Maurer, Wiese, Turner

 

            Case Args:

1NC:

Phil- Hello my relatives, play “water song” by Western Shoshone spiritual leader.

For the history of western thinking of past 8 centuries, framework has never been changed, we need a reexamination and cultural reconstruction.  Our efforts to bring justice into the world has changed, we should analyze questions and the question knowledge.  Then we can see different types of problems.  This difference transformation- fundamental questions that form the basis of civilization, social conditions will continue in cause/effect logic.

Destruction of the whole complex, change the way western people think and collect data.  All parts of human experience are related, because of their relationships.   New picture of reality= transformation, words with new words.

 

Deloria, USFG can’t be approached by topical mandate, instead should challenge framework of knowledge, compartmentalization and reducation- risks destruction of the planet, brutally genocidal relationship will remain unchanged.  Change way we collect data, horrifying atrocities against indigenous people.

 

Vote neg to repudiate this framework.

American, genocidal racism and militarism, 16th/17th century American Indians and European relations is most important- indigenous definitive to those against others- Churchill, lens.  History provides agenda, America colonized, suffered and continue to suffer.  Wholesale death, US same world as in the past. 


Churchill- horizon of violence, greed dishonesty with the 1AC. Must first discuss their claims from the bedrock- US/Indian relations.  Negative approach, rewards white male.  Turtle island, we betray the 1ACs transformation. We are participants in the world, interventions never destabilize where we stand.  Own locations within which we are ordered. 

 

Expert evidence not enough, destabilize, read debate through horror show that is Us-India, vote neg to unlearn privilege, must actively seek out, Keulartz, Metaphor is key to language, different systems of construction and modes of thinking, rigorously with metaphors.  From this perspective, the Indian field ofknowledge expands meaning, while science reduces meaning.  Vote neg to blur boundaries of aff/neg

 

1ac is not enough, topical narrowing begets violence and exclusion, vote neg to transform our technologies, to challenege assumptions.

 

Debate matters, make this debate matter, as a community- cannot invalidate genocidal blood lust.

Anything which doesn’t question,   I think you’re going to say that it’s the most important debate, not all of the 1NC is made on that.

Whats the link to the plan?

How should we look at the world?

There are different ways, we should be open? All we can say is making policies based on one way is bad.

Need to recognize place.

Double consciousness.

 

Fiat and engaging the state is like sitting in a hotel room yelling that they should do something, instead act like a thinktank and think about things.  Way you construct things is wrong. This education is otherwise-collins evidence is negative because we need to shift the way we view the world.

 

Science seeks to tell knowledge in certain ways, nuclear power plants don’t hurt anyone is a scientific discourse. Thing to do in a thinktank is to play the water song.  That’s an example of a legitimate response. Activist group online.  Trying to get people to think differently. Yespa

Need to engage arguments and debate differently.

The ways we collect data and how we respond to that data.  Deloria- scholars technical language to deal with it, cleverly divert this into harmless categories, continual replacement of words and new words is what the aff engages in, speed of 2ac overrun and its semi stable flow.  Literacy test, type of semantic domination of the US dominates people.

Can include economic discussion, Thompson ev, but their way of knowing the world, perm is incoherent- chances itll mess up is large, deloria.USfg should, excludes contradictions.
