Fort hays br Neg

            Round # 2 Shirley

            Vs Team: Northwestern BM – Precautionary Principle

            Judge: Blackmon – Pace

 

            The 1NC:

 

Music clip

 

Everything must be arranged in a full order.  For Americans find that they lack muscle, but not Americans but soldiers, and they make the necessary means to manufacture soldiers.  It’s war the Americans are preparing for, to compete, one must have soldiers, battleships, armies.  

 

We ask that you affirm that the USFG should use the precautionary principle as the criteria for formulating and implementing regulations on the non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels in the united states such that precautionary measures apply even if some cause and effect relationships proving harm to present or future human or non-human communities cannot be established scientifically.  We’ll clarify

 

Quote from Foucault’s Order of Things

 

We ask that you affirm that the USFG should use the precautionary principle as the criteria for formulating and implementing regulations on the non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels in the united states such that precautionary measures apply even if some cause and effect relationships proving harm to present or future planetary communities

 cannot be established scientifically.  We’ll clarify

 

Sound clip about indigenous nations and internal and external colonization

 

We ask that you affirm the USFG should not, we’ll clarify

 

Nancy Nesbitt uses the RFID to highlight the ubiquity of surveillance structures and to hold multiple identities – quotation

 

We ask that you affirm that the USFG should not use the precautionary principle as the criteria for formulating and implementing regulations on the non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels in the united states such that precautionary measures apply even if some cause and effect relationships proving harm to present or future human or non-human communities cannot be established scientifically.  We’ll clarify

 

The GPS can be monitored, it includes all in this room.  Laura Kergen explains the importance of GPS technology in configuring social space – quotation

 

We ask that you affirm that the consumption of fossil fuels should use the precautionary principle as the criteria for formulating and implementing regulations on the non-governmental consumption of fossil fuels in the united states such that precautionary measures apply even if some cause and effect relationships proving harm to present or future human or non-human communities cannot be established scientifically.  We’ll clarify

 

Global capitalism is imposing cultural homogeneity – we must change debate spaces, ballots cannot represent all that’s going on in debate – traditional debate imposes unchallenged space.  The ballot needs to be a site of incongruent representations of desires – quotation

 

Embrace the ballot as a heterotopia where advocacies can fit congruently.  If debate is to remain relevant, if it’s to continue to educate students in the age of discursive imperialism, debate must reconfigure its own spaces and operate within a political terrain.  Debate is unchallenged – we want to transform the ballot into a discursive heterotopia

 

            2nc Extensions:

 

the ballot is a discursive space where arguments and teams are written on, we can affirm all the affirmative plan and advantages in juxtaposition to all other arguments, the 1ac isn’t a reason to reject the negative nor is it intrinsic to an affirmative ballot – disrupting the space is key to politics. 

 

The ballot as a heterotopia exposes debate’s ordering and orderings in general.  We’re trying to expose the contingency of what is thought to be reality.   Democracy should be held in juxtaposition to other ways of viewing the world.   This mode of thinking jars and and encourages us to make better decisions (X)

 

Their permutations are reasons to vote negative that to the extent that their permutations are correct, we affirm their advocacy in the 1nc, so the perms are the negative.  Their advocacy is the plan text.  We need a bunch of different ways of butting things up against each other, of viewing the topic in ways that unsettle us.  All their arguments about maintaining democracy is an attempt to formalize the way we debate such that it determines the way we learn.  We must expose the ways we learn as a way of finding colonialism (X)

 

We also think that the idea that we should have a single solution doesn’t make sense in the realm of the environment where there are lots of knowledge bases that need to be attended to, Shiva argues that this homogenization justifies systemic violence (Shiva card)

 

The point of the discursive heterotopia is to get the tools needed to fight imperialism.  We must not continue in sedimented ways, responding to questions of exploitation requires us to examine spatial relationships that are a part of them (Edward Soja quote)

 

We think that this is a better way to make decisions, to literally juxtapose the different advocacies, literally write those on the ballot in juxtaposition to each other, this has the jarring affect previously mentioned (another quote on that question)

 

There’s not a reason why the permutation would be any better than the negative’s political act.  This political act is consistent with the args that we’re making.  The single ideology of the negative is heterotopia.  All of their permutations and the plan text are the opposite of the things they’re asking for, our political ideology is to affirm all these different advocacies as a means of butting up against each other that opens up other social possibilities (quote)

 

 

            1nr Theory debate:

 

We think that multiple ways of knowing should be incorporated in this round, their argument that deliberative democracy is the single way to evaluate the debate is an attempt to undermine that contingency (quote)

 

the framework for political debate must be open to reform – shouldn’t make those decisions off the board

 

all arguments are conditional, all counterplans are topical because they move away from the implied status quo.  The negative should introduce multiple contradictory approaches, mixed scanning politics enhances the scope and allows us to consider more alternatives (Etsioni evidence)

 

theoretical objections fail to capture the space created by us.  Treat this strategy as an invitation, not a burden.  They would harness the 1ar and 2ar to help improve the quality of debating in your decision. 

 

Most of their concerns are reasons for our spatialized approaches to theory.  We force focus without excluding superior alternatives from considerations (Bradley quotation)

 

We do respond to their arguments, we do more work in the debate to show argument interaction than most debaters do on the line by line.  The line by line mirrors the Geneva Convention by dictating how the Vietcong was to operate.  Creates technical language to dismiss non-western language oriented thoughts (Deloria evidence)

 

We’re not saying others have to debate this way, but we think you should respect our attempt to debate across cultures, we supplement not supplant.

 

They have one given relationship to the ballot and the outside world, that’s discursive imperialism (Zupancic quote)

 

We work within the given constraints of debate, means we can change things and implode things within the limits of debate and create new better styles of debate.

 

            2nr Strategy:

 

The discursive space of the ballot, by including multiple contradictory things on it, exposes the givenness of our realities so that any sort of problems that exist in the worlds, we can expose the givenness of them.  The Precautionary Principle doesn’t attend to the local knowledge bases that the Shiva evidence articulates.  The Soja evidence, the necessity to think about the practical and theoretical aspects of our world to be able to handle environmental degradation. 

 

Our strategy attempts to use different contradictory paths.  They begin with a single advocacy, but when we do that, we don’t come up with the best ideas – the Etsioni evidence.  This process allows you to think differently, so you make better decisions.  Bradley evidence says that it avoids being overly rationalistic, if you make your decision at the outset of what the advocacy is, then you don’t come up with the best ideas. 

 

Democracy is a political practice, the only way it’s valuable and relative is that we don’t take things off the table.  They say one advocacy key definitionally takes things off the table.  We should have no common doctrine initially to try to figure out what the best decisions to be made.

 

the negative has a better political strategy.  Their permutation still falls within the same category of a single advocacy at the outset.  Our multiple advocacies allow ideas to butt up against each other and creates the explosion that Zupancic is talking about.  Creates the possibility of a public space that responds politically.   That’s what the ballot as a discursive heterotopia can do.

 

 

Fort Hayes RB neg

            Round #2 Shirley Classic

            Vs. Northwestern BM 

               

            Case Args: We read 5 variations on their plan text and argued that all of the args., advocacies, words, and things in the round ought all to be affirmed on and in the ballot as a discursive heterotopia; (Benjamin Genocchio – Postmodern Cities and Spaces), (Foucalt – The Order of Things. “preface”), (Nancy Nisbet www.subtletechnologies.com/2003/nisbet.html), Antonin Artaud www.levity.com/digaland/celestial/artaud /judgement.html; “To Have Done With the Judgement of God” (Laura Kurgan (CaseBook)); (Ed Wingenback American Journal of Political Science Vol. 13, No.1, Jan. ’99 p.213-232); Amitai Etzioni, Public Administration Review, “Mixed-Scanning: A ‘Third’Approach to Decision Making” December p. 388-9)

 

 

 

 

 

 

Fort Hays RB Pre Shirley

 

FHSU BR Neg:

Neg Strats.

Reassess space:

We begin with an epigraph from Thomas Dumm in Foucault and

the Politics of Freedom about the necessity to reassess

space in discussions of freedom as space has been assumed in

liberal theory to be neutral and dividable.  Spatially

conditionally, we argue multiple overlaying and intersecting

counter-sites that oppose the 1ac: 1st countersite:

re-assess the 1ac sites as spaces -spaces inform most

basic debate formulations but also politics in general, and

it is necessary to re-assess space if we are to accomplish

the political tasks at hand. 2nd countersite: the aff treats

the topic, specifically "in the us" as a spatial

container to be filled, this homogenizes and

de-differentiates the topic and destroys its difference. 3rd

countersite: politics of space treated differently - and

understanding that politics operate within given spaces of

identity and ignore space: we find William Spanos' concept

of Identityless-Identities to inform a style of politics

that shifts strategically to attend to particular power

asymmetries. 4th countersite: affirm the entire 1ac as a

heterotopia, included is a quote from Foucault's "Of

Other Spaces"

http://foucault.info/documents/heteroTopia/foucault.heteroTopia.en.html

that heterotopias represent contest and invert culture that

it is found as a part of- this dislodges their spatial

assumptions of debate by responding to the givenness of

debate spaces.

 

Foreground spaces

We begin with an epigraph from Thomas Dumm in Foucault and

the Politics of Freedom about the necessity to reassess

space in discussions of freedom as space has been assumed in

liberal theory to be neutral and dividable.  While Dumm

indicts most of liberal political theory, Edward Soja in a

quote from Thirdspace: Journey to Los Angeles and Other

Real-and-Imagined Places (1996) indicts most current

scholarship as failing due to taking for granted space and

spatiality. Also from Soja, we strategically foreground

space as a needed corrective.  Debate practices as well as

the line by line treat speeches as containers to be filled

with argument, we also counter the IAC's politics of space

and spatiality- space and spatiality matters in this epoch

(as indicated by Foucault's "Of Other Spaces")  We

also examine debates orderings of its words and things

(Foucault The Order of Things)- treat politics of space

differently - and understanding that politics operate

within given spaces of identity and ignore space: we find

William Spanos' concept of Identityless-Identities to

inform a style of politics that shifts strategically to

attend to particular power asymmetries - and if you decide

that both the aff and neg need to be included as the ballot

then include the entirety of the IAC in our negative space

in order to represent, contest, and invert their affirmative

space and politics- advocating in an other space that

represents contests and inverts the political agenda of the

affirmative, Foucault again in "Of Other Spaces"

 

Spatial Identity Politics

The New York Times april 14, 1996, Debbie Gallant - we

begin with a story of a hate crime in billings, Montana -

a stone was thrown through the window of a jewish family's

home in order to destroy the menorah that had been there -

soon thousands of their christian neighbors had displayed

menorahs in their windows as a sign of solidarity - this

is a powerful political strategy - temporarily effacing

strict identities in order fight a common enemy - a

similar strategy of invisibility was carried out by the NLF

and NVA during the american occupation of vietnam (Spanos,

Heidegger and Criticism, p. 205) - identity politics

fragmented and ultimately collapsed post-vietnam activism

- spatial identity politics is a necessary corrective to

the failings of past political movements - as a part of

this strategy we install the room as political art with a

gps receiver - the dislocation that results from the

technological revolution: every inch of the planet has been

precisely mapped such that we can locate a debate as point

devoid of content: of identity (

www.princeton.edu/~kurgan/urhere/html/frame.htm ) - and

with a radio frequency id chip - by passing the chip

around we necessarily pass around an identity effectively

eschewing traditional notions of identity as fixed,

singular, positively ascertainable (

www.subtletechnologies.com/2003/nisbet.html ) - since most

notions of advocacy, competition, really most of debate rely

on fixed static notions of identity and location, we call

for a ballot that affirms the art installation as a

political strategy

 

Art Installation

We change the spaces of the debate - hang posters and set

up computers that display information relating to gps and

rfid (see above:

www.princeton.edu/~kurgan/urhere/html/frame.htm,

www.subtletechnologies.com/2003/nisbet.html) - we

encourage all the participants (judges, aff, others) to come

out of their seats, interact with our art installation -

we engage the debate/aff differently - we don't engage

the flow or refutation, instead we engage the debate in our

installation - in the space of the debate -most of our

speech time is devoted to participation and interaction

by/with the others  in the debate - most of that time is

usually spent discussing the gps technology, how it changes

the space/location of the debate and the "advocacy" that

are parts of the round as well as the rfid chip which serves

to challenge advocacy and identity in the round including

the spaces of the ballot - we then install the aff site

and the judge site (in addition to the gps and rfid sites)

to complete our installation

 

 

 

Fullerton

2NC

Goes for the K

Main argument was that the affirmative is a displacement of fossil fuels. The point of the debate is not whether or not action is good, but how identity is formed. Our argument is that the judge should endorse a geneological criticism. Metaphor that Bush taking democracy to Iraq is similar that Bush is now taking democracy to the Suburbs. This causes formations that take place when identities are formed. We do not preclude action, but we argue that you should act ethically and learn from history first. Biopolitics is bad but the reason why it happens is the formation of identity. K t/s case/

            Round #2  Shirley

            Vs Team Redlands TS:

            Judge: Vermitsky

 

 

            Off Case Args:

OBS I The power is in you not democracy

The left should not be calling for more democracy and a better democratic process; the key is to define our subject space correctly.  A subject space that seeks its authorization in a higher power, like God or the communist rev or dem will fail; we mus realize that we must act on our own, w/o recourse to a higher calling.  More demo in the system accepts reality as it is; a more radical subject space can change reality itslf

Glyn Daly 04 Slavoj Zizek: risking the Impossible www.lacan.com/zizek-daly.htm

“yet here I would venture…to risk the impossible”

 

Democratic system sare exactly such a system of immunity—it’s a way to defer our subject space and make it part of a colleciotn. We justify our decions on the basis of dem and not ourselves.  You should reject this approach and not seek authorization through dem; this card proves competition b/w our approach and theirs

Zizek 04  The Ongoing “soft revolution”  Critical Inquiry Wntr 04 v 30 i2 p 292 (32) “today the ultimate ideology…there is not external guarantee”

 

They key ethical stance is to shoot higher; don’t try to make capitalist democracy more incluseive, shoot to smash it altogether.  Recognize all you can do and how radical your subject stance can be.  Limiting this potential is more dangerous; the Nazis were evil not b/c they thought they were drunk w/ power but b/c they thought of themselves as insignificant bureaucrats

Alenka Zupancic 2000 Ethics of the Real: Kant and Lacan  p 96-97

“Another problem still remains…by-product of our actions”

 

There is an alt way of thinking: do not accept the world as it is and try to work w/I it but realize that the wold is a construction and as such we can change it.  Politics must not be repetitive democratic deliberation but active reistance.  It’s the diff b/w trying to correc the same system that reelected bush/ch and insisting the power sturcutrea that allowed such a travesty to happen are illegitimate in the 1st place and overturning the very order that produced such pitiful excuse fo leaders in the 1st place

Daly same cite

“Zizek is concerned to confront…nihilo and the political itself”

 

the aff will claim that their call to biomass is the nuggest that will revolutionize the entire system. Not so.  The aff and their authors pose as radicals but so longa s they try to work w/I the democratic system they can never transform it

Thomas Brockelman 03 The failure of the radical democratic imaginary; Philosophy & Social Criticism v 29 #2 p 194-6

“within Marxism ideology….contemporary academic discourse

 

the key is not to enter inot an adverbial debate w/ the power structur on neutral grnd its to draw a line b/w us and them entering in debate makes enemies adversaries and can never challenge the system.   They take antagonism and make it something called “agonism” wihc is just fine w/ those in P!

ZiZek 02

Revoltuion at the Gates: selected Writings from Lenin 1917 p 268-9

“in iceleand, some thirty…illegitimate enemy”

 

those whose interests don’t win out int eh democratic debate—are always treated as dirty others and oppressed and capitalism always triumphs.  Democratic debate w/I the capitalists structure can only produce decision based on fear and exclusion

Hakim Bey 93 Ontological Anarchist of the Information Age www.hermetic.com/bey/boundary.html

“the apa offers an interesting…antidote to fear, which is boredom”

Fullerton MM Neg

            Round # 1  Shirley

            Vs Team: Emory GP

            Judge: Ruth Zisman

 

            Overview:

 

 We begin with a rant on the importance of history and culture. We also question the success of colonization and why it still exists.They kritik government exclusion-minorities and immigrants are excluded in our democracy, the affirmative ignores these problems and is complicit through its state action. Our alternative is a genealogy of power. (Impact=colonialism and Nazism)

 

Immigrants are working in inhumane conditions. Where is the government? Why do we use this system? Our negative is a rejection of exclusivity, colonialism; these policies like the affirmative make the same mistakes of the past and justify any atrocity. These examples of forced assimilation continue to destroy culture-the affirmative’s color blindness perpetuates the problem.

We question the formulation of the affirmative policies-as long as certain cultures continue to be destroyed, it functions as genocide,  Johnson 01

 

AT: Framework:

 

Why do we follow this blindness? Fiat, that’s why.  Rawls ‘democratic process is a reason to vote against them. We reject their democracy. What is a citizen? Their use of the word is complicit in the death of an immigrant who can never be a citizen. Their democracy has killed workers for the wealth of corporations. We must find different mechanisms, and we control the uniqueness.

There are no justifications for accepting your interpretation- Kappeler 95 “ The Will to Violence: The Politics of Personal Behavior”

 

We should take political action within our agency-  this is a gateway to their interpretation

Reason why we come first-we must have this debate before we can take political action

We must constantly criticize- Kulnych 97-  “Performing Politics: Foucault, Habermas and Postmodern Participation” Winter 97

 

Role Playing is exactly the problem with their interpretation- we ignore the problems and disengage ourselves from the political, killing activism.  The counter-interpretation forces us to educate ourselves before entering the political system  Antonio 97

 

They force people into the system-

 

our interpretation is a gateway turn to all of their abuse arguments.

 

AT: Switch Sides

We will defend our framework, change comes with questions of agency, only through the negative can we access this ground.

 

AT: Activism

We criticize their internal link- we should only act within our agency, not making political action, the only way they can access their Rawls ev. is through policy making.

 

Their framework replicates the exclusive democracy- creates more racism and sexism

 

We become bad activists when we ignore status quo problems-

 

AT Authoritarianism:

Their hegemonic constructions justify state-based authoritarianism Dillon, 2002

 

They are more utopian than we are- we should have a bottom up approach. Don’t blame others, if there is a problem ask what you yourself can do

 

 

 

PERM:

Our alternative debate is a genealogy

We criticize their discourse, checks back their impacts

They can’t capture the 1NC,

We are not exclusive of state action; we need to find a mechanism to make the state more inclusive

 

Their alternative=enforces an abusive state.

 

Impact cites:

Attempts to formulate fiat is inadequate-the 1ac is a manual for living as per its methodology

Clifford in 2001, (Michael, Political Genealogy after Foucault, 2001 pg. 70-71)

 

Color Blindness is bad-

Culp 94- “ Jerome McCristal “COLOR BLIND REMEDIES AND THE INTERSECTIONALITY OF OPPRESSION: POLICY  ARGUMENTS MASQUERADING AS MORAL CLAIMS” NYU LAW REVIEW

            Judge: Ruth Zisman

Fullerton MM Pre Shirley

 

 

FEAR CITES

 

THE LINKS

 

THEIR ATTEMPT TO ISOLATE AND OVERCOME AN ASPECT OF TERRIFYING WORLD. FAR FROM HELPING ANYONE CONFRONT THE REALITY THEY DEPICT, THEY GENERATE TERROR IN THE FORM OF COMMODITY

ZUPANCIC 2003 (63-65) The Shortest Shadow: Nietzche’s Philosophy of the Two.

 

DISASTER IS EVERYWHERE WE ARE. THE 1AC TELLS ONE MORE TALE OF A TWISTED WORLD. THE SITUATIONS THEY LOCATE CONTRIBUTE TO THE COLLECTIVE LANDSCAPE OF FEAR. THIS CREATES THE VERY CONDIONTS OF UN-FREEDOM THAT FUELS CAPITALIST PRODUCTION

MASSUMI 2002 HTTP://WWW.TEXTZ.COM EVERYWHERE YOU WANT TO BE: AN INDTRODUCTION TO FEAR

 

FEAR WILL ALWAYS MOBILIZE PEOPLE THE WRONG WAY—IT TEACHES THEM TO DO POLIICS IN ORDER TO BUY OFF THE APOCALYPSE RATHER THAN CREATE BEAUTIFUL FUTURES. LIVING BECOMES A SURPLUS-VALUE IN THE CAPITALIST SYSTEM, THERE IS NO VALUE TO LIFE IN THEIR FRAMEWORK

MASSUMI 2002

 

IMAGES OF APOCALYPSE TURN LIFE INTO A PERPETUAL PREPARATION FOR DEATH, REDUCING THE VALUE TO LIFE

BORG 2003 PSYCHOANALYTIC PURE WAR: INTERACTIOSN WITH THE POST APOCALYPTIC UNCONSCIOUS, JOURNAL FOR THE PSYCHOANALYSIS OF CULTURE AND SOCIETY, SPRING 2003, PG. 57

 

THE ROLE OF DEBATE, WE ARE NOT THE VICTIMS THEIR IMPACTS TALK ABOUT. OUR ROLE SHOULD BE INDIVIDUAL REFELCTION AND FIGURING OUT OUR OWN ONTOLOGIES.

MASSUMI 2002

 

DO NOT APPROACH THE IMAPCTS OF THE AFFIRMATIVES AS POLICY QUESTION STO BE EVALUATED AS SUCCESSES OR FAILURES. VIEW THE STATUS QUO WITH UNCONDITIONAL HOPE.

MASSUMI AND ZOURNAZI 2002 (HOPE: NEW PHILOSOPHIES FOR CHANGE, PG. 211, 212)

 

ASSERTING UNCONDITIONAL HOE IN THE POTENTIAL OF THE PRESENT IS PART OF A LARGER PROCESS OF GLOBAL BECOMING. FAITH INTHIS POWER OF BECOMING IS THE ONLY WAY OUR PARTICIPATION IN THIS DEBATE CAN AFFIRM LIFE. MIRACLES DO HAPPEN AND WE MAKE THE CHOICES THAT EITHER DENY THOSE MIRACLES OR ACTIVELY CREATE THE CONDITIONS WHERE THEY OCCUR

MASSUMI AND ZOURNAZI 2002 PG. 241-242

 

LIVING CAN BECOME MEANINGFUL ONLY ONCE WE LET GO OF THE TYRANNY OF SURVIVAL AND CHOOSES TO SAY Yes to llife in all its mysterious beauty

Zizek 2003, the puppet and the dwarf: the perverse core of Christianity, 2003, pg. 94-100)

 

 

 

 

LAT CRIT NEG

FULLERTON MM

 

 

 

LINK

The legal system and language antipathy reinforces Latino invisibility, disempowerment, and marginality-LatCrit can be self-empowering and build solidarity between Latino communities.

Valdes 1997 (Francisco, Visiting Prof. of Law, University of Miami, California Law Review, October, p.1133)

 

 LINK EXTENSION

The legal system has a historical tradition of valorizing Whiteness and continues to be racist.  LatCrit is essential to calling this construction into question.

Valdes 1997 (Francisco, Visiting Prof. of Law, University of Miami, California Law Review, October, p.1112-1115 )

 

IMPACTS:

OUR IMPACTS ARE BASED ON EXCLUSION, WE REALLY DON’T READ EVIDENCE, IT MOSTLY CONCERNS WITH OUR PERSONAL EXPERIENCE AND HOW THE PLAN IMPACTS OUR LIVES.

 

The Alternative:  We must rethink the Black/White Binary and the label “other people of color.”  The absence of Latino/as from considerations of race is a grave omission, perpetuating an inaccurate view of history, enabling racists and race scholars to stereotype us, preventing us from fully participating in the struggle for civil rights. 

Perea 1997 (Juan, Professor of Law, University of Florida College of Law, “The Black/White Binary Paradigm of Race:  The               

                    Normal Science of American Racial Thought,” California Law Review, October, p.1257-1258)

 

 

SOLVENCY FOR THE ALTERNATIVE

 

LatCrit theorists propose an alternate way to look at race – one that recognizes both the myth and reality of race. 

Lopez 1997 (Ian, Acting Professor, BOALT, “Race, Ethnicity, Erasure:  The Salience of Race to LatCrit Theory,”California Law

       Review, October, p.1155-1158)

 

LatCrit is a self-reflexive theory – it operates on four distinct levels, critiquing experience, instilling practicality and transformation, fighting all forms of oppression, cultivating community, and defying essentialist notions.

Valdes 1997 (Francisco, Visiting Prof. of Law, University of Miami, California Law Review, October, p.1092-1095)

 

 

LatCrit discourse utilizes theory as a means to self-empowerment, resisting the urge to repeat the omissions and oversights of outsider theorizing.

Valdes 1997 (Francisco, Visiting Prof. of Law, University of Miami, California Law Review, October, p.1138-1139)

Rnd #5 – Nichols

Vs. San Francisco State BL

Judge: Louden

 

1NC

A-Spec

Violation – the affirmative doesn’t specify their agent of criticism

 

Standards

1/ Kills negative pre round prep and ground

2/ 1NC Strategy skew because prevents turns to certain industries

3/ Most limiting interpretation is key

 

Voter Fairness

 

Framework

Interpretation – The grammatical interpretation of resolved means the have to defend the consequences of FG

Definition is not just a starting point for the resolution

FG = government that’s in Washington DC

Should = demonstrate expectation off the plan

Violation - affirmative doesn’t fiat the plan

Standards

1/ Fiat is the most fair interpretation – predictable ground

2/ Aff’s interpretation allows them to sever plan action

3/ The Aff doesn’t have a text to their advocacy which is bad – when the advocacy is not written, there’s always possibilities of things they criticize and they can spike out of links

4/ The affirmative has a monopoly on discourse – they can read a k to a DA but not an Adv

Voter for Fairness and Jurisdiction

 

Hong Kong Oil DA

High Oil Prices are causing Hong Kong fishing reductions in the South China Seas

Lyn 10-10-2004

“Rocketing world oil prices have force some of Hong Kong’s” and “to cut back imports”

 

Attempts to solve climate change will hurt the oil industry by lowering prices

Amor 2002

“shareholders in leading oil and gas companies” and “access to energy reserves”

 

Every method used by commercial fishers cause pain and suffering for all marine life that can last for hours or days

Carr 2001

“the commercial fishing industry has come up with a variety of gruesome methods” and “ship draws in the lines”

 

The speciest and evil murder of non human animals creates a double standard of justice that miscalculates the value of life. Without a meaningful measure of justice, there is on value to life in their framework.

Dunayer 2001 Animal Equality: Language and Liberation p 4-5

“to specieists, however, unjustified killing is murder” and “speciesism rests on a double standard”

 

Counter Demand

Demands for action now out the movement at the mercy of the state – they argue state powers are the problem, crushing their movement

Martin 1990

“the desired for quick change s one reason why” and “the problem of structures”

 

And, the success of their movement is adopting the plan – however, this isn’t change, but cooption of their movement, preventing future action

Martin 1990

“most bureaucracies rely not on the use of force” and “difficult to recognise and to oppose”

“Karl Jacoby writes that t seems” and “the enslavement of animals was the training ground for male violence”

They are also conceding there is not text to their advocacy, which makes it impossible to engage them in their discussion. And, we solve all of your offense; you can claim critical disadvantages, just not critical advantages. Voter

CP – Exclude MOX

 

The US congress should establish, an emissions-free portfolio standard using non-mixed oxide powered nuclear power plants as a requirement for a phased reduction to zero non-governmental fossil fuel consumption for electricity generation in the united states by the neart

 

Engagin in MOX confuses and complicates US non-proliferation diplomacy and encourages the civil use of plutonium.  This destroys the NPT, increases the proliferation and makes it simple for plutonium to fall into the hands of terrorists

Steven Dolley 1995 – “The Mox and Vitrification Options Compared” – www.nci.com

            Judge: DeVault – Mary Washington

 

            Case Args:

 

US LEADERSHIP ADVANTAGE ANSWERS

  1. the status quo proves heg hasn't decreased enough to cause the impacts
  2. the plan  leads to backlash (X)
  3. multilateralism collapses US hegemony and prevents unipolarity (x)
  4. leadership solves nuclear war (Khalilzad)
  5. strong deterrence incentives in South Asia - no reason to engage in warfighting (X)

 

SOLVENCY ANSWERS

  1. no decrease in consumption

a)       empirically denied (X)

b)       older cars (X)

c)       foreign firms (X)

  1. we've got enough oil for 5,000 years (x)
  2. 3. oil isn't a fossil fuel - it's continuously generated (X)

ASPEC

a)       limits – justifies multiple number of agents

b)       ground – denies us textual competition to counterplans

Topicality Require – means mandate

 

POLITICS – SOCIAL SECURITY REFORM

 

Social security reform will pass now but will be a tough fight - capital key

 

social security reform will pass - Bush has the capital (X)

 

the auto industry and congress oppose the plan - would require massive political capital

 

raising CAF standards is the most controversial policy effort

 

legislation expends political capital - Seidenfeld 1994

 

Bush is critical to social security reform - without him, it's doomed

 

privatization is key to economic growth - stimulates capital and investment

 

 

BUSINESS CONFIDENCE

 

Bush election sends pro business signal, the plan would break his promise and signal uncertainty, nothing would be able to curtail support

 

reducing consumption tanks the global economy – Gelbspan

 

entire economy perceives new environmental regulations - the plan ripples through the economy

 

CAF destroys auto ability to develop new technology and costs tens of billions of dollars

 

predictability key  to biz con and investment

 

biz con decline results in economic collapse

 

US collapse causes worldwide depression

 

impact is extinction

Coercion DA

 

Protection of freedom is the only legitimate function of government—coercive measures that restrict such freedom are unjust

Peikoff 97 (Leonard, www.aynrand.org/site/PageServer?pagename=objectivism_pobs) "the basic political requirement…political and economic freedom"

 

Governmental energy regulations are the root cause of all energy crises and subvert individual freedom

Machan 95 (Tibor, Private Rights and Public Illusions, p. 65)

 

Electricity Prices DA

Electricity prices low now

Renewables increase electricity prices

Higher electricity prices hurt consumer spending

Knight Ridder 5/12/01 "any hikes in gasoline or electricity prices…could erode consumer confidence"

 

Consumer confidence key to US economy

Money Marketing 9/9/04 "it is the confidence of the consumer…look like a difficult situation"

 

Delegation CP—text: The United States Congress should through a resolution of authority delegate the necessary authority to the relevant governmental agency (s) <the plan text/plan mandates>.  The relevant governmental agency (s) should <the plan text/plan mandates>

 

Obs 1—Competition—CP isn't normal means and is mutually exclusive with the plan

 

Epstein and O'Halloran (David and Sharyn, 20 Cardozo L.Rev. 947) "there are two alternative modes…will perforce be used less"

 

Agency action solves the case

Topicality—consumption isn't emissions

T—upstream is production, not consumption

 

Upstream applies to production, not the actual use of the fuel

Here's a list of the major negative positions we have been reading.

- Politics
- States CP
- Gas Tax CP

to improve competitiveness in technology sectors)

key to solving Chinese starvation)

Oklahoma

NEG

We exclusively run the K....

K's we have run this year

1. Environmental Ethics

Shallow Reforms mask deeper change (these cites come from a book called "Defending the Earth" 1991. conversations between murray bookchin and david foreman)
We advocate "lifeplace" thinking, which is basically local good. The cite is Thayer 2003 ("LifePlace: bioregional thought and practice" pg. 1-3)

2. Cartography

Aff representations=collective identity. (Michael Shapiro, Violent Cartographies: Mapping Cultures of War 1997, p. 150)
We'll make specific Link arguments based on the Aff
Generic Links
1. USFG L- Shapiro, The Politics of Representation, 1988 (p. 90)
2. Country Name (naming) L-Shapiro 88 (p. 92)
3. Policy Rhetoric L-Shapiro 1997 (p. 60)

Alternative

We advocate 2 (not 2 each round, we'll decide on 1 before)

1. Levinasian alternative--infinite respect for otherness, accept the other (Shapiro 1997, p. 172-179)
2. Affirm disorder (Stavrakakis, Lacan and the Political 1999, p. 135-140)
-----

3. US Off the Planet

All cards come from Ward Churchill, "From a Native Son" (p. 85-90  &  520-530)
There are not tags..the 1NC is one long speech, with the cards read somewhere during the speech.
We argue that we should kick the US off the planet (put away your Space bad cards, this is not literal).  We claim that the issue of land should be a first priority before other issues (even if those issues are noble in their intentions). Our argument is that other forms of oppression (sexism , racism, homophobia, etc) stem from the colonization of native North American.  Achieving land return is the foremost question. Our Alternative is to imagine a world without the USFG.

            Case Args:

Solvency:

  1. Nuclear power is making a comeback now

        AJC 11/2/04 “oil’s rise above $50 a barrel is doing more”

  1. US nuclear power is set to expand

        --Business Week 11/8/04 (with oil over $50, nukes are back”         http://www.businessweek.com/magazine/content/04_45/c3907073_mz013.htm

        --Greenwire 7/6/04 “Beyond the industry’s two primary obstacles to expansion”

  1. Nuclear reactors can be made safe
  2. US nuclear power plants are highly susceptible to terrorist attacks
  3. Terror attacks will hurt the US economy
  4. US nuclear power means greater radiation exposure – millions could die

 

Natural Gas:

  1. no i/l – not all sectors affected
  2. NG prices falling now

        Inside F.E.R.C. 9/13/04 “Analysts last week slashed their near-term and long-range U.S. gas price forecasts”

  1. NG prices on track to decline – lower demand is key

        Tradesignals.com 10/1/04 “Meanwhile nature gas prices are expected”

  1. High NG prices good for the U.S. Economy – generate substantial benefits for coal and gas producing states which means more investment, consumer spending, revenue, jobs

        Dar 03 (Vinod, Managing Director @ Dar and Company, “Gas Crisis?”                 http://www.darandcompany.com/GasCrisis.html)

  1. NG forms the basis of strong cooperation with Canada – CFTA and 80’s prove

        Middleton 03 (Stacey, J.D. Candidate, 2003, Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law, 11 Cardozo J.                 Int’l & Comp. L. 177) “prior to the CFTA and NAFTA the U.S.-Canada energy relationship”

  1. US-Canada cooperation key to solve terrorism

        Sands 00 (Christopher, Dir. Of Canada Project @CSIS, “Integrated National Security Interests and               Homeland Defense,” www.csis.org/americas/canada/001022_integrated.pdf    

  1. WMD attack risks retaliation and would kill millions

        Easterbrook 01 (Gregg, Senior Fellow @Brookings, Writer @ New Republic, CNN 11/1)

  1. Natural gas forms the basis of strong US/Canadian energy cooperation – all Canadian natural gas exports to the US – Watkins and Bradley 03 (Campbell and Paul, Professor Emeritus (Economics) at the Univ. of British Coumbia and Hon. Prof. at University of Aberdeen, C.D. Howe Institute Commentary, April) “Painted with a broad brush, the picture of cross-border trade”

 

Price Shocks:

  1. They don’t solve
  2. No risk of resource wars

        Odell 04 (Peter, Prof. Emeritus of Int’l Energy Studies @ Erasmus Univ, Why Carbon Fueld Will     Dominate the 21st Century’s Global Energy Economy, p. xii-xiii) “Over the 21st century as a       whole”

  1. Resource wars are solved by technology and market mechanisms

        Hamilton 2003 (Ashley, Pols Stdnt @ Univ. of BC. Dialogue “Resource Wars and the Politics of     Abundance and Scarcity, http://www.polsis.uq.edu/au/dialogue/vo-1-3-5.pdf

  1. Resource wars can be solved by alternate technology
  2. Electricity prices are lower now than any other point in history
  3. Nuclear Power is extremely expensive – Capital investment required for new nuclear plants trades off with cheaper, more resilient energy alternatives – Vidal 6/12/04 (John, Nuclear Plants Bloom, www.guardian.co.uk/life/feature/story/0,13026,1280884,00.html “Nuclear stations usually take eight”
  4. Introducing renewables increases prices, many reasons

        The Electricity Daily, June 8, 2004, l/n “Introducing renewable energy unavoidably leads to higher                electricity prices”

  1. Hurts consumer confidence

        Knight Ridder Washington Bureau May 12, 2001 l/n “As previously announced layoffs”

  1. ConCon key to the economy

        Money Marketing, 9/9/04, p l/n “In one way, it is surprising that market expectations”

  1. Nuclear power is extremely expensive – construction of new plant would require increases in electricity prices – Makhijani 98 (Arjun, Founder @IEER, Nuclear Power: No Solution to Global Climate Change, March www.ieer.org/ensec/no-5/nuclr-no.html

1NC Kritik

Nature is dead, replaced by humanity’s artificial simulation of the environment which serves to convert wildlife into standing reserves of natural resources. Ecological capital becomes the ultimate basis upon which life is sustained, resulting in a global disciplinary grid of mandatory efficiency that culminates in the sophistication and expansion of bio-political control.

Timothy Luke, “The (Un)Wise (Ab)Use of Nature: Environmentalism as Globalized Consumerism?”

www.cddc.vt.edu/tim/tims/Tim528.PDF

“All of these environmentalizing initiatives reveal different aspects” AND “from the system of purchases.”

 

1AC’s depiction of the environment articulates it specifically by giving it spatial characteristics, assuming the identifiable examples of the environment exist within certain artificial territories. Regulating environmental activity by limiting it to a proper place reinforces the very state control over the environment that created the harms in the first place

Ferguson, 1996, Challenging Boundaries, ed by Shapiro and Kennan Alker

“At the global level, Homi Bhabha calls this” AND “stable truth, can it be resisted and re-created.”

 

This form of green governmentality is rooted within notions of management, control, and organization where power is situated at the level of life. The focus of discipline in relation to the body politic is absolutely essential to all wars, conflicts, and genocides, where the entire populations are encouraged to war for the benefit of the greater good.

Foucault, The History of Sexuality, 1978, p. 136-8

“Since the classical age the West has undergone” AND “biological danger to others.”

 

As opposed to the governmental managerialism of the affirmative our alternative is a struggle, a strategy, a green aesthetics of existence characterized by constant criticism and problematization,. While the affirmative just replaces one solidified power relation with another, alternative actualizes freedom as a practice and provides the only means through which to avoid domination, cooption and rhetorical devastation.

Eric Darier, 1999, Discourses of the Environment

“In order to answer this question, it might be helpful” AND “Foucault is particularly relevant to the task.”

 

The alternative is a distant strategy from that of the affirmative. Rather than speaking from a position of height, the alternative recognizes the agency we have on the ground

David Owen, Maturity and Modernity, 1994, p. 208-10

“In our reflections on Foucault’s methodology” AND “determinations of who we are.”

T and K

 Harvard Neg

 

Harvard AM

 

            Round # 7 Shirley

            Vs Team: Northwestern BM

            Judge: Strait

 

            Case Args:

 

Solvency

 

1. Turn: Science

 

a. Precautionary principle prevents scientific debate – undermines scientific literacy

Social Issues Research Centre, “Beware the Precautionary Principle,” 2002 – http://www.sirc.org/articles/beware.html

The precautionary principle is, however, a very useful one for consumer activists

 

b.  Turns democracy – we should privilege scientific method in policy-making – content neutrality vital for good policy and democracy

Norman Levitt, 1999 – Prometheus Bedeviled – p. 287-8

 

 

2. Turn: Technological Progress

 

a.  Precautionary principle stifles progress

Henry Miller and Gregory Conko – June 2001 (“The Perils of Precaution” – Policy Review) http://www.policyreview.org/jun01/miller_print.html

Application of the precautionary principle has already elicited unscientific

 

b. Technological progress is the only hope for global survival

Normal Levitt 1999 – Prometheus Bedeviled – p. 113

I am constrained by the realization that the globe now contains

 

c.  Restrictions on technological innovation will devastate economic growth

Eliezer Geisler 2001 – Creating Value with Science and Technology – p. 193

 

d. Decline in US economy risks global depression and war

Business World 1/8/1998

A global recession will make the 1929 depression

 

3.  Turn: Precautionary principle is a bad decision-making paradigm

 

a.  Precautionary principle offered as a “magic bullet” for resolving uncertainty – it is not

Michael Gough, 2003 (Politicizing Science: The Alchemy of Policymaking edited by Michael Gough) p. 24-5

Making decisions about risks to health and the environment is difficult for Congress

 

b.  Precautionary principle increases risks: diverts attention from more serious threats and ignores risk of inaction

T – Requiring

 

A. Our Interpretation – Topical affirmatives must mandate a decrease in the use of fossil fuels

 

Definitions

 

1. an energy policy is a direct plan of action – the plan must manage the distribution of energy not simply affect it

Robert MacGeorge 2003 – “What is Energy Policy, and Why Do We need It?” – http://www.ridgway.co.nz/Files/Energy-Policy.pdf

The New Collins Concise English Dictionary defines energy as

 

Requiring is the active form of the word “require”

Dictionary.com 2004

Require, requiring

 

Require means mandatory obligation

Words and Phrases 1960 (Vol. 37 Repay – Res Judicata, p. 117)

The word “required” as used in an act that the municipal authorities

 

Consumption means use

EIA 2004 – http://www.eia.doe.gov/glossary/glossary_e.htm

Energy consumption: The use of energy as a source of heat or power or as a raw material input

 

A reduction is lessening

Corpus Jurus Secundum vol 76 p. 170

REDUCTION.  The act of reducing, or the state of being reduced.

 

B. Violation – the affirmative does not directly mandate a decrease in fossil fuel consumption – it applies a decision-makingn principle that they claim would facilitate a reduction

 

Extensions

 

Oops, your aff doesn’t require a decrease in fossil fuel consumption – in fact – adoption of the precautionary principle would preclude GHG emissions reductions and would relegate alternative energy to the realm of research and development – not only should you prefer our evidence because it is based on a comprehensive assessment of the principle, but the fact that we can debate this question proves absurdity of your T defense and why we have to debate about ev to determine you’re topical, which guts predictability

Indur Goklany June 2002 – “Perilous Precaution: the Folly of Disregarding Science” – http://www.scienceform.net

The precautionary principle has been invoked to justify a policy of aggressive GHG emission controls

Permanent tax cuts 2nc UQ

 

Bush’s post-election political capital will assure quick passage of permanent tax cuts

 

CBS MarketWatch, 11/8/2004

Bush to use momentum to advance tax plans

President Bush's vow to spend the political capital he accrued in his election victory this past week will likely translate into quick action to extend tax cuts, with Republican lawmakers ready to move as soon as the 109th Congress convenes in January.

 

 

Bush will get permanent tax cuts now-must carefully pressure congress to assure passage

 

Footwear News, 11/8/2004

Bush's election to a second term, with his Republican Party increasing its majority in the House and Senate, suggests some policy certainties, industry executives said.

The president, in concert with GOP lawmakers in Congress, can now press for a simplified federal tax code and push to make permanent his earlier tax cuts, such as the reduction of inheritance taxes. Likewise, there is a shared agenda between GOP leadership in Congress and the White House to lower health-care costs, particularly for businesses shouldering double-digit increases to pay for employee policies.

"One of the factors that probably affects everybody, and certainly our members, is the health-care costs," said Bill Boettge, president of the National Shoe Retailers Association.

In the meantime, the election swept at least five more trade-friendly GOP members into the House and four into the Senate. But Bob Litan, a senior fellow in economic studies at the Brookings Institution, said, "President Bush still has to contend with some members of his own party having free-trade willies."

Nevertheless, Litan said the falling value of the U.S. dollar should help Bush sell his trade agenda. A cheaper dollar means export prices decline and boosts their volume, while increasing import prices and decreasing their volume.

Even so, progress on Bush's ambitious trade-expanding agenda -- it calls for at least a dozen free-trade pacts -- may be limited. "Instead of grand leaps forward, it will inch forward," Litan said. "The whole trade train has slowed down from an express to a local." At the top of Bush's agenda are tax reform and tax cuts. He pressed Congress in his first term to pass almost $ 3 trillion in tax reductions as a means to boost a slowing economy. Now Bush wants to make permanent $ 1.9 trillion of the trims, which are set to expire at the end of 2010 and include eliminating inheritance taxes. The 10-year cost would be $ 1 trillion.

But Republican and Democratic skeptics on Capitol Hill who oppose more cuts have said the federal budget can't sustain additional loss of revenue, given the $ 400-billion deficit and continued cost of the war in Iraq.

Another argument being made against the need for tax cuts is the improving economy, which perked up in the last year and saw Gross Domestic Product in the third quarter grow at 3.3 percent. In addition, retail sales last month increased 1.5 percent overall, including a 0.8-percent boost for sales at apparel and accessories stores, which is 4 percent higher than the previous year.

Plans to streamline the tax code are being closely watched by retailers who fear a national sales tax, which the president has talked about informally. Retailers argue that a national sales tax replacing the entire tax system would amount to a levy of more than 30 percent on all goods and services and hamper consumer spending.

Said Steve Pfister, SVP, government relations, at the National Retail Federation, "There has to be a careful vetting as to how the administration moves in respect to tax reform."

 

Bush has the votes

 

Business Week 11/22/2004

Whatever happened to the deficit hawks? As the celebration ends, Republicans should begin to take a hard look at the budget mess and the broader economic calamity that could befall President George W. Bush in his second term. Most of it is of his own making. And with wall-to-wall control of the government since 2002 and four full years since the last Democratic Administration, the responsibility will be entirely his.

Bush now has the votes to make his tax cuts permanent and to add new ones. The Congressional Budget Office (CBO), which reports to Republican committee chairmen, admits that with realistic assumptions the deficit will total more than $4.4 trillion by 2014 and not the $2.2 trillion in official projections. That's because making the 2001 and 2003 tax cuts permanent will cost an additional $1.65 trillion over 10 years. Preventing the alternative minimum tax from biting the middle class will cost $603 billion more. Tax simplification could be a net revenue loser, too.

Reg Neg:

A text: The United States Federal Government should conduct a binding regulatory negotiation over the substance, implementation and enforcement of (Eli: “Hey, could I borrow your plan text?”)

b) it competes

1. the counterplan is not resolved- dictionary.com defines resolved as a definite course of action, reg negs are not resolved because they allow involved parties to amend or nullify to aff’s regulation.

2. the CP tests the word requiring which means “to impose an obligation on; compel” according to American Heritage Dictionary 2000

3. normal means for the plan is command and control regulation- this is distinct from reg neg

            Round 6  Shirley

            Case Args:

                Sustainability

                Economic growth reduce poverty in the SQ

                Global poverty results from decline in growth

                Global conflict as result

                Global income and inequality has been declining for decades

                Economic growth is increasing developing environments

                Public policy making requires consequentialism

 

                Transitions

                Radical economic protection is key

                Zey, 1998

                Specificity is preferred

            Off Case Args:

The hunter has become has be the hunted

1. Zizek’s repetitive unceasing use of analogies becomes infinitely regressive, and replaces substance

2. The emphasis on defamilizarizing social reality attempts to destabilize the subject while positing an overwhelming social structure

3. exposing or traversing  the fantasy is impossible 

4. The dude is a neurotic

 

Nicol, Brian, “As If: Transversing the Fantasy in Zizek,” Paragraph, July, Vol. 24, Issue 2, p. 140

 

There can be no end ideology is inevitable but necessary, a certain critical juissance

 

Hasty Generalization, dogmatic refusal to compromise with Liberal Capitalism irrationally alienate him from the rest of critical theory as though he is just so damn excited to join the parade that he wants to precipitate that he won’t let anyone else march with him.

Karnas in 2002   [Todd, “Rat-Man and Wolf-man, Symploke 10.1, muse.jhu.edu]

 

 

Criticisms of capitalism that assert the existence of capitalist hegemony do not just highlight that which they wish to destabilize; they also performatively contribute to the creation of that hegemony 

Gibson-Graham, The End of Capitalism as We knew it, 1996, p. viii-x

 

Oedipus provides the model for capitalism’s strangle hold, by telling us what it is we really want, capitalism is able to colonize our very desires. We are left as neurotics requesting our own repression, we are left begging for fascism

 

Mark Seem, 1972, Anti-Oedipus: Capitalism and Schizophrenia

The Affirmative’s fusion of capitalism and desire is not descriptive , but is instead a productive of a universal model of the human psyche, and constitutive of that desire. Even the rhetoric of the 1ac, which insists that “we are energy consumers” imposes this model of subjectivity. This move to solidify the mind also ensures that a truly revolutionary subjectivity will always be excluded from critical political strategies of fragmentation

 

 

More on Fragmentation: Revolution requires that we shake off the oedipal yoke of psychoanalysis, refuse to bind ourselves to its imposed though structures , scramble the codes of subjectivity and stop desiring our own repression

 

Deleuze and Guattari Anti-oedipus: Capitalism and Schizophrenia, 1972, 83.

Visions of the social space as being wholly contained within capitalism allow it to saturate our entire existence and require totally impossible narratives

Gibson-Graham 1996, 258-9

Gibson-Graham, 1996

Harvard LM Pre Shirley

 

Hey JP I got Harvard LM to explain their stuff some more.

 

 

two main negcase strategies:

 

 

1. the refusal

a) the refusal is a Kafka story that we read (from the Complete Works, 95)

the story is about a town thats run by this guy called 'the tax collector.'  the poor qaurter of the town burns down and the people go to him and ask him to get money from the capital to rebuild it.  he says no, and then the narrator says that this made all the people feel relieved.  he explains that this happens all the time and that the peoples demands are always refused, but they are happy because it confirms a center of power, even as that power denies them.

 

 

this is like debates one-way state focus in that it creates an 'absent center', its the corner stone of metaphysical thought and that causes the impacts

 

 

b)Faith in the center is bad -- Derrida from Structure Sign and Play p.

280

c)The impact is, ya know, extermination of the other and stuff - Spanos

from America's Shadow, 2000 p. 10-12

d) the alt is us, reps key judge --Doty from Imperial Encounters, p170

we kind of usually refuse to be pinned to a specific text - the doty card just sort of says representations underly politics.   we say that things like fiction are important to sort of fracture the uniform language of politics the doty card talks about.   we say thats sort of like a metaphor for what the act of critique is in terms of disruption.

 

 

2. the south

a)the link: the south is a borges story from Personal Anthology, p16-23

its about a guy who goes on this fantasy trip to this ranch he owns while hes dying of blood poisoning. we use it to make the argument that the romanticization of nature isnt politically active, but more of an escape mechanism.

 

 

b)the impact: the impact is infinite distance --"the imperial message" a

Kafka story from the complete works, 95

the imperial message is a story about a messanger of the emperor who can

never reach you (who are awaiting the message) because he is infinitely

far from you.  but you sit there and wait for him because you are silly.  the sort of voyeristic distance is an infinite one that seperates us from a lived experiance of the world.  thats life denying, like kafkas infinite distance.

 

 

c) the alternative is laughing like the devil not like the angels --

Kundera from the book of laughter and forgetting

its this little parable where he says the first laughter was the devils, he laughed at gods arrogance in presuming to be able to order the entire universe.  the angels tried laughing back but only out of fear and insecurity at god being laughed at.   the cards explains that the devils laughter sort of lifts the weight of the world and allows us to be free rather than continually insecure about a collapse of order

 

 

We will obviously explain these more if asked.  We've also run a foucault

K (against GMU) that was mostly Luke cards, pretty standard really.

 

 

Oh, yeah, and one time, when L was stuck in Pittsburgh, M ran a

stavrakakis/zizek psychoanalysis K against Emory KG's democracy aff.

 

two main negcase strategies:

 

 

1. the refusal

a) the refusal is a Kafka story that we read (from the Complete Works)

b)Faith in the center is bad -- Derrida from Structure Sign and Play p.

280

c)The impact is, ya know, extermination of the other and stuff - Spanos

from America's Shadow p. 10-12

d) the alt is us, reps key judge --Doty from Imperial Encounters, p170

 

 

2. the south

a)the link: the south is a borges story from Personal Anthology, p16-23

b)the impact: the impact is infinite distance --"the imperial message" a

Kafka story from the complete works

c) the alternative is laughing like the devil not like the angels --

Kundera from the book of laughter and forgetting

 

 

We will obviously explain these more if asked.  We've also run a foucault

K (against GMU) that was mostly Luke cards, pretty standard really.

 

 

Oh, yeah, and one time, when L was stuck in Pittsburgh, M ran a

stavrakakis/zizek psychoanalysis K against Emory KG's democracy aff.

 

Harvard LM Neg

 

Also at Kentucky you judged Harvard LM round 3 negative against Kansas

CS, and Harvard won.

--- end of quote ---

 

 

kansas read renewable fuel standards w/ a big warming advantage. harvard read a critique of centering based on some kafka and a card from derrida and a couple of cards about the weather. essentially, they argued that the aff displaces anxiety onto an imaginary center (variously the state, the weather, etc.), this disables effective solutions and causes violence. aff permuted; neg won the race to the middle.

            Off Case

There is no distinction between life and death. The 1ac is based on life as an organism. Neg posits alternative understanding---carbon as music not organism. Under this interp. 1ac has no value and no impacts. Vote neg on presumption. The 1ac reinforces scientific rationality, which is a form of destruction, since the incomprehensibility and contradictions of the cosmos are “destroyed” by the AFF’s attempt to perfect the organism.

            1nc Positions

T: Energy Policy must be implemented by the DOE

In assessing the political acceptability AND mandatory reduction target

 

C/A Lewis

 

Counterplan: Fuel Efficiency

Text: The Department of Defense and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration will research and develop fuel efficient aircraft technologies consistent with the Air Force Science and Technology programs. All necessary funding is guaranteed. We’ll clarify.

 

Solvency: Their bullock evidence cites declining support for Air Force programs as the problem. Military research facilities are crucial to maintaining the US technological edge.

Bullock 1999, online

I believe it is still important AND technology development function

 

DOD fuel efficiency gains will benefit the commercial sector

Defense Science Board Task Force, 2001, online

The link to national security AND lower system unit cost

 

The gov’t can assist commercial aviation through R&D

National Research Council 2002, online

At least since the founding AND by the first approach

 

Tech superiority key to successful warfighting and maintain the US military edge

Bullock 1999, online

Superiority in military technology AND how much to spend on it

 

            1nc Case Args

Airlift Adv.

Relying on commercial tech development will destroy US military technological edge – 3 reasons.

Bullock, 1999, online

Why can’t the commercial marketplace AND what will come inevitably

 

1AC contradicts – if tech for efficiency exists now, then the military doesn’t need any gains in efficiency

 

The proble isn’t tech – its how the DOD evaluates efficiency options

Defense Science Board Task Force, 2001, online

Existing and emerging technologies AND different investment decisions

 

SQ solves –

a)        dod is funding emissions efficiency research now

National Research Council, 2002, online

In addition to the FAA AND with regard to commercial aviation

b)        Congress is already replacing and modernizing refueling aircrafts

General Accounting Office, 2004, online

The current refueling force AND of about 6.2 percent

 

China Adv

Gov’t inventories are causing high oil prices – they’ll reach capacity within months, and prices are already starting to fall

Hanke, Forbes, 11-29-04, online

What’s missing is the inventory story AND permanently high oil prices

 

China is modernizing their commercial air fleets now AND all civilian modernization efforts increase military power

Flight International 10-26-04

Chinese manufacturers are steadily increasing AND defence programmes

 

Navy and info tech is key to Taiwan and China is essentially there now

Alexandr Nemets, Newsmax/Tuesday, 8-10-04, online

China also sees its navy AND much more effective

 

China believes its ARMY and info tech is key to deterring the US, and its modernizing these now

Nemets, above (aff author)

During the last several months AND acquiring the most advance weaponry

Iowa KL

            Round 4 Kentucky

            Vs. aff: Wake AL

            Judged by:

                Josh Hoe – mult conditional cps bad, 50 state fiat bad…he buys these

            Case Args:

Warming

Sun’s magnetism is the cause of global warming – the human impact is tiny. Glassman 5-1-02 www.aei.org “Global Warming? Try Getting Out of the Sun”

 

Cosmic ray patterns perfectly coincide with temperature patterns – the climate is on its way to a cool period.  Jaworoski Winter 2004 “21st Century”

Competitiveness

1. Heg unsustainable – nine reasons.  Posen and Ross Winter 97 “International Security” pg. 42-3 “One of the foremost…blunders are possible.”

2. Counterbalancing –

A. perception of US hegemony leads to international coalitions to balance the US.  Zarif Harvard International Review Winter 2003, “In such a world system…military muscle.”

B. Counterbalancing leads to Prolif and first of wmds.  Eland CATO Policy Analysis, Nov. 26, 2002, pg. 459

3. Heg ? imperial overstretch. Layne 10-6-02 LA times Lexis “And at the end of the day, hegemons”

Overstretch decreases the US’s overall security and leads to wmd Prolif. Eland 02. pg 459.

4. interventionism

A. primacy makes global intervention inevitable. Layne Fall 1993.   Foreign Policy. “the strategy of preponderance will inexorably”

B. interventionism kills millions and leads to wmd terrorist attacks. Bandow July 1994 Current.  “Further, intervention has a great human cost…able to provide full protection.”

5. terrorism

A. hegemony leads to terror attacks with wmds – restraint solves. Eland 12/17/98 CATO Foreign Policy Briefing, No. 50 “All of the examples….more restraint overseas.”

Lack of strategic clarity dooms the War on Terrorism to unsustainability. Record, “Bounding the Global War on Terrorism” December 2003. Pg. vi

 

 

Elections

A. Bush win now. Frontrunner 10-6, “polls out today showing that president bush”

B. Decreasing FF consumption alienates bush’s most significant political allies.  Gelbspan 04 – Boiling Point pr. 43-44 “For starters…Responsive Politics

C. Kerry will hike taxes causing a depression. Kudlow 3-19-4 online “Kerry’s the true Herbert Hoover candidate”

Depression causes global wmd wars. Beardon 2000

 

Kerry’s plan crushes growth without adding government revenue.  Riedl, 9-21-04 online “Campaigns typically understate the cost”

Bush’s tax plan will stimulate demand and supply sides of the economy without inflation risks.  Kane 9-20-04 online “the Bush plan would provide a strong stimulus to both the demand”

Kerry would role back the Bush tax cut and crush current growth – Bush policy key.  Kudlow 4-3-04 NationalReviewOnline.com, “Jobless Recovery?” lexis “the combination of tax cuts and low interest rates”

 

States CP

Text: The fifty states and all relevant United States sub-national actors should establish a cap on non-governmental carbon dioxide emissions, reducing it to two thirds of present levels by 2020, and implement the cap through auctioned tradable permits.  The fifty states should produce and distribute pamphlets explaining the program and encouraging cooperation with all relevant foreign actors.  The fifty states should offer all relevant foreign actors memorandums of understanding as per the 1NC Rabe evidence.  We will clarify. 

A.       Not Topical – It’s the states

B.       Competes because federal action is bad.

C.       Solvency – states solve memorandums of understanding New Jersey Proves.  Rabe 2004 Statehouse and Greenhouse: The emerging politics of American Climate Change policy, p. 139 “New Jersey is clearly…verification system.”

 

State emerging policies are essential to reducing US ghg production – they put climate change on the national agenda and send the necessary international signal. Hodas, 21 Pace Envtl. L. Rev. 53, 2003

California proves all of our solvency arguments.  Giovinazzo, 30 Ecology L.Q. 893, 2003

1990 Clean air act sets precedent for a state centered permit system.  Rabe 2002 online “many federal policies relevant to climate change”

States solve trading policies, Rabe 2002

CP solves entire case – international memorandums  solve Kyoto provisions.  Rabe 2004.

James Madison GM Pre Shirley

v.

 

 

Consumercide Kritik

 

The problem of resource scarcity is directly related to the next ridge syndrome of early Americans

(Roderick Nash, “American environmentalism: Readings in conservation history”. 1989)

 

The affirmative’s decrease in consumption does not question why we consume, it simply rearranges existing structures

(William Ophuls “Requiem for modern politics”. 1997)

 

Hence the judge should base their decision on a utopian vision for much simpler lifestyle. Otherwise the ongoing energy despotism will continue to fuel biocide and genocide

(William Ophuls “Requiem for modern politics”. 1997)

 

Thus our alternative is endorse a utopian vision of the conserver society

(Ted Trainer “the conserver society: alternatives for sustainability”. 1995)

 

 

 

Oil DA

 

A U.S. decrease of oil consumption means Saudi Arabia would start a price war which Russia would win

(Edward Morse and James Richard “the energy battle for energy dominance” Foreign Affairs, March/April 2002)

 

U.S. conservation could start a battle for control over oil prices

(Edward Morse and James Richard “the energy battle for energy dominance” Foreign Affairs, March/April 2002)

 

Collapse of Saudi economy results in civil war and global depression

(Steven David “saving America from the coming civil wars” Foreign Affairs Jan/Feb 1999)

 

Collapse of global economy risks nuclear war

(Tom Bearden “the unnecessary energy crisis: how to solve it quickly”. www.freepublic.com)

 

NEG v. Emory  (permits)

 

Eco Mod

 

The ecological crisis is not the nature but that of society. To begin to

respond, we can’t rely on recycling or green shopping insead we must formulate

an entirely new environmental Ethic. Foster 1994 “The Vulnerable Planet” pg 12

– Yet most current prescriptions…relationship between nature and society.

 

Early Radical critique focused on formulating such a reflexive ethic, however

it has become co-opted by a strategy of ecological modernization, instead of

focusing on self-determination, de-centralized decisionmaking and social

concerns, ecological modernization priviledges top-down technocratic decision

making and a renewd belief in mastery and control to assuage our environmental

concerns Hajer 1995 “The politics of Environmental Discourse: Ecological

Moderniation and the Policy Process.” Pg 32-3

 

With the earth in balance, we must identify a new process. Reflexive ecological

modernization is possible only if we turn policy making over to the people it

effects. Dicsussion choice will reformulate both our understanding of the

problem and the solution while taking power back form the technocrats. Hajer

1995 pg 280-1

 

Second implication: because non-reflexive eco-mod falls back into the old

modernist within the system, whitout changing it totally, they’ll never solve

 

We believe the judge to be an intellectual who must evaluate how to construct

environmental policy, not whether or not to act. The ecological crisis demands

that we investigate institutional practices and affirm values of democratic

decicion-making. Hajer 1995 pg 280

 

Global Environmentalism

 

environmental movemens must be able to mobilize various groups and form

coalitions; People will choose to support or oppose activists depending on how

the movement affects their interests. Buttle 1995 “Rethinking International

Policy in the Late 20th Century.” Pg 191-192

 

global framing faisl for two reasons; impacts are easily undermined by specific

studies and because their rhetorical strategy relies on economic benefits as a

form of persuasion, it divides regions rather than uniting. Buttle 1995 –

193-194

 

Thinking globally

 

Nd acting locally has resulted in consumer-driven solutions wherein we are

cleansed by our consumption of supposed safe, “green products while it

simultaneously allows for international conferences of states and coporations

to set sneivornmental regulations that are in their own benefit, and to the

detriment of nature.” Maniates 2002 “Individualization: Plan a tree, buy a

bike, save the world?” from Confronting Consumption by Princen and Maniates.

Pg 58

 

 

James Madison GM – Alex Gonzales-Black & Piero Mannino@ Liberty

                -k of consumption (William ophuls, requiem for modern politics, 97)

t- total reduction = net decrease in consumption

oil da- price wars “morse and Richard: the battle for energy dominance” foreign affairs 02

Japan Counterplan

Text: The United States Federal Government should enter a process of prior, genuine, and blinding consultation with the government of Japan over the Affirmative plan. The United States will advocate the affirmative plan throughout the entirety of the consultation, but will give Japan the right to accept, reject, or modify any parts of the plan.   The united States Federal Government will then implement that plan according to the changes made by Japan. 

October Surprise

 

Observation I – Competition

Observation II – Japan will say yes

-Struck ‘01

Obs III – US-Japan Alliaces

Prior Consultation key to US-Japan alliaces

-Mochizuki ‘97

US-Japan are key to overall asian stability

-Roth ‘00

Asian instability Risks Nuclear War

-Straits times ‘04

If Bush starts looking bad in the polls he will invade Iran

Gwynne Dyer “04

If Bush’s number start to look shakey, he will attack Iran

The Counterplan:

 

The United States Federal government should enter in to a package deal negotiation with the European Union and condition the affirmative plan on a European Union agreement to ban cod fishing. Negative speeches will clarify intent.

 

Contention 2: Competition

               

The counterplan is mutually exclusive-The plan is immediate and unconditional, the counterplan enters a negotiation and puts conditions on the plan. You cannot do both.

 

Contention 3: Net Benefit

 

  1. Cod will go extinct without a fishing ban, Reuters, October 18th, 2004, http://olympics.reuters.com/newsArticle.jhtml?type=scienceNews&storyID=6531209 “Cod stocks in Europe’s—state of these stocks

 

B. Overfishing risks ocean ecosystem collapse, Robin Kundis Craig, 2002, Law Quarterly, “Taking the long view of Ocean Ecosystems”

 

 

Block Strategy:

They extend everything in the block

 

            2nr Strategy:

 

Go for the counterplan in the 2NR with the codfish scenario as an independent biodiversity advantage along with timeframe defense against peak oil, as to leverage the full weight of the advantage

KANSAS JT NEGATIVE (against UTD)

 

T:  Non governmental:  the plan is limited to nongovernmental producers of energy not consumers.  Empirically, net metering allows a reduction in governmental consumption.

Kansas JT Pre Shirley

 

KY is the only tourney

we've attended so far...that being said, I don't think we

really have any positions that qualify as "negative

generics" yet.  The positions we've read in more than one

debate (ie, two debates) are Agamben/Biopolitics and a

Politics disad based on extension of the debt ceiling, the

cites for which can be found on several other case lists

b/c it's the Politics disad all the KU teams have been

running.  Other neg. positions we've run are the Sea World

PIC (contra George Mason Univ.'s "animal exploitation

industries" aff), Iraq Reconstruction Oil Disad, Russian

Economy Oil Disad, and "High oil prices key to renewable

energy/energy efficiency" turns.   In another debate, we

"deployed silence," to quote the opposition (Regis).  Hope

that helps...I don't really have the cites for these

positions on me at the moment, but I don't think there's

anything too exotic about any of them.

1NC-

 

Alien v. Predator

 

                Ethics of consumption and environmental degredation has spread around the world as part of global governmentalist project of development. The aff has made a choice to use (?) space of the state to oppose consumption of which forecloses action in non-state space.

                Kuehls ’96 Beyond Sovereign Territory: The Space of Eco-Politics.

 

 

The state is the improper actor to orient our thinking around because the notions of consumption can operate beyond the grasp of sovereignties.

                Kuehls 96

 

The choice to incorporate the state into advocacy not only dooms any hope of solvency for the aff. But ensures the ability of sovereignty to canalize our political thinking away from non-state responses to consumption

                Kuehls 96

 

Vote neg to deracinate politics from the aff’s worship at the alter of sovereignty – this is crucial to countering global governmentality and consumption.

                Kuehls 96

 

Speaking for others

The oppressed must speak for themselves. The aff places themselves in a location to speak for another.

                Alcoff 94 Feminist Nightmares: Woman at Odds.

 

Allowing privileged persons to speak for the disposed ensures that the dominant voices will continue to be heard, reifying oppression.-

                Alcoff 94

in for massive climate changes.

extreme," says Kargel.

            Case Args:

 

We must start from a historical genealogy from which we recognize the colonial nature of US culture, and recognize the privileges that we accrue from such a system (Ward Churchill interview they play off laptop). Alternative

 

There must be a pragmatic methodology for social change that makes a connection with the oppressed, through dialogue.

Oppression is grounded in concrete reality, must start from that reality to create strategies of real change. Must understand the dynamics of oppression, must recognize your privilege in the complicity of the system.

China DA (agriculture)

High-yield agriculture is allowing a US surplus of grain – this grain surplus is going to be exported.

Des Moines Register, September 26, 2k4 (Sunday)

 

“As Iowa farmers began to harvest….Exports are the major swing factor…”

 

First, Without high-yield farming, billions would starve to death

[Dennis T. Avery, Saving the Planet with Pesticides and Plastic, p. 161

 

“Hunger is one of our strongest emotional…most of them caused by civil strife”
