                                Orlando Sentinel Tribune, Feb. 1, 2k4

                               

“To get an idea of the magnitude… huge umbilical cord between the two countries”

 

Chinese Starvation becomes inevitable – puts billions at risk

International Herald Tribune, May 3, 2k4

 

“The rapid urbanization of China…7 percent of the world’s arable land.”

 

Competitiveness/Neoliberalism K

Link: National competitiveness discourse serves to prop up neo-liberal economies based on high consumption, expanded markets, division of labor and anti-environmentalism.

[Ibrahim El-Issawi, Al-Ahram Weekly Onine, “Competing Agendas” January 8, 2k4 http://www.weekly.ahram.org.eg/2004/672/ec2.htm ]

“one of the reasons competitveness…is what national competitiveness is about”

 

Implications

Neo-liberalism negatively effects the lives of millions by destroying homelands and creating environmental exploitation that flips the case.

 

[Friends of the Earth International, “Towards Sustainable Economies:Challenging Neoliberal Economic Globalization, http://www.foei.org/publications/pdfs/sustain-e.pdf ]

               

“Neoliberal economic globalization is flawed in practice…An alternative approach is necessary.”

 

Competiveness rhetoric leads to an explicit cycle of escalating nationalism

 

[George DeMartino, Global Economy, Global Justice: Theoretical objections and policy alternatives to neoliberalism. Routledge Publishers, 2000, p. 171

 

“Despite whatever other virtues…tariffs on their exports might do the trick.”

 

Nationalism inevitably leads to genocide

[Carl Savich, “Nationalism and War: Nationalism: Origins and Historical Evolution” June 14, 2k3, http://www.serbianna.com/columns/savich/043.shtml

 

Alternative – The Neoliberal economy is created through deliberate political choices. Rejecting such policies and their inherent notions of competition is the first step in creating a just economic order.

 

[David Korten, Knight-Ridder Financial News, “There’s a Dangerrous Flaw in ‘Global Economy’ Concept” Marcch 10, 1996, http://www.islandhosting.com/~contempo/library/mai/nafta.3.html]

 

“It is quite disingenuous…join in this challenging endeavor.”

Government Procurement CP

Federal procurement of renewable technologies causes economies of scale and commercialization – shifting the national market away from fossil fuels.

 

Stronberg and Singh, ’01 [JBS Group and Renewable Energy Project]

[Joel and Verinder, Government Procurement to Expand PV markets, http://solstice.crest.org/repp_pubs/articles/pv/4/4.html]

 

“Achieving even the modest environmental goals…”

 

State government and federal department purchases prove that procurement remains an open option to the government

 

Case, ’02. [Director of Procurement Strategies at the Center for the New American Dream]

[Scot, Government Procurement Journal, October, www.govpro.org]

[May, http://www.eere.energy.gov/femp/pdfs/29267-2.3.pdf]

States/Lopez-style CPlan

 

1. THE PLAN AND CP ARE MUTUALLY EXCLUSIVE:

CAN’T RULE THAT THE PLAN IS ILLEGAL AND DO THE PLAN AT THE SAME TIME. IT SEVERS THE INTENT AND ENFORCEMENT OF THE AFF.

 

2. The counterplan’s use of the 11th Amendment provides exclusive jurisdiction that blocks federal action.

Louise Weinberg, Brigham Young University Law Review. 1995. Rev. 731

In Pennhurst…Pennhurst blocks federal court orders…as a matter of state law.

 

Contention 2: Solvency

The Court can make our ruling and devolve authority to the states.

Mark A. Miller, Cleveland State Law Review, 1998, Rev 159

The history of the Tenth Amendment is an appropriate…curtail the Spending powers.

 

More Solvency Evidence

They have no federal key warrant, especially in the context of energy policy.

Energy Report v29, n33, Aug. 13, 2001. L/N.

The governors of all 50 states…associated with energy production.

 

State leadership on energy is key- it can foster changes at the national policy level

ACEE Press Release. Dec 11, 2003. online at www.aceee.org/press/e031pr.htm

States can take important leadership roles…innovative and effective….leadership in energy efficiency policy.

 

State action spurs federal action on fossil fuel consumption, which in turn sparks international modeling

Dylan Golden 1999. “The Politics of Carbon Dioxide Emissions Reduction: The Role of Pluralism in Shaping the Climate Change Technology Initiative”. UCLA J. Environmental Law and Policy. L/N.

Individual states vary widely…in the case of gasoline taxes.

 

States can solve on Federal Lands

NGA homepage 04. NR-17, Management of Federal Lands Policy

Many states have the capability…management of all land resources.

 

NGA fiat is only 1 actor- it includes all the States, Territories, and Commonwealths.

Environmental News Network, Aug. 17, 2001.

The governors of the 50 states…energy supplies and services.

 

NGA has done uniform action on energy policy.

Energy report, Aug. 13, 2001.

The governors of all 50 states…their energy prices will be stable.

 

State energy laws solve for multiple reasons

William Prindle and Nikolaas Dietsch, 2003. Energy efficiency’s next generation: innovation at the state level. ACEEE. November.

California’s Title 24 standard…code enforcement.

 

 

Specific States Solvency for Tradable Permits

EU is comfortable trading with states- they just want some form of US participation and believe that the states could create a global model

Greenwire. June 28, 2004.

Climate change will be one of two major issues…first step to a worldwide emissions trading market.

 

State governments can adopt tradable permits schemes- occurs now

National Journal. July 13, 2004.

Although the Bush administration…flexible cap-and-trade program…gradually reduced over time.

 

State tradable permits are capable of creating world markets- their economies are huge

Platts Coal Outlook, Sept. 29, 2003.

But even a regional…way we should proceed.

 

Flaws on state level are same for federal rules- states implement these laws

Barry rabe, Greenhouse and Statehouse. Nov. 2002. p4

Climate change has not figured prominently…other nations and Canadian provinces

 

 

Most commonly-run Topicality args

 

Topicality Require:

 

A.             Definitions

1.              “Requiring” something makes it mandatory

 

Words and Phrases ’97 (v37 pocket part, Requiring, p. 111)

“Term “requiring” as…in nature of command or order.”

 

2.              “Total consumption” is a term of art that is distinct from sector-by-sector approaches.  It’s inclusive of all 5 major sectors of the economy

 

EIA ’04 (Energy Information Administration’s Monthly Energy Review July 1st, 2004—lexis)

 

“Primary Consumption: Consumption in the five energy-use sectors…Classification System 22 plants.”

 

B.             Our interpretation

Post-the-plan, it has to be illegal for total consumption to rise in the US.  The Aff may choose to implement this consumption cap by flexibly targeting specific sectors for reductions- as long as it is illegal for the total to rise above present levels.

 

C.             Reasons to Prefer

1.              Ground- they allow Affs to infringe on the core ground of “consumption good” by intentionally arguing their plan is offset via the rebound effect in other sectors.  They dodge business confidence links by saying they target a non-symbolic industry.  Core ground is key to fairness.

2.              De-limits without core ground- they could target any sector, product, State, or fossil fuel.  Limits are key to preparation, fairness, and education.

3.              Substantially is a poor check- we defy them to come up with a topic where this has not been the case.

 

D.             Voting Issue- for fairness, preparation, and education

 

Extra-T-   Aff can’t prescribe alternate remedies.

 

A.             Interpretation-  Affs can only require reduction in fossil fuels, and then defend post-plan which replacement emerges.  Fiated replacements go beyond the scope of the topic.

 

First- fiated replacements circumvent the market- meaning it’s not energy policy.

 

Gregg ’03 (US Senator Judd Gregg of New Hampshire- ENERGY POLICY ACT OF 2003- CONFERENCE REPORT- Nov 20th- http://gregg.senate.gov/statements/sp112003.pdf)

“We have essentially picked a winner, ethanol, and we have said…because it was too heavily subsidized.”

 

Second, they’re a program- not a policy.

 

Daniel Moynihan, former HEW Secretary and NY Senator, 1970 (The Public Interest, Summer, p. 90-91)

“Well, countless things went wrong…respond to the system in its entirety.”

 

B.             They violate- plan fiats__________

 

C.             Reasons to prefer

 

1.              Limits: They de-limit to specific products- including dozens of reactors or gas blends.  There’s hundreds of energies they could push- jacking predictability.

2.              Fairness: They rob core arguments on where the market heads after fossil fuel reductions.  And, Affs like Nano and Lunar Hydrogen push the topic to non-central advantage areas- like space colonization.

3.              Topic Two- In direct contrast to this topic, that wording had an including clause that required replacements.  That wording got smoked in the voting.

4.              Grammar- All the words after “energy policy” are functionally an adjective that describes the kind of energy policy the Aff is allowed to be.  They clearly go beyond that scope.  Grammar outweighs or else artificial limits would reign.

 

D.  It’s a voter- fairness, and other remedies make the 2NR impossible.   They’d have an incentive to skew the 2NR by forcing us to extend Extra-t args that just get us back to square one.

 

 

Capitalism Critique

 

ATTEMPTS TO REMEDY SPECIFIC FORMS OF OPPRESSION NATURALIZE EXPERIENCE AS A PRE-REQUISITE FOR ACTIVISM AND PERPETUATES ISOLATED, MOLECULAR POLITICS OBSCURING THE COMMONALITY OF

CAPITALIST EXPLOITATION

Ebert 96

(Theresa L. -- Assoc Prof Engllsh at SUNY, Albany, Ludic Feminism andAfter, p.118-9)

Post-al politics displaces class consciousness into identity politics… …in the name of respect for the other.

 

THE AFF’S DEMAND FOR REFORM OF ECOLOGICAL DESTRUCTION MYSTIFIES THE REAL NATURE OF CAPITALISM AS THE BASIS FOR SYSTEM-WIDE EXPLOITATION — ATTEMPT CREATE PIECEMEAL CHANGE WILL BE ROLLED BACK THE BE EVER EXPANDING POOL OF CAPITAL WHICH NECESSITATES DESTRUCTION

Kovel ‘02

(Joel, Professor Social Studies @ Bard College, The Enemy of Nature: The End of Capitalism or the End of the World?)

The value-term that subsumes everything into the spell of capital… …species along with numberless others.

 

LIBERAL TOLERANCE IS ULTIMATELY FUTILE AGAINST THE BACKDROP OF GLOBAL CAPITALISM AND IS VIOLENTLY RE-APPROPRIATED IN THE FORM OF AGGRESSIVE FUNDAMENTALISM - WE MUST CREATE A UNIVERSAL OPPOSITION TO CAPITALISM WHICH BREAKS THE TREND OF PARTICULARITY AND CAN UNDERMINE CAPITALIST GLOBALIZATION

Zizek 99

(Slavoj, Prof Sociology @ U Ljubljana, The Ticklish Subject, p. 208-11)

This is politics proper in the moment in which a particular demand… …the Roman global empire.

 

PARTICULAR DEMANDS AGAINST OPPRESSIVE STATE PRACTICES ARE REVOLUTION WITHOUT A REVOLUTION - SINGLE-ISSUE POLITICAL ORGANIZATION LACKS CONCRETE UNIVERSALITY, ALLOWING IT TO

BE ABSORBED AND REINFORCE CAPITALIST FORCES WITHOUT LEVERAGING RADICAL CHANGE

Zizek ‘02

(Slavoj, Prof Socio(ogy @ U Ljubljiana and Marxian Hack, Revolution At The Gates, p. 296-302)

So the struggle ahead has no guaranteed outcome… as we usually put it, feasible.

 

CAPITALISM IS A RUTHLESS SYSTEM OF ECONOMIC EXPANSION — IT INSTRUMENTALIZES THE GAINS OF THE AFFIRMATIVE AND MAKES RACISM, SEXISM, MILITARISM, ENVIRONMENTAL DESTRUCTION AND EVENTUALLY PLANETARY EXTINCTION INEVITABLE

Dyer-Witheford ‘99

(Nick, Professor — University of Western Ontario, Cyber-Marx p. 9-12)

The result of this critique has been the increasing… …could be part of the solution.

 

WE ADVOCATE A UNIVERSAL OPPOSITION TO CAPITALISM -- GROUNDING POLITICAL RESISTANCE IN UNIVERSALITY AND DEMANDING WHAT IS CURRENTLY SEENS AS IMPOSSIBLE REFUSES LIBERAL REFORMIST BLACKMAIL AND OPENS UP THE POSSIBILITY FOR ALTERNATIVES TO CAPITALISM TO EMERGE

Zizek ‘00

(Slavoj, Senior Researcher Institute Social Studies @ Ljubljiana, Contingency, Hegemony, Universality, p. 325-6)

Today, however, the relationship between the couple knave-fool and the political opposition… …bleeding heart liberals as Linksfaschismus so be it.  

 

Spending Disad Shell

A. Deficits and Spending set to decrease now- Bush holding the line

John Snow, US Treasury Secretary, FDCH, 9-20-04

 

 

So the first thing you have to do, going back to my earlier comment...

...It will be well below that national average.

 

 

B. Plan breaks fiscal discipline- compliance of environmental regulations extremely expensive

Mark Cohen, Owen Graduate School of Management, Vanderbilt, Monitoring and Enforcement of Environmental Policy, 1998 www.worldbank.org/nipr/work_paper/cohen/cohen.pdf

 

 

Thus far, I have assumed that if the enforcement agency detects a violation...

...monitoring to ensure that a remedial cleanup or compliance program has taken place.

 

 

C. Failure to hold the line on spending ensures deficits destroy the U.S. economy

Norman Ornstein, Resident Scholar/AEI, Roll Call, 7-7-04

 

 

Today's budget deficit is 4.2 percent of our GDP. That's a large number but not an alarming number...

...Cut it all out and we still have staggering obligations and huge future deficits.

 

 

D. Economic Decline Causes Nuclear War

Walter Russell Mead, Senior Fellow @ Council Foreign Relations, Foreign Policy, 4-1-04

 

 

Similarly, in the last 60 years...

...economic interdependence runs deeper now; as a result, the "inevitable" U.S.-Chinese conflict is less likely to occur.

Most common answers to warming advantages

 

Satellites disprove warming independently verified and peer reviewed

 

Christy 1997 (John R., climate expert, “Evidence from the Satellite Record”, in. Global Warming: The science and the politics, ed. Jones, Fraser Inst.,  http://oldfraser.lexi.net/publications/books/g_warming/)

 

global temperatures based on satellite observations

 

 

Surface temperature data is flawed — heat island effect accounts for warming

yet another new scientific paper fmds other methodological problems in commonly accepted temperature data

 

There’s no warming — newest studies show variability is higher than we thought

 

Bradley 2003 (Robert L., pres. Inst. For Energy Research, PhD Pol. Econ Int’l

College, Climate Alarmism Reconsidered) pg 50-1

 

 

CO2 is good for plants — their studies of species extinction are flawed, CO2 increases resistance and optimum temperature, increases range and checks migration

Extinction”, C02 Science,  http://www.co2science.org/reports/extinction1mr1execsum.htm)

 

The vast majority of people who have studied the subject have not understood some of the issue’s most basic elements;

 

Even extreme warming will be good for the vast majority of plants — they’ll

adapt, and C02 increases resistance

Extinction”, C02 Science, http://www.co2science.org/reports/extinction1mrlch2.htm)

 

What is the ultimate implication of the finding that plant optimum temperature rises so dramatically in response to increasing atmospheric C02 concentration?

 

Predicted warming will fall within optimal growth range for plants — warming

won’t be destructive

 

Bradley 2003 (Robert L., pres. Inst. For Energy Research, PhD Pol. Econ Int’l

College, Climate Alarmism Reconsidered)

 

The optimum atmospheric CO2 level for biosphere productivity  from enhancejlosynthesis has been estimated at between 800 and 1,200 parts per million ments indicate that plantgrowth

Michigan State BH neg

          Round 8 Kentucky

          Vs. aff: CH—Permits

          Judged by: Pomorski

               

          Case Args:

 

 

          Bush DA

Kerry kills US-Japan relations

 

Spec

We specified an agent, I don’t know why they read this.

 

          Commodification K

Permits commodify the environment

 

          Lopez Counterplan

In a relevant test case, the United States Supreme Court will issue a narrow ruling that Federal authority over the regulation of non-governmental carbon dioxide emissions commandeers the States’ legislative functions in violation of the 10th and 11th amendments. The Supreme Court will devolve authority of this narrow ruling to the State governments and United States Territories. This does not mean the federal government will not maintain authority over the federal sector. The 50 State governments and relevant territories will, through legislation, establish a cap on non-governmental carbon dioxide emissions, reducing it two-thirds of present levels by 2020, and implement the cap through auctioned tradable permits earned by reductions in fossil fuel consumption.

“to foster the notion that they could flood the world with cheap oil”

C.) Cheap oil kills transition

Michael Renneris 03 UPI feb 6

“sustained low prices would critically undermine the fledging”

Michigan State BH Neg

            Round #5  Shirley

            Vs Team: Berkeley RS

            Judge: Paul Strait

 

            Case Args:

Technological thought inevitable. Kateb 1997

Kritik of being allows capitalism to exist.

 

Waiting for a miraculous paradigm shift is a strategy that dooms us to nuclear omnicide – We must act to oppose the current state of affairs or any hope of future ontological transformation will be extinguished.   Santoni, 1985, Nuclear War: Philosophical Perspectives , p. 156-7 “To be sure….our planet’s fate.”

 

Refusing the adversarial game of demands and “protest against” opens us to alternative methods of enacting change.  Karlberg 2003, Peace & Change v28 n3 July, p. 342-3

 

Rejection of problem solving is elitist and locks in oppression of the marginalized. Jarvis 2000, International Relations and the Challenge of Postmodernism, p. 128-9

 

Ontology is a useless philosophical narrative, pursuit of which has the unfortunate consequence of condemning actual people to death. Caputo 1993, Against Ethics, p. 70

 

Their attempt to move away from calculative thought constitutes a calculative approach.  Buckley 1996, “Rationality and Reasonability in Heidegger’s and Husserl’s View of Technology” online, “the difference between these two types of thinking is one of kind”

 

Technological thought it inevitable – even global catastrophe wouldn’t be enough to knock humanity out of our love for technology. Kateb 1997 “Technology and Philosophy” Social Research Fall, Vol. 64 Iss.3

“But the question arises as to where a genuine principle”

 

Attempts to overcome the metaphysics of technological thought are metaphysical themselves – there is no alternative.   Gurciullo 2001, “The Subject of Weak Thought: There Are Only Interpretations and This Too Is An Interpretation” in Theory and Event

 

Political action is metaphysical and humanist. Zimmerman 1983, Environmental Ethics, “Proper limits for behavior cannot be established by current legal forms”

 

Attempting to reform institutions merely defers ontological questioning and reinforces control-based subjectivity. Zimmerman 1994, Contesting Earth’s Future: Radical Ecology and Postmodernity p. 109

 

Ontological activism legitimizes contest models of governance, which guarantee the inevitable failure of their project and the replication of destructive societal habits.  The adversarial game must be rejected. Karlberg 2003, Peace & Change, p. 339-41

 

 

 

 

 

            Off Case Args:

T Policy – must specify goals and mechanisms.

 

Framework

Our framework – the aff can only defend advantages based on the consequences of hypothetical enactment of their plan by the USFG. They should win if the topical plan is the best policy option presented.  The neg should win if the plan is worse than the status quo or an alternative competitive with the plan.

 

Politics

Plan alienates base, Bush must appease.

Fossil fuel reductions alienate base. Baltimore Sun 4-30-2004 “the passage of legislation to mandate that the United States”

Bush will push gay marriage ban.

“Gay Marriage” ban causes oppression – must be rejected. David Nett, :Matrimonial Discrimination: 2-24-04, online, “A Constitutional amendment encouraging discrimination”

 

 

Lopez Counter Plan

The court can make our ruling and devolve authority to the states. Mark Miller, Cleveland State Law Review, 1998, “Tenth Amendment power was reborn in New York”

            Commodification K

Permits commodify the environment

 

            Lopez Counterplan

In a relevant test case, the United States Supreme Court will issue a narrow ruling that Federal authority over the regulation of non-governmental carbon dioxide emissions commandeers the States’ legislative functions in violation of the 10th and 11th amendments. The Supreme Court will devolve authority of this narrow ruling to the State governments and United States Territories. This does not mean the federal government will not maintain authority over the federal sector. The 50 State governments and relevant territories will, through legislation, establish a cap on non-governmental carbon dioxide emissions, reducing it two-thirds of present levels by 2020, and implement the cap through auctioned tradable permits earned by reductions in fossil fuel consumption.

MSU HV Neg VS Harvard Rd 4 @ Dart RR

 

COUNTERPLAN

 

Procurement and R&D subsidies are less effective than the plan – posner judge of the US court of appeals and lecuturer at chicago law school 2k4 – Richard, catastrophe, Risk and Response, p. 159-60 – “Subsidizing research on measures to control global warming might seem more efficient than a technology-forcing tax because it would create a direct…”

 

AT: subsidies cp – Kemp, researchers at Maastricht economic research institute on innovation and technology, 11/26/99 (http://64.233.161.104/search?q=cache:jsbpCDfvwLkJ:www.few.eur.nl/few/research/ocfeb/pret/steering%2520of%2520technical%2520change2.doc+%22innovation+waiver%22&hl=en&ie=UTF-8) – “economic incentives such as taxes and subsidies provide a too weak and indirect stimulus.”

 

Tech promotion by itself fails – reducing GHG emissions requires brining tech to the market – Claussen, 6/16/04, www.pewclimate.org, “Energy efficiency, Climate Change, and our Nation’s Energy Future – “we need a policy that will draw the technologies into the marketplace.”

 

Tech advancement not sufficient – Wirth, april 97, USIA Electronic Journal, Vol 2, No. 2 – “The availability of low carbon technologies is a prerequiresite for, but not a guarantee of, the ability to reduce greenhouse gas emissions at reasonable cost.”

Reg lead to adoption of new tech – Richard and Jonathan, Reconstructing Climate Policy, pg. 57 2k3 – “the appropriate new technologies will nto be developed and adopted unless market actors, including both producers and consumers, have an incentive to demand and adopt them.”

 

Subsidies don’t solve – kemp same cite as before – “the conclusion that emerges from the different studies is that investment subsidies were only of limited effectiveness in promoting the diffusion of environmentally beneficial technologies”

 

Stricter regulations induce comparative stronger innovation .  Biz invest when forced to, increases competativeness and reduces long term costs – Adam Jaffe Prof @ Brandeis NBER 95, Journal of Economic Literature Vol XXXIII March, pp. 132 – 63 – “under stricter environmental regulations, some regulated firms will benefit competitively”

 

International Subsidies create perverse incentives that cause increased pollution – Winer, prof law duke, jan 99, yale law journal – “abatement subsidies have the crucial drawback that they involve actual payments to pollution sources to cover the costs of abatement.  Such payments generate perverse incentives for increased pollution.”

 

The CP allows the US to change Kyoto and get others on board – Paul Roberts, Harper’s Magazine, The End of Oil: A perilous new world, 2004 p. 325-326 – “a new U.S. energy policy would send a powerful message to the res o fthe players in the global energy economy.”

 

KYOTO

 

Emissions trading allows the United states to derail Kyoto by creating a parallel program – Pomeroy, Env Reporter for Reuters, 10/1/04, http://www.enn.com/ch_clim.html?id=9 – “Washington should take a lead in confronting global warming – although he also says it is too late to sign up for Kyoto.”

 

The international community will follow the US, they will agree to alt. Kyoto – Environmental News Network 11/6/00 http://www.enn.com/about_enn_main.html - “an international community concerned about climate change and pepared to convene for a conference in the Netherlands appears to be waiting for the United States, the world’s leader in carbon emissions, to come up with a plan to curb the crud.”

NEG

 

Cp text:the usfg should redirect all fossil fuel subsidies to renewable energy, shift all usSg fossil fuel investments abroad to the Global Environmental Facility, earmarked for renewable energy assistance to Developing countries, require non military federal entities to make 7.5% of their total energy purchases from renewable sources by 2010, implement a natl net metering program, enhance department of energy renewable energy research and development commitments from $500 million to $733 million, and reinstate the highest prioriy existing credits and incentives for renewable energy and energy efficiency as per the Daschle and Bingaman recommendations in the 2003 energy bill debate. The USFG should subsidize protective suits being developed by DuPont and fully fund Dupont to ensure destruction of chemical and biological weapons. All renewables will be clean, non fossil fuel based sources. All necessary funding will come from cuts in agricultural subsidies.

 

Ending US FF investments in dev countires S warming: US inv creates more emissions than china India, brazil and mexico combined Daphne Wysham 4-17-01 Institutes Policy Studies, Ascribe Newswire

 

Shifting investments abroad solves warming and renewables same cite

Bus Con

T Extra T

A Interpretation – Affs can only require reduction in fossil fuels, and then defend post-plan which replacement emerges.   Fiated replacements go beyond the scope of the topic. 

 

First – fiated replacements circumvent the market – meaning it’s not energy policy. 

Gregg ‘3 Energy Policy Act of 2003, http://gregg.senate.gov/statements/sp112003.pdf “we have essentially picked a winner, ethanol… didn’t fly because it was so heavily subsidized”

 

Second, they’re a program, not a policy Moynihan, 1970, The Public Interest, Summer, p.90-91 “countless things went wrong… Programs relate to a single part of the system; policy seeks to respond to the system in its entirety”

 

B. They violate:

 

C.  Reasons to Prefer

First – limits.  They de-limit to specific products – including dozens of reactors or gas blends.  There’s hundreds of energies they could push --  jacking predictability.

 

Second – Fairness.  They rob core arguments on where the market heads after fossil fuel reductions.  And, Affs like Nano and Lunar Hydrogen push the topic to non-central advantage areas – like space colonization.

 

Third – Topic Two.  In direct contrast to this topic, that wording had an including clause that required replacements.  That wording got smoked in the voting.

 

Fourth – Grammar.  All of the words after “energy policy” are functionally an adjective that describes the kind of energy policy the Aff is allowed to be.  They clearly go beyond that scope.  Grammar outweighs or else artificial limits would reign. 

 

D.  It’s a voter – fairness, and other remedies make the 2NR impossible.   They’d have an inventive to skew the 2NR by forcing us to extend Extra-T args that just get us back to square one.

 

T Require = mandatory

Total consumption = term of art

Illegal for total to increase

Offsets

T- Generation

Generation – terminal plan flaw – the plan requires “generation” change, not “consumption”

 

Generation not equal consumption – Michigan court case Ferry ‘2 The Harvard Environmental Law Review “Pennsylvania’s statute provides…from the customer through a competitive transition charge”

 

No guidance what is sign reduction of consumption in context of generation

Net metering proves our distinction Ferry ‘2 “Net metering allows consumers with small generating facilities… and the meter turns backwards”

 

Perm the procurement CP

Delays into the market

Grammar key – VI

CP

TEXT: The United States Federal Government should establish production tax credits for the construction of Gas Turbine-Modular Helium Reactors to be made available and annually increased until nuclear power constitutes at least fifty percent of non-governmental electricity generation.  The United States Federal Government should establish a depreciation period for capital investment in nuclear power plants of seven years.  The United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission should adopt the following reforms (as cited in or Kovan evidence): (1) Design certification for gas turbine-modular helium reactors; (2) early site permits and (3) combined construction permits and operating licences.  We get to clarify intent.

 

NRC adopt different standards for citing/requirements

Solves NIMBY Kovan ‘3 “The good news is that industry has done a good job of gaining… future nuclear plants”

COUNTERPLAN

Procurement and R&D subsidies are less effective than the plan - posner judge of the US court of appeals and lecuturer at chicago law school 2k4 - Richard, catastrophe, Risk and Response, p. 159-60 - "Subsidizing research on measures to control global warming might seem more efficient than a technology-forcing tax because it would create a direct..."

AT: subsidies cp - Kemp, researchers at Maastricht economic research institute on innovation and technology, 11/26/99 (http://64.233.161.104/search?q=cache:jsbpCDfvwLkJ:www.few.eur.nl/few/research/ocfeb/pret/steering%2520of%2520technical%2520change2.doc+%22innovation+waiver%22&hl=en&ie=UTF-8) - "economic incentives such as taxes and subsidies provide a too weak and indirect stimulus."

Tech promotion by itself fails - reducing GHG emissions requires brining tech to the market - Claussen, 6/16/04, www.pewclimate.org, "Energy efficiency, Climate Change, and our Nation's Energy Future - "we need a policy that will draw the technologies into the marketplace."

Tech advancement not sufficient - Wirth, april 97, USIA Electronic Journal, Vol 2, No. 2 - "The availability of low carbon technologies is a prerequiresite for, but not a guarantee of, the ability to reduce greenhouse gas emissions at reasonable cost."
Reg lead to adoption of new tech - Richard and Jonathan, Reconstructing Climate Policy, pg. 57 2k3 - "the appropriate new technologies will nto be developed and adopted unless market actors, including both producers and consumers, have an incentive to demand and adopt them."

Subsidies don't solve - kemp same cite as before - "the conclusion that emerges from the different studies is that investment subsidies were only of limited effectiveness in promoting the diffusion of environmentally beneficial technologies"

Stricter regulations induce comparative stronger innovation . Biz invest when forced to, increases competativeness and reduces long term costs - Adam Jaffe Prof @ Brandeis NBER 95, Journal of Economic Literature Vol XXXIII March, pp. 132 - 63 - "under stricter environmental regulations, some regulated firms will benefit competitively"

International Subsidies create perverse incentives that cause increased pollution - Winer, prof law duke, jan 99, yale law journal - "abatement subsidies have the crucial drawback that they involve actual payments to pollution sources to cover the costs of abatement. Such payments generate perverse incentives for increased pollution."

The CP allows the US to change Kyoto and get others on board - Paul Roberts, Harper's Magazine, The End of Oil: A perilous new world, 2004 p. 325-326 - "a new U.S. energy policy would send a powerful message to the res o fthe players in the global energy economy."

KYOTO

Emissions trading allows the United states to derail Kyoto by creating a parallel program - Pomeroy, Env Reporter for Reuters, 10/1/04, http://www.enn.com/ch_clim.html?id=9 - "Washington should take a lead in confronting global warming - although he also says it is too late to sign up for Kyoto."

The international community will follow the US, they will agree to alt. Kyoto - Environmental News Network 11/6/00 http://www.enn.com/about_enn_main.html - "an international community concerned about climate change and pepared to convene for a conference in the Netherlands appears to be waiting for the United States, the world's leader in carbon emissions, to come up with a plan to curb the crud."

A global climate regime incrementally growin gout of dom policy will compete w/ Kyoto - Bodansky prof Law Washington, Fall 2001 National Interest - "the United States should decide what it is willing to do domestically, and then examine the ways that itnenrnational process can help support these efforts."

Bush is hell bent against Kyoto - Bulletin's Frontrunner, June 12, 2001 - "Bush made clear today that he had no intention of revrsing his opposition to a global warming accord supported by the European leaders he will meet with this week."

NEG

Cp text:the usfg should redirect all fossil fuel subsidies to renewable energy, shift all usSg fossil fuel investments abroad to the Global Environmental Facility, earmarked for renewable energy assistance to Developing countries, require non military federal entities to make 7.5% of their total energy purchases from renewable sources by 2010, implement a natl net metering program, enhance department of energy renewable energy research and development commitments from $500 million to $733 million, and reinstate the highest prioriy existing credits and incentives for renewable energy and energy efficiency as per the Daschle and Bingaman recommendations in the 2003 energy bill debate. The USFG should subsidize protective suits being developed by DuPont and fully fund Dupont to ensure destruction of chemical and biological weapons. All renewables will be clean, non fossil fuel based sources. All necessary funding will come from cuts in agricultural subsidies.

Ending US FF investments in dev countires S warming: US inv creates more emissions than china India, brazil and mexico combined Daphne Wysham 4-17-01 Institutes Policy Studies, Ascribe Newswire

Bus Con
Bus con - decline in BC = full econ spiral LAT 9/8/4 "convincingly rebounded from the summer's soft patch... not a lot of ammunition to fight back with"

T Extra T
A Interpretation - Affs can only require reduction in fossil fuels, and then defend post-plan which replacement emerges. Fiated replacements go beyond the scope of the topic.

First - fiated replacements circumvent the market - meaning it's not energy policy.
Gregg '3 Energy Policy Act of 2003, http://gregg.senate.gov/statements/sp112003.pdf "we have essentially picked a winner, ethanol... didn't fly because it was so heavily subsidized"

Second, they're a program, not a policy Moynihan, 1970, The Public Interest, Summer, p.90-91 "countless things went wrong... Programs relate to a single part of the system; policy seeks to respond to the system in its entirety"

B. They violate:

C. Reasons to Prefer
First - limits. They de-limit to specific products - including dozens of reactors or gas blends. There's hundreds of energies they could push -- jacking predictability.

Second - Fairness. They rob core arguments on where the market heads after fossil fuel reductions. And, Affs like Nano and Lunar Hydrogen push the topic to non-central advantage areas - like space colonization.

Third - Topic Two. In direct contrast to this topic, that wording had an including clause that required replacements. That wording got smoked in the voting.

Fourth - Grammar. All of the words after "energy policy" are functionally an adjective that describes the kind of energy policy the Aff is allowed to be. They clearly go beyond that scope. Grammar outweighs or else artificial limits would reign.

D. It's a voter - fairness, and other remedies make the 2NR impossible. They'd have an inventive to skew the 2NR by forcing us to extend Extra-T args that just get us back to square one.

T Require = mandatory
Total consumption = term of art
Illegal for total to increase
Offsets

T- Generation
Generation - terminal plan flaw - the plan requires "generation" change, not "consumption"

Generation not equal consumption - Michigan court case Ferry '2 The Harvard Environmental Law Review "Pennsylvania's statute provides...from the customer through a competitive transition charge"

No guidance what is sign reduction of consumption in context of generation
Net metering proves our distinction Ferry '2 "Net metering allows consumers with small generating facilities... and the meter turns backwards"

Perm the procurement CP
Delays into the market

CP
TEXT: The United States Federal Government should establish production tax credits for the construction of Gas Turbine-Modular Helium Reactors to be made available and annually increased until nuclear power constitutes at least fifty percent of non-governmental electricity generation. The United States Federal Government should establish a depreciation period for capital investment in nuclear power plants of seven years. The United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission should adopt the following reforms (as cited in or Kovan evidence): (1) Design certification for gas turbine-modular helium reactors; (2) early site permits and (3) combined construction permits and operating licences. We get to clarify intent.

NRC adopt different standards for citing/requirements

NRC reforms solve - Kovan '3 Nuclear News Jan "Noting that the NRC should encourage.... In the process as feasible"
Solves NIMBY Kovan '3 "The good news is that industry has done a good job of gaining... future nuclear plants"

            Case Args:

 

Fossil fuel based agrochemicals including pesticides and fertilizers are increasing in usage in the US

Clive Edwards and David Pimentel 2002 (“The Future of Human Populations: Energy, Food, and Water Availability in the Twenty-First Century” – Just Ecological Integrity: The Ethics of Maintaining Planetary Life edited by Miller and Westra) p. 123

There were global increases in food production of up to 3 percent annually in the last century, while increases in human population

 

Pesticides are inevitable

Robert F. Norris 2003 – Concepts in Integrated Pest Management – p. 518

The use of pesticides will continue, but it is anticipated that the efficiency of the products

 

Real world evidence is confirming beneficial effect of CO2

Roger Gifford August 2004 – New Phytologist 163:221 p. 224

In summary, as with global warming, there are substantial issues yet to be addressed

 

There are many inherent fundamental limitations on GCMs – should not base policy on them

David Legates 5/16/2002 – Limitations on Climate Models as Predictors of Climate Change – http://www.ncpa.org/pub/ba/ba396/

World leaders are making critical decisions based upon predictions of General Circulation Models

 

Solar force – the sun – is the real cause of recent warming

S. Baliunas and W. Soon 2000 – “Increasing Carbon Dioxide and Global Climate Change” – www.marshall.org

Natural factors of climate change: The Sun – one reasons for the exaggerated forecasts of the computer scenarios may rest in incomplete knowledge of natural climate variations

 

Surface measurements are inaccurate   - satellite data is more accurate and shows no warming

The Heartland Institute 2/14/2002 – “What the Global Warming Treaty Would Do to You,  Your Job, and Your Country” – http://www.heartland.org/studies/ieguide.htm

The most reliable temperature data show no global warming trend

 

Even if diseases increase it wouldn’t lead to an epidemic

Sherwood Idso, November 2003 – Enhanced or Impaired? Human Health in a CO2-Enriched Warmer World

Kuhn et al. additionally note that the number of secondary malaria cases

 

Termites emit methan

Alexander Gillespie 2003 (“The Problem of Methane in International Law” – Review of European Community & International Environmental Law 12 (3) 321-328

Slightly more than half (probably somewhere between 60% and 80%) of current methane emissions are anthropogenic

Text: The USFG should establish an environmental competition statute that requires fossil fuel companies to pay the costs that competitors incur in realizing lower projected carbon dioxide emissions levels, plus a substantial premium relating to the relative difference in emissions levels of the firms in question.  The premium levels will be adjusted as necessary to ensure a minimum of (whatever the cap of the plan is).

CP 1NC

Text – The United States Federal Government should establish an energy policy requiring an 80% phase-out of non-governmental fossil fuel consumption in the following practices in the United States by no later than 2012 – the operation of agricultural machinery, food transportation by road, air or water, and pesticides and pertilizers.  The plan will be carried out by the United States Department of Agriculture.  We get to clarify intent.

 

Competition – CP precludes the possibility of the plan restricting the use of fossil fuels in railroads, which is the link to all of our disads.  The plan will necessarily have an effect on railroads – they ship 40 percent of all agriculture.   Hamberger FNS 3-2-99 “Bulk commodities… transload centers on a competing railroad”

 

Solvency – Our CP solves the whole case – the elimination of FF use in pesticides and fertilizers would

eliminate industrial ag all by itself.   Also, efficient distribution of crops is essential to reducing hunger.  Only our CP can accomplish this.  Van Der Gaag 2K www.newint.org/issue323/keynote.htm “The corporations defend their position by saying…guardians of the land”

 

2NC Diesal Turn

  1. fuel price spikes (a) Diesal fuel prices decreasing – Traffic World 12/7/98 “diesal fuel prices have been trending lower…cents per gallon in the Midwest” (b) shift to biodiesel would substantially increase RR costs – Automotive industries 5/1/3 “the fuel is not readily available… biodiesel would be extremely costly” (C) increasing fuel prices kills railroads Traffic World 12/7/98 “contract diesel prices paid by railroads…more harm than good”
  2. Biodieels doesn’t work in locomotives and would cause a massive shut-down in winter – AgWeek 01 (4-30) “limited research has been conducted into using biodiesel blends…want to take a look at first”

R&D CP

 

CP TEXT: The United States federal government will establish a program of renewable energy research and development that includes the following:

n        tax incentives and credits for renewable energy development

n        substantial increase in basic science research subsidies

n        arrangement of credit and temporary financial guarantees to renewable energy developers

n        engagement of the private sector in public/private renewable energy research and commercialization initiatives, including laboratory/university/industry cooperation.

 

The Department of Energy will implement these programs. Overall responsibility shall be granted to a single person reporting directly to the Secretary of Energy. Department of Energy staff skills should be strengthened by training and rotating external staff. These programs should undergo external private peer review every two years. The Energy Analysis program will be refunded at $6 million per year.

 

The United States federal government will propose parallel and cooperative multilateral research and development initiatives with interested countries. Each country’s contribution will be contingent on the total level of participation.

Funding will be supplied by redirecting fossil fuel subsidies. We’ll clarify.

 

CP creates a private sector scramble towards renewable development – even a few successes will snowball throughout the global economy

Marco Verweij, Apr 3, www.mpprdg.mpg.de/workshop/MarcoVerweij.pdf

“The literature on innovation… …cost beneficial immediately.”

 

Other countries will participate in collaborate R&D – better way to access LDC participation than the plan

Scott Barrett, Nov 2k1, www.aei.brookings.org/policy/page.php?id=21

“The knowledge obtained from… …emissions more cheaply.”

 

 

 

 

R&D solves better than binding caps – ensures a more stable transition

Jeffrey Rachlinski, U. Ill L Rev 299, 2000

“The best source of a remedy… …climatologists are mistaken.”

 

This solves Europe adv – R&D best restores US climate leadership

Thomas Shelling, May/June 2002. Foreign Affairs.
”Eventually, to bring in… seriousness about global warming.”

 

 

 

SOLVENCY

 

Permits undermine competitive impulses toward innovation – they lock in the squo and create perverse incentives against innovation

Time Jenkins et. Al, June 2001. www.foe.co.uk/resources/consultation_responses/industrial_use_energy_foe.html#Conclusion

“To be a workable… …stressed by ACBE.”

 

Monopoly turn – Dominant firms will refuse to sell permits to new sources – creates a significant barrier to entry and undermines new firm creation

Julia Reinaud, 2003, www.iea.org/dbtw-wpd/texbase/papers/2003/cop9invdec.pdf

“Under “exclusionary manipulation”…. …Union for example).”

 

Permit scheme causes incentive NOT to trade – companies won’t sell renwables because diffusion of tech will decrease value of permits

Barbara Rippel, 11/25/97, www.consumeralert.org/pubs/Study/ets.htm

“Advocates of emissions taxes… …the ton of emissions.”

 

Permits decrease incentive for future pollution reduction – encourage polluters to resist future reduction in order to hoard permit and generate revenue

David Driesen, 2003, “Economic Dynamics of Environmental Law” p 63

“Increased reliance on emissions.. …have to encourage innovation.”

Northwestern BM neg vs Harvard @ Dart RR

 

 

 

Northwestern Neg

 

  1. Topical cases must regulate the burning of fossil fuels into energy

We have definitional support

Consumption means the direct and immediate destruction of an economic good

Words and Phrases 1960

(vol. 9, consult-contriving, p.22)

“Consumption is the use of economic goods resulting in the dimiution or destruction of their utilities.”

 

 

This has been held too be the best statutory definition of consumption in the context of fuel

Fisher, Judge- Supreme court  of IL. 1942

(Spetember 21, 380 Ill. 226, 241 LN.)

 

Emphasis is placed upon the meaning of the word “consumption” ass used in the statute and particularly as appied to theose particles of building material such as sand, gravel and cement, whose separate iodentity destroyed in the process which the contractor applies.

 

  1. Production is NOT consumption- the consensus of the permits literature supports our distinction
  2. Dr;. Frances Sussman, June 2004, www.ccap.org/pdf/emissioncaps.pdf

 

A key decision affecting coverage of affiliated enterprises will be whether to fucos on upstream emitters (eg operations at or near the point of fossel fuel generation) or downstream emitters…

 

They don’t even set a cap on the physical availablility of fossil fuels in the US, their plan text only sets up a production cap, this means that after the plan, we couldjust shift to the consumption of fossil fuel imports

Tim Hargrave March 1998 www.ccap.org/pdf/upstpub.pdf

 

The accounting treatment, which is consistent with that established by the Intergovernmental panel on climate change, could lead to international oil market distortions.

 

Vote Negative

1-        Limits- the aff allows for intervention anywhere in to the fuel cycle, they allow for cases like ban ANWR drilling, ban oil refineries, or even ban cars, our interpretation foces the aff to directly regulate consumption

 

  1. Ground- our core disads and cps stem off tof regulations on consumption- they rob us of the upstream CP and core links to demand destruction and regulations on UTILITIES, these arguments are crucial and god-given negative ground on this topic.

 

1NC Tort Reform

  1. Tort reform will pass, rising health care costs and Bush effort will get it through
  2. Donald Lambro, 1/10 Washington times

 

Republicans start this session with a beefed up majority in the senate, which democratic filibusters have often turned into a graveyard.

 

 

Upstream permits uniquely spur congressional backlash-makes permits carry the political baggage of an energy tax- a gybrid system avoids the link

Masurec, June 2002  www.ppionline.org/documents/co2/0602.pdf

For all its theoretical advantages, an   upstream system for controlling carbon and other greenhouse gas emissions has yet to pass the rest of political feasibility. 

 

  1. Uniqueness
  2. B- Plank kills political capital
  3. 2. Political capital is crucial to tort reform passage, it’ll be tough fight but Bush will persevert UPI1 1/15

 

The house of rep. has passed medical tort reform before only to see it languish in the senate.  Bush, following his re-election, boasted of the political capital….

 

  1. Tort reform is crucial to stable smallpox vaccine supply- failure destroys US disease research base

 

Miller 11/03/04 (CNNFN)

Miller:  all right, let’s take the flue vaccine, and I’m not going to discuss theoverall, because I don’t really have an opinion as to what’t in his mind.   But I think that he certainly thinks….

 

 

Strong smallpox vaccination base is crucial to prevent an attack

Erwald, 12/17/01

www.ph.ucly.edu/epi/bioter/riskypolicysmallpoxvac.html

Perhaps most important, voluntary vaccination could prevent a smallpox attack from occurring. 

 

A Smallpox attack would destroy the entire United States and trigger massive waves of fatalities

Veeeronnique de Rugy and Charles Pena, CATP 4/18/02

www.cato.org/pubs/pas/pa434.pdf

 

The smallpox threat a bioterrorist attack could come in one (or more) of many forms (plague, smallpox, or anthrax, for example)…

 

Impact is Extinction-

Seinbruner, Brookings 12/22/1997 (Foreign Policy)

That deceptively simple observation has immense implications.  The use of a manufactured weapon is a singular event. 

 

 

 

 

 

AT:  Have to monitor more entities

  1. This assumes a purely downstream approach, the CP only regulates utilities and big industrial boilers downstream, at this point the downstream approach is just as verifiable and stimulates more efficient price signals, extend Mazurek and Hargrave

 

 

  1. your effieciency impact is nebulous and irrelevant, even authors who concede the efficiency difference note that it makes little difference in the long run

CCAP June 1999 www.field.org.uk/PDF4%20incidence.pdf

There two pure solutions are both higly unlikely, of course.  Ultimately, from an efficiency perspective….

 

 

  1. Other existing regulations will dampen efficiency benefits of upstream permits

CCAP same

The efficiency benefits associated with comprehensive coverage in an upstream system would be reduced by existing PAM’s

 

  1. You can’t quantify your shitty efficiency impacts, they’re offset by reductions in market power and not enough to significantly impact permit regime

Festa, April 1998

www.ccap.org/pdf/wwwdown.pdf

 

In any system, it is important that the number of entities and associated amount of data be limited so that the administrative burden and the accounting system are manageable but plentiful enough so that there is menaningful trading. 

 

Northwestern CP

 

1NC

Hybrid system solves better than the case – minimizes administrative costs and sends a more effective signal in favor of innovation Mazurek June 2002 www,ppionline.org/documents.co2_0602.pdf “a purely upstream approach may cost less and control more…. Unregulated sources”

 

CP closes down loopholes and prevents permit evasion – the paper trail requirement is feasible CCAP 99 www.field.org.uk/PDF/4%20Incidence.pdf “From an efficiency standpoint… and energy information”

 

CP prevents resale or fuel hiding CCAP same as above “Strategic Behaviour…. Not just that combusted”

 

Paper trail solves the wholesaler loophole without imposing large transaction costs

(a)      Fuel producers would develop accounting systems – these would only need audited aggregate data to solve

(b)      Allowance surrender is infrequent, giving firms time to adapt to audits Hargrave June 2K www.ccap.org/pdf/Hybrid1.PDF “A third method would have the government…. Found out of compliance”

 

The CP spurs greater innovation in the electricity sector – utilities respond more effectively to direct regulation than to price signals Hargrave 2K “An earlier paper in this series…. A downstream model”

 

2NC CP Solves Better

  1. Prices signaling – utilities and big industry respond better to direct regulation
  2. Consumer Blash
    1. CP is crucial to avoid it – shields consumers from the perception of rising fuel prices Cooler Heads Coalition 5/28/3 www.globalwarming.org/article.php?uid=513 “the authors found that a downstream program… Reduction efforts”
    2. The impact is psychological backlash – the plan breaks down the motivation for compliance Alter 2K www1.oecd.org/puma/refref/pubs/Compliance/pdf “A series of studies of the effects… abandoning selfregulation”
    3. Only positive behavioural change can solve the case – otherwise noncompliance is inev Ryan 97 www.neopolitique.org/Np2000/Pages/Essays/Articles/antitrust.htm “Braybrooke  pointed out that the desires…economically responsible”
  3. Permutation confuses the regulatory process – providing multiple sources of regulatory codes destroys efficiency and causes industry frustration Collier June 2K www.selfregulation.gov.au/publications/TaskForceOnIndustrySelf-Regulation/DraftReport/report.pdf “the great majority of cases the nature of any…. Delving into different products and services”
  4. Hybrid approach establishes more predicatble and precise market signals Pholobert and Reinaud June 2K4 www.iea.org/dbtw-wpd/textbase/papers/2002/trading.pdf “a hybrid approach to greenhouse gas emissions… allocation for the upstream segment”
  5. Hybrid system solves – motivates widespread GHG abatement Zhang 98 www.chinaenvironment.net/papers/zhangzhongxiang2.html “national trading systems could be…. Content such as natural gas”

AT: Can’t track fuel

 

Tax accounting proves it is feasible – already segregate by destination Festa 98 www.ccap.org/pdf/wwwdown.pdf “the following conditions must be met…. Used in the transportation sector”

 

Gas distributors have a clear understanding of fuel destination Harvrave 2K “Moving the allowance requirement downstream to gas distributors would mean…. In the trading system”

 

The CP regulates coal use downstream – little coal used for non-industrial purposes Hargrave 2K “Accounting for coal in a hybrid system would be…. Will be captured downstream”

            Counterplan

Text: the usfg will encourage voluntary measures to lay the domestic groundwork for an emissions trading system.  These measures will include technical assistance for the development of self-regulatory regimes, public recognition of emissions cuts, and the provision of credits against a future cap and trade system.  The usfg will enter into negotiations with China proposing a bilateral cap-and-trade regime in which the total cap on non-governmental carbon dioxide emissions will be two-thirds of present United States levels, plus China’s business-as-usual projected emissions, by 2020.  American compliance with this regime will be conditioned upon Chinese reciprocation.  Other non-Annex I countries will be invited to join negotiations and integrate into this bilateral regime.  The United States federal government will provide necessary technical assistance for Chinese implementation.

 

China will say yes and will respond with robust R&D effort—desire to sell permits to the US will guarantee full-scale participation.

Carlo Carraro and Barbara Buchner, November 2003 http://www.feem.it/NR/rdonlyres/EE4755B4-5089-4EAA-AB66-74DEE1FC665A963/10104.pdf

Unilat reductions in ff consumption encourages LCD free-riding—the plan collapses US leverage and removes any incentive for China to join an emissions control regime.

Hakan Nordstrom and Scott Vaughn, 1999 http://www.wto.org/english/res_e/booksp_e/environment_e.pdf

“While a lot…co2 in the atmosphere”

 

Presence of a domestic cap would collapse the bilateral trading regime—exacerbates carbon leakage.  There would be no demand for Chinese permits

Scott Barrett, 1998 (Oxford Review of Economic Policy, Vol 14, No 4)

“A further problem…are met domestically”

 

Cp solves delay args and ensures a smooth transition into a regime with China

Jonathan Weiner and Richard Stewart, 2003 Restructuring Climate Policy

http://www.aei.org/publications/bookID.211/book_detail.asp

“We propose a…participants or otherwise.”

“Thus, Surrey challenges…point of loss.”

Condition on China CP

The USFG will encourage voluntary measures to law the domestic groundwork for an emissions trading system. These measures will include technical assistance for the development of self regulatory regimes, public recognition of emissions cuts, and the provision of credits against a future cap and trade system. The United States federal government will enter into negotiations with China, proposing a bilateral cap and trade regime in the which the total cap on non governmental upstream fossil fuel consumption

(insert plan)

A maximum of 80% of the United States’ projected C02 emissions within 15 years, and a maximum of 55% of United States projected CO2 emissions within 45 years, using 1990 levels as a baseline, in both cases adding China’s projected business-as-usual CO2 emissions.

American compliance with this regime will be conditioned upon Chinese reciprocation. Other non Annex I countries will be invited to join negotiations and integrate into this bilateral regime. The USFG will provide necessary technical assistance for Chinese implementation.

 

China will say yes and respond with robust R and D

Carraro and buchner, November 2003

Northwestern BM neg

            Round #1 Shirley Classic

            Vs. Kansas BW

            Judged by: Patel, Nirav

            Kritik X: - Eco-Security/Externalization K Calls for individuals to utilize “Ethic of Environmental Connectivity” <Casebook>
