Northwestern BM Pre Shirley

 

T-DELAY ILLEGIT

 

A. Topical cases must immediately mandate a reduction in consumption---cannot specify a time-frame

We have definitional support

Requiring = present participle

Margaret Benner, 2k3, wwwnew.towson.edu/ows/verbs.htm “four suffixes”

 

This mandates present action

American Heritage Dictionary, 2000, www.bartleby.com/61/88/P0538800.html “a participle expressing”

 

Consumption refers to PRESENT use

Soled, 1996, 15 Va. Tax Rev. 447, l/n, “central to the definition of consumption”

 

INCENTIVES NOT TOPICAL

 

We have definitional support---financial penalties for emissions are NOT requirements---it gives industry legal discretion over compliance---the fact that it INDIRECTLY encourages emissions cuts means that it is not a legal requirement

Justice Blackmun, 6/24/92 (505 U.S. 504,at 536, l/n)

“plurality flatly states”

 

2.  Legal precision is more important than contextual accuracy---as policy-makers, we must strive to uphold precise definitions as determined by legal code---allowing for 'common usage' is infinitely regressive and destroys communicative stability

Bradley Shannon, law at University of Idaho, January 2002 (Washington Law Review, 77 Wash. L. Rev. 65)

“whenever the possibility”

 

Our definition is specific to environmental law---EPA has held that fines and payments are not emissions requirements

Sherrie Flynn, San Joaquin Agricultural Law Review, 2003 (1 S.J. Agri. L. Rev. 173)

 

Environmental context key

Marie Adornetto Monahan, law at John Marshall Law Review, Summer 2003 (Southern Illinois University Law Journal, 27 S. Ill. U. L. J. 687)

“evidence of the context”

 

5. Historical legislative wording proves---financial penalties are not considered regulatory requirements

Robert Waltz, Southeastern Environmental Law Journal, Fall 2002 (11 Southeastern Envtl. L.J. 109)

“damage award”

 

T-KYOTO

 

(A). Our Interpretation: A “substantial reduction” must meet or exceed Kyoto targets, i.e. a 30% reduction in fossil fuel consumption

 

Substantial” must be defined contextually

Words and Phrases 1960

(Vol. 40, State – Subway, p. 759)

 

In the area of energy policy, Kyoto levels represent a “substantial reduction in consumption of fossil fuels”

Rabkin, Dept of Government – Cornell, 1997

(http://www.apec.org.au/docs/rabkin.pdf)

Kyoto calls for a 30% reduction in consumption of fossil fuels

Miller, President – Center for Energy and Economic Development, 1998

(http://www.ceednet.org/resources/pdf/981270.pdf)

 

C. Reasons to prefer

 

Predictability – Other definitions of substantial are uncertain; Kyoto is the only game in town.

Hovi, Research Council of Norway, 2003

(Global Environmental Politics, November, LN)

Education – Kyoto targets drive global energy policymaking; they are the gold standard for domestic policies to reduce fossil fuel consumption

Power Engineering International 12/1/03 LN 

Ground---30% cut is crucial to economy and politics disads---the aff interpretation allows for a 0.2% cut which would avoid all our disads

 

CENTRALIZATION K

 

Use of centralized bureaucracy undermines the capacity for empathetic and human relationships---result is a complete annihilation of ethics---culminates in extinction. Alternative is to resist the impulse towards centralization and instead affirm localized and human interactions.

Almost all the cards come from John Papworth, Small is Powerful, 1995.

 

Other cites:

Alt solves the environment better

Karl Hess, senior environmental fellow at CATO, December 1994 (http://www.libertyhaven.com/politicsandcurrentevents/environmentalismorconservation/closinggreen.shtml)

AT PERM

Ludwig Von Mises, distinguished professor of the Austrian School of Economics, 1996 (Human Action: a Treatise on Economics, http://www.econlib.org/library/Mises/HmA/msHmAtoc.html)

“socially undesirable”

 

AT PRAG

Harry Browne, Libertarian presidential candidate and executive director of public policy at American Liberty Foundation and editor of Liberty Magazine, March 2003 (Why Government Doesn’t Work, p. 19-20)

 

 

ECO REPS K

 

A. Ecological crisis unites people---generates possibility for empathy and community

Bruce Miller, 1990, www.joe.org/joe/1990winter/f1.html “threat of global environmental change”

 

B. Specific representations of danger erects a blockade between people and their connection to this universal empathy---images of danger establish the separations that psychologically necessitate a separation from the other

Howard Stein, “Days of Awe,” Journal for the Psychoanalysis of Culture and Society, 8.2, 2003, p. 187-99, “search for a sustainable, good-enough enemy”

 

C. Impulse to connect environmental commitment with a portrayal of specific dangers is the root of aggression---enables psychological splitting and a disconnect with the other

Joanna Byles, 2k3, “Psychoanalysis and War”, Journal for the Psychoanalysis of Culture and Society, 8, “failure of civilization historically to control”

 

D. These zones of danger necessitate and enable all international violence

Claudia Aradau, 2k1, http://venus.ci.uw.edu.pl/~rubikon/forum/claudia2.htm “securitized issue is presented as an issue”

 

Specifically, the notion of environmental apocalypse collapses people’s incentive to respond to crises and instead engenders violent numbness towards towards ecological spaces

Frederick Buell, 2k3, From Apocalypse to Way of Life, p. 201

 

We ask you to affirm the universal connectedness generated by ecological crisis. This advocacy requires you to de-link the appeal for sustainability from the obsession with security. Only this reconception of politics can generate the basis for positive and sustainable environmental policy

Simon Dalby, 1999, Contested Grounds, p. 177-8, “fundamentally rethink”

 

Our alternative does not require giving up on recognizing environmental danger---refusing the aff’s particular conception of apocalypse enables more realistic and persuasive engagements with environmental destruction

Buell, p. 201-3

 

Finally, the stories we tell regarding connectedness and security are influential---use the ballot to refuse the affs representations---this is crucial to an enduring peace

Byles, “enormously influential visual images”

 

2NC Cards

 

Framework:

Doremus, 2k, 57 Wash & Lee L. Rev. 11 “stories we tell”

Frameworks Institute, www.frameworksinstitute.org/strategicanalysis/perspective.html

 

AT: Perm

Deudney, Contested Grounds, p. 213-4 “thinking directly”

Dalby, p. 157-8

 

AT: Eco-Fear Good

NYT, 11/6/94, “national environmental movement”

Perrault, 1997, clinton2.nara.gov/PCSD/Publications/TF_Reports/linkage-chap6.html “motivating people in a positive way”

 

PERMITS K

 

A. Framework

COnsumption is more than a material process---it is socially constituted

through language and identity construction

Jackson, 2004

(http://www.sd-research.org.uk/researchreviews/documents/motivating_sustainable_consumption.doc)

"task of constructing"

 

These categories and social practices determine the very framework of policy

consideration---we must move beyond purely political discussions to get at

the ethical root of consumption

Levin and Espeland, 2000,

www.kellogg.northwestern.edu/research/ford/confer/opne/chapt5.htm, "market

based solutiosn have become..."

 

B. Link---permits produce an institutional logic rooted in

technologization---pollution is commodified and pollutors are disciplined

Levin and Espeland, "commensuration facilitates transformations"

 

C. Impacts

1. Commensuration---managerial politics of permits establishes numerical

metrics as the basis of social interaction---reduces all value to a

mathetmatical expression

Levin and Espeland, "commensuration transforms qualitative differences"

 

Impact = Dillon

 

2. Commodification

This logic commodifies the environment

Spaulding, 1997, Stan Envtl L. J. 16. 293 "first and foremost among these

problems of commodification"

 

Accepting this logic in the case of permits sanctions its logic universally

Spaulding, "pollution trading may place"

 

This commodification of life embraces a supremecist ideology of enemy

creation and hierarchical domination

Tokar, Dollars and Sense, March-April 1996, "groups like the Environmental

Defense Fund..."

 

Impact = Santos

 

D. Our alternative is to reject tradable permits because they embody the

disciplinary commodified logic of commensuration

 

This debate is about competing constructions of social meaning---coting

negative is a significant comunicaitve gesture with transformative potential

Jackson, "most important aspect"

 

Our alternative radically liberates the consciousness and enables effective

engagement with political institutions and the ethical basis of consumption

Spaulding, "commodification reveals"

 

 

 

 

VOLUNTARY CP WITH NET BENEFITS---ON NORTHWESTERN DJ’S DISCLOSURE FORM---SAME CITES

 

 

 

PERMITS NEG: ENVIRONMENTAL COMPETITION STATUTE

 

 

CP: The United States federal government should establish an environmental

competition statute that

requires fossil fuel companies to pay the costs that competitors incur in

realizing lower projected

carbon dioxide emission levels, plus a substantial premium relating to the

relative difference in

emissions levels of the firms in question. The premium level will be adjusted as

necessary to

ensure a minimum of _______ (plan)

 

Solves better than the case

Driesen, Economic Dynamics of Environmental Law, p. 154

 

Adjustment of premium level is easy and can effect specific outcomes

Driesen, 158-9

 

CP leads to incentives for private monitoring and enforcement---ensures no need

for government

intervention

Driesen, p. 155

 

Case Net Benefits

 

1. Permits lock in the status quo---pervse incentives against innovation

Tim Jenkins et. al. June 2001,

www.foe.co.uk/resources/consultation_responses/industrial_use_energy_foe.html

"stimulated by competition"

 

2. Companies will refuse to sell renewables in order to protect the permit price

Rippel, 11/25/97, www.consumeralert.org/pubs/Study/ets.htm "fewer incentives"

 

3. Permits cause companies to resist deeper emissions reductions

Driesen, p. 63

 

4. Market power

a) dominant firms will refuse to sell permits

Julia Reinaud, 2003, www.iea.org/dbtw-wpd/textbase/papers/2003/cop9invdec.pdf

"exclude other firms"

 

b) turns the case

AGO, June 1999,

www.greenhouse.gov.au/emissionstrading/papers/paper2/pubs/paper_2.pdf

"impede technological progress"

 

5. Quantity miscalculation---marginal costs of carbon abatement will be

high---causes inordinate

economic fluctuations

Ross McKitrick, 10/11/01, www.cei.org/pdfs/McKitrick.pdf "costs of mistakes"

 

this tanks solvency---short-term economic decline collapses stability of the

permit market

UNEP, 10/21/02,

www.unep.ch/etu/etp/events/Economic_Instruments/WG_EconInst_Synth.PDF

"tremendously

complicating"

 

6. Transaction costs---search for trading partners causes dead-weight loss

Hahn and Hester, 6 Yale J. on Reg. 109 "more costly and lengthy"

 

RIGHT TO POLLUTE K

 

Plan sells licenses to pollute-socially legitimates destructive corporate

behavior

Robert Goodin, Kyklos, 1994 "permitting people"

 

The impact is extinction---accepts the behavior that is the root cause of

ecological destruction

Tokar, Dollars and Sense, p. 3-4 "result of emissions trading"

 

 

This externally causes extinction

Fetishizes the commodities---negates the value to life

Spaulding, 1997, "most basic definition of fetishism"

 

Commodified intersubjective relationships culminates in universal dehumanization

The Humanist, 1994 54.1 p. 32 "commodity fetishism"

 

This makes genocidal violence inevitable

Columbia Daily Spectator, 2/8/99 "most Germans"

 

CP avoids the link

Goodin, "difference is very real"

 

SIGNING STATEMENT CP

 

CP: The United States Congress should pass legislation [plan]

 

The President should sign the bill and issue a signing statement declaring that

the legislation is

unconstitutional, refusing to carry it out. Congress will confer a cause of

action to interested

parties to bring suit against the President for refusing to enforce the

legislation.

 

NET BENEFIT

NO formal doctrine exists on presidental non-enforcement

Carroll, 1997, 46 Cath. U. L. 475, "courts should deter"

 

The Counterplan is crucial to create a test case

Dave Barron, 2000, 63 Law & Contemp. Prob. 61, "congress is not powerless"

 

CP would cause the Supreme Court to rule against the president

Peter Raven-Hansen and William Banks, 81 Iowa L. Rev. 79, "serious and

unresolved"

 

SOP violations must be rejected

Redish and Cisar, 91

 

 

 

AGRICULTURE NEG VERSION 1

 

CP: the United States federal government will

1) establish education standards that create curriculum reform and teacher training standards to formally encourage the integration of concepts of sustainable living into secondary schools. The United States federal government will encourage the states to adopt these standards and collaborate in their implementation, providing necessary funding and technical support. The United States federal government will enlist the help of the National Science Teachers Association and World Resource Fund to certify and develop academic benchmarks for achievement in sustainability.

 

2) Cap agricultural subsidies at $225,000 per farm and re-target subsidies at encouraging a transition away from fossil-fuel based agriculture. The three-entity and commodity certificate loopholes will be closed. The United States federal government will grant public recognition for farmers that utilize these subsidies to transition to sustainable practices.

 

It solves your case better---

Government leadership and education campaigns, combined with subsidy incentives, can effectively catalyze grassroots sustainability movements and encourage societal shifts towards sustainable agricultural practices---these strategies are more effective than command and control mandates

Judith M. Espinosa and Michele A. Perrault, (former) Secretary of the Environment, State of New Mexico and International Vice President, Sierra Club, February 1997 (http://clinton2.nara.gov/PCSD/Publications/TF_Reports/linkage-chap6.html)

“Americans are cynical”

 

Educational training and reform is effective at inducing a societal culture shift towards sustainability

Judith M. Espinosa and Michele A. Perrault, (former) Secretary of the Environment, State of New Mexico and International Vice President, Sierra Club, February 1997 (http://clinton2.nara.gov/PCSD/Publications/TF_Reports/linkage-chap3.html)

“formal classroom education”

 

By facilitating individual mindset shift, the CP will force a change in corporate practices

Judith M. Espinosa and Michele A. Perrault, (former) Secretary of the Environment, State of New Mexico and International Vice President, Sierra Club, February 1997 (http://clinton2.nara.gov/PCSD/Publications/TF_Reports/linkage-chap6.html)

“capacity building”

 

Education and corporate culture shift can effect a transition to sustainable agricultural practices---allows people to exert pressure on farmers and undermines the psychological and economic basis for overconsumption

Judith M. Espinosa and Michele A. Perrault, (former) Secretary of the Environment, State of New Mexico and International Vice President, Sierra Club, February 1997 (http://clinton2.nara.gov/PCSD/Publications/TF_Reports/linkage-chap6.html)

“Pantagonia”

 

Federal voluntary education standards heavily influence state educational officials and spur educational reform

San Diego Union Tribune, 11/6/94 (l/n)

“major public fight”

 

Restructuring subsidies would encourage a transition away from mechanized agriculture

RAYMOND OFFENHEISER, PRESIDENT, OXFAM AMEICA, 9/16/03 (CNN International, l/n)

 

Legislative commitment to financial incentives for sustainable agriculture avoids the disads---encourages a shift while avoiding the overly bureaucratic and adversarial process of command and control regulation

Jackie Robinson and Sean Ryan, economics and law at University of Queensland, June 2002 (http://www.coastal.crc.org.au/pdf/economic_instruments.pdf)

“Instruments for environmental”

 

AG DISAD

 

A. US agricultural industry is soaring now

Ann Veneman, secretary of agriculture, 1/29/04 (FDCH, l/n)

“2003 was a landmark”

 

B. The plan cripples the farm industry---banning fossil fuel use would collapse farm profits and spark land price collapse and undermine loan credit---this forces reconsolidation and destroys small farms

Terry Francl et. al., senior economist at the American Farm Bureau Federation, 10/30/98 (http://www.heartland.org/pdf/gwag-study.PDF)

“major economic downturn”

 

2. Federal environmental regulatory enforcement strangles small farm growth---process of implementing regulation drowns small farmers in paperwork and deters the deployment of innovative farming practices

David Schoenbrod, law at NYU, Spring 2001 (The Journal of Small and Emerging Business Law, 5 J. Small & Emerging Bus. L. 91)

“single federal regulation”

 

C. Impact

1. Robust agricultural industry is crucial to the US economy—plan kills the economy

Center for Energy and Economic Development, 2003 (http://www.ceednet.org/resources/agmanifesto.asp)

 

2. Decline of US agriculture and stumbling world economy will trigger a global backlash against economic liberalization

Terry Francl et. al., senior economist at the American Farm Bureau Federation, 10/30/98 (http://www.heartland.org/pdf/gwag-study.PDF)

 

3. Impact = Lewis

 

POLITICS NET BENEFIT

Farmers support the CP but oppose the coercive regulations---the plan ensures massive political backlash

Utility Week, 7/2/04 (l/n)

 

AGRICULTURE VERSION 2

 

CP: the United States federal government will establish an annual payment cap on agricultural subsidies in the amount of $225,000 per farmer, transferring those funds to the encouragement of farming techniques that do not rely on fossil fuel use. The United States federal government will condition the continuance of this payment cap, along with the establishment of [plan]

on a European Union commitment to the elimination of all or nearly all of their agricultural subsidies.

 

The CP solves better than the case---

 

US unilateral cuts do NOTHING to encourage EU reciprocation---high subsidy level and commitment to mechanized agriculture is crucial to US negotiating leverage, which is the only hope of securing substantial EU or Japanese subsidy reductions

Senator Kent Conrad, 5/23/02 (http://www.agweb.com/news_show_news_article.asp?articleID=88215)

“negotiated change”

 

This means they can’t solve any of the case---EU is the single biggest obstacle to global agricultural reform and the worst practitioner of mechanized agriculture

Richard Rahn, adjunct fellow at CATO, 9/10/03 (http://www.washingtontimes.com/commentary/20030910-093753-2813r.htm)

 

A multilateral framework is crucial to global trade liberalization---negotiations framework will draw in other countries and encourage international reform

C Fred Bergsten, prez of Institute for International Economics, Nov/Dec 2002 (Foreign Affairs, ebsco)

 

History of trade negotiations prove CP solvency---Uruguay Round seemed doomed, but tough US negotiating allowed trade blocks to be bargained away successfully

David Orden, agricultural economics at Virginia Tech, February 2003 (http://www.ifpri.org/divs/tmd/dp/papers/tmdp109.pdf)

 

Your answers won’t apply to our specific CP---the initial US concession of a payment cap will restore US credibility and jumpstart the negotiations process

Omaha World Herald, 9/27/03 (l/n)

 

The plan sends a universal signal of American weakness---caving into the EU on subsidies obliterates broader US credibility and encourages other countries to bully us on trade issues

Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, 11/14/03 (l/n)

“expose us to more bullying”

 

Perception of unilateral US trade concessions signals weakness to China---encourages them to exploit US vulnerabilities in other areas

Washington Times, 96                         (6-24)

“flip-flopping”

 

This aggression spills over to the military arena---encourages anti-American balancing and Chinese adventurism

New Republic, 99                 (6-14)

“more emboldened”

 

Chinese regional adventurism prompts US-Chinese great power war

Bernstein and Munro, China Gurus, 97

(Rich and Ross, Foreign Affairs, Mar/Apr)

“China’s military”

 

POLITICS NET BENEFIT

B. The plan loses Bush the election

1. Bush has staked the election on the need to get something from Europe in return for US subsidy cuts---he must avoid the perception that he is backing down and unilaterally giving into Europe on trade

Financial Times, 1/13/04 (l/n)

“cannot afford trade concessions”

 

a) Small farmers support subsidy reductions for big farmers, but oppose a unilateral disarm in the face of big European subsidies---only the CP can get them on board

CNN, 10/28/03 (CNNFN, l/n)

“small family farmers”

 

small farmers outnumber the large framers---the overwhelming majority of farmers support restructuring subsidies to aid small farmers

State Journal-Register, 5/6/03 (l/n)

“targeting income support”

 

2. Bush has already staked a position on conditional subsidy elimination

NYT, 7/30/04

“stated its willingness”

 

COMPETITIVENESS NET BENEFIT

 

Unilateral cuts in agriculture devastates US agricultural industry---places US ag at the mercy of European exports

Terence P. Stewart, adjunct prof at Georgetown University Law Center, 3/13/96 (Federal News Service, l/n)

“easily jeopardize”

 

2. Unilaterally subsidy cuts destroys US competitiveness---only a multilateral negotiated reduction can preserve equity of the market

Robert Atkinson, vice president of the Progressive Policy Institute, February 2004 (http://www.ndol.org/documents/rural_economy_0204.pdf)

“competitive disadvantage”

 

US agriculture would net gain from a multilateral reduction---opening up the European market allows US agriculture to dominate and gain major share of exports---enough to compensate for the effect of domestic regulations 

Miguel Figueroa, Kansas University School of Law, Fall 1995 (5 Kan. J.L. & Pub. Pol'y 93)

“farmers who are efficient”

against Dartmouth BC (gas vouchers) at KY

Northwestern BM

against Whitman SS at KY

Centralization Kritik. It's all an author named Papworth, a book called Small is Powerful, something like that. It's kind of like a global/local K but with lots of preempts to normal "local bad" stuff in the 1NC.

 

Northwestern BM

against Louisville at KY

competitive debate is good, that it's not really for everybody but that that's okay, since moderate speed, evidence and its attendant research, etc etc all have their own benefits.  Then they said that Louisville's metaphor was bad because the resolution would disempower minorities, since they are the first people to suffer from reductions in energy use.   Tristan made a whole bunch of confession-bad arguments in the 1NR that Branson didn't really do much with in the 2NR, although I thought that he should have.

 

Louisville said that this was a bunch of bullshit, that you can do all your debate stuff but you still need to have a noncompetitive purpose (a non-selfish, activist reason why you debate, specifically in ways that contribute to meaningful black participation, or meaningful inclusion of some other social group based on your social location), that Northwestern has not done enough, all that.   They lost because, just as I've seen them do in every other debate, they made a bunch of arguments about style and education but totally conceded the attack on their metaphor. 

 

(Roland adjudicating) Northwestern basically said UDL's good and things like their summer workshop was a means to increase meaningful black participation. They also said that there should be room in debate for all types of debating, including L'ville.  Louisville said in turn that the UDLs were nothing more than plantations and that their way of debating was important for increasing participation. The debate went back and forth with both sides using people like Tracy from Northwerstern as evidence for why their "project's" were correct.

Northwestern BM Neg against Dartmouth CS [Feebates], Semis of Harvard

 

 

We have definitional support---financial penalties for emissions are NOT requirements---it gives industry legal discretion over compliance---the fact that it INDIRECTLY encourages emissions cuts means that it is not a legal requirement

Justice Blackmun, 6/24/92 (505 U.S. 504,at 536, l/n)

"necessarily indirect"

 

 

Legal precision is more important than contextual accuracy---as policy-makers, we must strive to uphold precise definitions as determined by legal code---allowing for 'common usage' is infinitely regressive and destroys communicative stability

Bradley Shannon, law at University of Idaho, January 2002 (Washington Law Review, 77 Wash. L. Rev. 65)

"without clear-cut definitions"

Ours is specific to environmental law

Sherrie Flynn, San Joaquin Agricultural Law Review, 2003 (1 S.J. Agri. L. Rev. 173)

"direct commands"

 

 

Legal history proves

"damage award is not a requirement"

 

 

Only evaluate definitions of require in the context of the environment

Marie Adornetto Monahan, law at John Marshall Law Review, Summer 2003 (Southern Illinois University Law Journal, 27 S. Ill. U. L. J. 687)

"evidence of the context"

NU BM Neg vs Harvard KT, Ky RR

 

CP: USFG will establish an environmental competition statute that requires carbon dioxide polluters to pay the costs that competitors incur in realizing lower pollution levels, plus a substantial premium relating to the relative difference in pollution levels of the firms in question. Communication between companies regarding their reduction plans under the statute will be restricted.

 

Right to Pollute Net Ben. Cites

 

1. Link – Robert Goodin, Kyklos, 1994

 

2. Impact – Extinction – Tokar, Institute For Social Ecology, Dollars and Sense, 1996

“threaten public health and ecological survival”

 

3. K solves – individual action. Nash, American Law & Economics Association Annual Meetings, Year 2004

“society’s overall attitude toward reduction of pollution is less demanding”

 

Permits more costly to enforce

Scarlett, Fall 1994, www.cato.org/pubs/regulation/reg17n3-scarlett.html

“significant reporting and auditing”

 

 

Revenue recycle bad:

Are like carbon tax: Kopp (web) quantity or quota dual . . . . identical to the properties of the carbon tax system

 

Robs revenue needed for polltn decreases: Rueter (web) carbon taxes do however provide economic incentives . . . . impede the technological advancement that is essential

 

Revenue compensates big industry: Pipes and Zycher (web) government resource consumption will rise in efforts to compensate the regulatory losers . . . of the regulations themselves.

 

Gov welfare inefficient: Pipes and Zycher: substantial body of empirical work

 

Deadweight loss and GDP decrease: Cordato (web) the cost to the private sector goes beyond the direct revenue transfers . . . resources of the government

 

 

AT Cplan gets link to commodify K:

Goodin between fines, charges and taxes . . . nothing wrong with it

 

 

 

 

Cp text:

 

The USFG will estabilsh an environmental competition statute that requires carbon dioxide polluters to pay th costs that competitors incur in realizing lower  pollution levels, plus a substantial premium relating to the relative difference in pollution levels of the firms in question.  Communication between companies regarding their reduction plans under the statute will be restricted.

 

It solves better than the case—the CP harnesses the power of the free market to provide continuous incentives for radical innovation and renewables development—creates an industry-wide race to pollution control that avoids th pitfalls of bureaucratic monitoring endemic to permit systems

 

Driesen, 2003 Economic Dynamics of Environmental Law, p. 154

“one could craft, for example, an “environmental competition statute”,…repeated government decisions are not necessary”

 

CP would create massive incentives for private enforcement and monitoring development –ensures massive information disclosure

 

Driesen, 2003 (above) p. 155  “the government might still decide…payments under the statute”

 

case net benefits

 

1. Permits undermine competitive impulses towards innovation—they lock-in the status quo and create perverse incentive against innovation

Jenkins, June 2001  www.foe.co.uk/resource/consultation_responses/industrial_use_energy_foe.html#Conclusion

“to be a workable option the policy has to be able…step changes stressed by ACBE”

 

[not a net benefit…says permits reduce innovation compared to taxes. The perm solves]

 

 

2.  Permit schemes create incentives not to innovate—companies will refuse to sell renewables because the diffusion of such tech will decrease the value of their permits

Rippel, 11/25/97  www.consumeralert.org/pubs/Study/ets.htm

“advocates of emissions taxes fear…tax for the ton of emissions”

 

[same]

 

 

3. Permits decrease the incentive for future pollution reduction—they encourage polluters to resist future reductions in order to hoard permits and generate revenue

 

Driesen, 2003  p. 63  “increased reliance on emissions trading…might have to encourage innovation”

 

Says if not designed right, firms would have an incentive to resist future regulation

 

 

4.l Turn—monopolies:

 

a. Dominant firms will refuse tosell permits to new sources—creates a significant barrier to entry and undermines new firm creation

 

Reinaud, 2003  www.iea.org/dbtw-wpd/textbase/papers/2003/cop9invdec.pdf

“under “exclusionary manipulation”, a firm…the european union for example”

 

b. turns the case—stifles innovation and prevents a transition to renewables

Australian Greenhouse Office, June 1999   www.greenhouse.gov.au/emissionstrading/papers/paper2/pubs/paper_2.pdf

“a potential bias against new market entrants…existing market power problems”

 

5. Quantity miscaculation—

a. the cap on emission may prove too low or too high given climate changes and tech improvements—miscalculations may have enormous negative impacts on the economy

McKitrick, 10/11/01  www.cei.org/pdfs/McKitrick.pdf

“comparing the next two, on the face of it…achieve the same level of emissions control”

               

b. the disad tanks solvency—short-term economic decline disrupts the stability of the permit market and undermines innovation

United Nations Environment Programme, 10/21/02  www.unep.ch/etu/etp/events/Economic_Instruments/WG_EconInst_Synth.PDF

“macroeconomic instability induces constant…negative impacts of MBIs.”

 

6.  A. Permit pruce fluctuation—unexpected shifts in technology will cause rapid changes in the price of permits

Tietenberg, 2000  www.tlc.usm.maine.edu/commons_pubs/Tietenberg-Tradable%20Permits.pdf

“in pollution, unlike fisheries, the cap is rather rigidly…imposed in the interim”

 

b. uncertainty turns the case—confusion and regulatory mixed signals will undermine both the permit scheme and the basis for innovation

Rippel, 11/25/97  www.consumeralert.org/pubs/Study/ets.htm

“these issues need to be decided before companies…continue to produce over a longer period of time”

 

7. Permits entail enormous transaction costs—search for trading partners and seeking regulatory trade approval generates dead-weight loss

Hahn and Hester, 1989  6 Yale Journal on Regulation 109  “transaction costs also play a major role…bubbles, netting, and offsets”

 

9. International permit scheme fails—other countries will not sell permits in the short-term, preventing the US from cheaply cutting emission

Lash, 1999  www.heartland.org/pdf/2329ey.pdf

“however, there are many assumption in the emissions-trading…major link to economic development”

 

10. Turn—Trade

International permit trading collapse the global trade regime—guarantees volatility of financial and exchange rate markets and collapses LDC exports

McKibben and Wilcoxen, June 1997 www.brook.edu/comm/policybriefs/pb17.htm

“a third problem with the plan…policy unattractive to developing countries”

 

 

 

EPA 1nc

 

EPA counter-terrorism efforts growing now—they are reallocating their resources from other departments to counter-terrorism

US Newswire, 4/26/03  “since september 11, 2001 our government has experienced…traditional environmental crime caseloads”

 

Enforcement of energy regulations drains EPA resources and forces budget tradeoffs—self-regulation is essential to preserve EPA resource flexibility

Borkey, 11/12/98 www.cerna.ensmp.fr/Documents/PBMGFL-OECDVAs.pdf

“voluntary approaches may be attractive…monitoring of other policies”

 

Permits are costly to enforce—reporting and auditing is expensive

Scarlett, Fall 1994  www.cato.org/pubs/regulation/reg17n3-scarlett.html

“at least four of the criticisms Mr. Kellogg…indictment of command and control”

 

These costs overwhelm EPA resources—force tradeoffs

Driesen, BC Environmental Affairs Law Review, Fall 1998  “the joint implementation pilot projects…effective international trading system”

 

 

Northwestern DH neg

            Round 8 Ga State

            Vs. aff: Emory FT

            Judged by: Waldinger, Patrick

               

            Case Args:

Competitiveness:

Delays are empirically proven – implementation proceeds at a slovenly pace

David Driesen, Economic Dynamics of Enviornmental Law, 2003

“The pressure from both sides”……”permanent paralysis.”

 

Turns the case – delays drive entrepreneurs out of business and stifle renewables innovation

Driesen 2003

“Since innovations can go”…..material innovations.”

 

Costly monitoring and enforcement turns the case.

Mark Cohen, August 1998

“Although intuition would tell us”…..overcome this problem.”

 

Normal means proves that there will be stringent conditions attached to trading – prevents permits market

Robert Stavins, April 2002

“While some problematic program”……increases regulatory costs.”

 

Permits entail costly and bureaucratic government monitoring

Driesen, Environmental Law Reporter, 2003

“But a major critique …….allocation decision

Lynn Scarlett, Reason Foundation, Fall 1994 – CATO

Milka Kirova, December 1999

Jonathan Wiener, December 1997

Northwestern DJ Neg

 

            Round # 8  Shirley

            Case Args:

 

 

            Off Case Args:

 

CP – Threaten to Do the Plan if Companies Don’t Do It Voluntarily

 

Perm fails – the presence of coercive regulations engenders hostility and breaks down industry / government cooperation – destroy the possibility of voluntary initiatives

Rolf Alter, Chair of Regulatory Management and Reform Programme for the OECD, 2000

http://www1.oecd.org/puma/regref/pubs/Compliance.pdf

A series of studies of the effects of different inspection styles used by regulators in coal mine safety

 

CP captures the signal—self-regulation is gaining international momentum as a superior of government policy

Berna Collier June 2000 – http://www.selfregulation.gov.au/publications/TaskForceOnIndustrySelf-Regulation/DraftReport/report.pdf

Future trends in international self-regulatory policy

 

Third-party regulators are more credible than government—public sees them as more neutral

Caroline Crawford, Director of Communications, Advertising Standards Authority in London, 1997 – http://www1.oecd.org/publications/e-book/4297681E.pdf

Official recognition of the ASA has gone hand in hand with increasing public awarenesss

 

Voluntary measures are allowed under Kyoto

Pew Center for Global Climate Change 2002 – http://www.pewclimate.org/docUploads/Kyoto%2DUSBusiness%Epdf

Kyoto gives parties flexibility as to how they meet their emissions targets

 

Increased government welfare spending – the plan would politically force the government to ramp up biased and asymmetrical welfare spending – would further inhibit the economy

Sally C. Pipes and Benjamim Zycher – December 2003 – http://www.pacificresearch.org/pub/sab/enviro/CO2-Study-12-03.pdf

Notwithstanding the larger relevance of the various cost estimates

 

Government welfare spending does not benefit the economy—it is less than half as efficient as leaving money in the private sector

Sally C. Pipes and Benjamim Zycher – December 2003 – http://www.pacificresearch.org/pub/sab/enviro/CO2-Study-12-03.pdf

The need to compensate the losers and to induce political majorities to support the acquisition of efficient

 

Regulators must approve each trade – crates uncertainty and chills innovation

Robert Hahn and Gordon Hester – 1989 – Yale Journal – T Yale J. on Reg. 109

Calculating the amount of surplus emission reductions that a firm is entitled

 

Grandfathered permits are popular with the industry and avoid the negative economic effects of transparency in auctions

Cramton and Kerr and 1998 – “Tradable Carbon Permit Auctions” – http://www.cramton.umd.edu/papers1995-1999/99ee-distributional-effects-of-carbon-regulation.pdf

In contrast, the main political economy problem with auctions

 

Free permits reduce spending and creates profits

Lawrence Goulder 2000 – http://www.rff.org/rff/rff_press/bookdetail.cfm?bookdetail-toc&outputid=3204

An upstream CO2 permit policy can be designed to avoid significant reductions

 

Any forms of permits, including gratis, will provide incentives for alternative energy technology

Parry 2002 – “Are Tradable Emissions Permits a Good Idea?” – Journal of Environment Economics and Management - November

In other policy contexts, such as the sulfur-trading program, grandfathered permits appear

 

Threat of regulation is effective at inducing CO2 abatement

Peter Borkey 11/12/1998 – http://www.cerna.ensmp.fr/Documents/PBMGFL-OECDVAs.pdf

A commonly expected gain associated with voluntary abatement is avoiding the costs of public regulations

 

Concrete threat of regulation spurs effective self-regulation – this is the only argument backed by hard scientific data in the entire field

Alan Randal 2002 – New Tools for Protecting the Environment: Education, Information, and Voluntary measures – edited by Thomas Dietz

Traditional economic theory supports flexible incentives

Northwestern DJ Pre Shirley

 

Northwestern DJ – Neg Wake Disclosure

 

 

Voluntary CP – we have run this on occasion vs Permits and RPS

 

Text: The USFG should threaten to do (aff) if (aff’s industries) do not voluntarily create standards that ensure (result of aff).  Compliance will be determined by an accredited private 3rd party auditor.  The USFG should offer public recognition to complaint industries and engage in informational support if requested by industry.  The passage of the plan will be conditioned upon non-compliance.

 

Italicized sentence has been included and excluded in different rounds.

 

1NC CP solvency cards

 

Threatening regulation solves the case – companies will comply

Coglianese and Nash, professors of public policy at Harvard November 2002 (Environment, www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1076/is_9_44/ai_93917172/pg_4)

 

CP will comply self regulation – firms choose voluntary over regulations

Natalie Stoeckl 2004 (Business Strategy and the Environment, vol 13, Wiley Interscience)

 

Companies will race each other to seek the public benefits of voluntary compliance regimes

Virginia Haufler, 2001 (Public Role for the Private Sector, pg 42-3)

 

Companies are motivated by societal reputation – will act based on fears of future sales opportunities

Wallace, May 2000 (http://www.selfregulation.gov.au/publications/TaskForceOnIndustrySelf-Regulation/ConsultantReport/ch1.pdf)

 

Self regulation builds trust and challenges the way industry relates to government – ensures enforcement

Huegen 1997 (www1.oecd.org/publications/e-book/4297681E.PDF)

 

3rd party monitoring causes objectivity and impartial regulation

Andrews May 2001 (www.dep.state.pa.us/dep/deputate/pollprev/iso14001/NAPA.pdf)

 

Private enforcement avoids our disads – private sector enforcement causes innovation and creativity and avoids regulatory costs

Fiorino Summer 1996 (Northwestern School of Law of Lewis & Clark College 26 Envtl. L. 457)

 

 

Net benefit Disads to the Voluntary CP (we have gone for all 3 of these and Elections as a net benefit to Voluntary on different occasions).  We also have run the Centralization Kritik and the Violence Kritik with this CP (or by themselves), both of which are outlined in detail in the Northwestern BM disclosure.

 

MNC Shift DA -

 

FDI flows are decreasing (Bangkok Post 9/24/04)

 

1) Unilateral GHG mitigation regulations cause companies to move to nations with less standards (Goldberg and Wiser 3 Wid. L. Symp. J. 385)

 

2) Industries are guaranteed to shift (Stewart 1993, 102 Yale L.J. 2039)

 

C) 1) FDI will be targeted towards developing Asian nations (Fowler 95 25 Envtl., L. 1)

 

2) FDI in Asian Nations will spark a backlash against global trading (Petras 1998, www.zmag.org/zmag/articles/jam98petras.htm)

 

3) pullout of developing nations from the economy will spark nuclear war (Lewis 98)

EPA counter-terrorism growing now, relocating environmental resources to counter-terrorism (US Newswire 4/26/03)

1) EPA counterterrorism key to deter terrorism on water supplies (Anderson  2003, www.gale.com/pdf/samples/sp656113.pdf)

Common T violations

 

1)Emissions are different from consumption

- Requirements have to be binding, incentives are measures not requirements (Durling and Lester 1999, 32 GW J. Int’l L. & Econ. 211)

- Regulations on emissions don’t require consumption cuts – Natural gas solves (Rascoff and Revesz 2002, 69 U. Chi. L. Rev. 1763)

 

2) Voluntary cases aren’t topical

- Words and Phrases 1960 vol 37 pg 117

- Require = enforce and monitor (LaCroix 1992 Army Lawer 12)

- Voluntary isn’t requirement (Borkey 1998 www.cerna.ensmp.fr/Documents/PBMGFL-OECDVAs.pdf)

Oklahoma Neg

 

Oklahoma CJ neg

            Round 1 Northwestern

            Richmond WE

            Judged by: RJ Green

               

Give Back the land and Kick the USFG off the face of the Earth K.

 

Their basic argument is that USFG exists as an illegitimate structure linked to the colonial legacy of Columbus. Thus, issues of property rights and land are critical to the understanding of how and why oppression works. The basic link is that you invoke the name of the USFG as an agent, that language is bad as it reaffirms the existence of the state (Shapiro). The problem is that intellectuals laugh off the need for land reparations, always deprioritizing the issue. Voting neg fixes that problem.

 

Tricks

 

Read Churchill evidence that says that native Land sovereignty solves issues of consumption through a shift to renewables. Also read Mcwharter as the aff is a managerial solution.

               

AT Permutation

 

Aff is still a utilization of ill-gotten land. Reaffirms colonization.

Must challenge institutions to solve oppression

Oklahoma CJ @UNT

 

 

OU CJ AFF VS. WESTERN ILLINIOS HH

Round 1, JUDGE = Kat Kauf

 

Kritik of Collective Identity

- Attempts to enforce collectivity eliminate difference

- The impact is genocide

- Michael Shapiro, Violent Cartographies 1997, pp. 172-179; 150-151

Oklahoma CJ Pre Shirley

Negative: We exclusively run the K.  1 off. The shell is almost always a 9 minute long shell. This year we have run deep ecology, environmental ethics, and critiques of the state.

 

 

OU CJ @ UCO

 

 

Where are we at and where are we going?   At the dawn of the 21st century, we are experiencing massive assaults against the earth; indeed the impacts and scenarios outlined in the 1ac..  But these threats to the survival of the planet are caused by a trend of centralization over the past 500 years where it is assumed the central body of the USFG can solve our problems.  As our unit of government has grown in size, the individual capacity of individuals to make moral judgments about their lives has decreased.  We are horrified by the impacts articulated by the Affirmative, but our ability to make day-to-day decisions rejecting these assaults against the environment has been placed into much more powerful hands.

Papworth 1995, Small is Powerful: The Future as if People Really Mattered p. 23-24

 

Additionally, the affirmative identifies numerous threats to the survival of the planet and proposes a policy to halt the abuses and enable business as usual to continue.  This approach represents a misplaced site of resistance where technofix solutions are assumed to be all that is necessary to stoop the destruction fo the environment or prevent war.  However, at heart our problems are only secondarily technical: they are primarily moral.  Without examining how our individual capacity to make moral decisions and engage in ethical relationships with each other and nature has been eliminated by centralized forms of control, the impacts of the affirmative are inevitable.

p. 26-7

 

And, debates about oil shortages or global warming and the focus on short-term impacts to the economy obscure the need for deeper change in the way we relate to each other.  Such an approach at best guarantees we will only temporarily avoid these short-term impacts and everyday forms of excess will continue, committing our children to a life of ecological damnation. P. 98-99

 

The affirmative may try to “outweigh” or “out-timeframe” our advocacy by arguing that not voting affirmative means we will all be extinct before the alternative could be realized.  Yet, their appeals to centralized authority are the very cause of global crisis.  No focus, however, urgent and necessary, on other problems (even thought they are important) can be allowed to override the fact that any solution created within the same governmental structures that have created the problems in the first place will destroy the individual freedom necessary to challenge those problems. P. 186

 

The alternative is to recognize the need for return to local community and individual decision-making.  Voting negative is explicitly an individual democratic decision to endorse such thinking and spark the trend towards a revolution f the mind that rejects the concept of government as being some all0powerful figure that can solve al of our problems. P. 156-8

 

Voting affirmative to seek an answer to one problem identified in the 2ac is to suggest that the underlying causes of that problem and all other need no answers.  For the centralized institution the affirmative asks you to endorse is also a rigidly hierarchical , oppressive, and militaristic institution that denies the worth of each individual leading to many of the grotesque tragedies of our time.  Its try or die with the negative for the scale of the evils perpetuated by the government now pose a biological threat to our own survival p 7-9

 

The centralized body of the USFG only operates by denying the reality and validity of the power of localized consciousness.   The nation-state today represents the ultimate form of danger to the biological survival of the human race.  In a world of the alternative, each of us has the unique capacity to make decisions concerning the forces the affect our lives.  Voting affirmative aborts that creative capacity and makes n assault on life itself p. 57

 

Finally, any attempt to institute solutions on a mass scale can only result in totalitarianism.  Affirming our alternative of local communities and individual democratic decision-making affirms an ethic of personal relationships that subordinates market considerations and short-term imparts to moral judgments p. 128

OU NEGATIVE (AGAINST SMS) @ SMS

 

 

WHERE ARE WE AT AND WHERE ARE GOING?   AT THE DAWN OF THE 21ST CENTURY WE ARE EXPERIENCING MASSIVE ASSAULTS AGAINST THE EARTH, INDEED THE IMPACTS AND SCENARIOS OUTLINES IN THE 1AC.  BUT THESE THREATS TO SURVIVAL OF THE PLANET ARE CAUSED BY A TREND OF CENTRALIZATION

PAPWORTH SMALL IS POWERFUL: THE FUTURE AS IF PEOPLE REALLY MATTERED 23-4

 

THE AFF IDENTIFIES NUMEROUS THREATS TO SURVIAL, THIS APPROACH REPRESENTS A MISPLACE SITE OF RESISTANCE

PAPWORTH SMALL IS POWERFUL: THE FUTURE AS IF PEOPLE REALLY MATTERED  26-7

 

THE AFF MAY TRY TO OUTWEIGH OUR ADVOCACY YET THEIR APPEALS TO CENTRALIZED AUTHORITY ARE THE PROBLEM

PAPWORTH SMALL IS POWERFUL: THE FUTURE AS IF PEOPLE REALLY MATTERED  186

Oklahoma U. neg@ Emporia

The Ethic:

 

A. the first step towards a regenerative future begins with a wholistic understanding of our environment

-Thayer 2003

Robert L. Jr., LifePlace p. 8-9

-McLaughlin 1993

-Van B. Weigel 1995

a2: perm

-Hayward 1995

Tim, Ecological Thought p. 1

“one of the … constructive dialogue”

-Broadhead 2002

Lee-Anne International Environmental Politics: The Limits of Green Diplomacy p. 57-59

a2: fiat

Pittsburgh

 

 

Our criticism offers a Lacanian frame with which to evaluate the desirability of the First Affirmative. Lacan posits that because language nad reality are the odds, language can not adequately describe reality since humans anre linguistic creatres this lack is inevitable. That lack produces anxiety because our descriptions of reality consistently fail. The affirmative is yet another attempt to fill this lack with a fantasy of completion  -- to fix the hole in reality while ignoring the reason for the gap itself.

Trying to complete the fantasy always fails because language does not adequately describe reality – language will fail to descriethe world, meaning the fantasy can not be completed. The affirmative team does not question the fantasy, instead they question the sypton as the communists blamed the Trotsleyites and capitalists for their societyal problems, and the Nazis blamed Jews because Aryan dominance was not a reality. The aff project functions in much the same way. Its some new-yet-old solution to a problem that continues to plague us.

In order for them to win, they must prove one of the two things:

1)    They must prove our description of reality is inaccurately and that our framing merits rejection or

2)    They must prove the plan is advantageous in our framework

 

 

The gap between language and reality makes identification impossible – language fails

Stavrakakis, Lacan and the Political, 1999 Pg. 34-5

 

Their advantages are fantasmatic screens designed to support untenable fantasies – their impact scenarios  are leverage for tier vision of purity

Stavrakakis, Pg. 81-2

 

The 1ac presents nature as a stable and harmonious if humans would just butt out – this fantasy of harmony in nature creates a new paradign that attempts to reset the natural balance by eliminating human involvement

Stavrakakis, 1997 Pg. 124-125

 

Underlying the international actions of the plan is the fantasy of national identity – thus fantasmatic structures legitimate violence against the other

Shapiro, 1993 The political subject of violence, Pg. 127-8

 

When the attempt to fix reality fails, the repressed desire returns as horrific mass violence

Stavrakakis 1999, Pg. 101-2

 

Utopian promise are more appealing the recognizing the futility of acting within the fantasy structure – utopianisms strangles our methodological queries

Stavrakakis, 99, Pg. 116-7

 

This flips solvency – the failure of fantasies represses and then releases extermination

Stavrakakis 99, Pg. 100-1

 

Method Comes First

Must prioritize psychoanalytic method to explain the devices of our imprisonment

Barratt 1993, Psychoanalysis and the postmodern impulse, Pg. 19-20

 

Methodology must be evaluated before solvency

Newfeld, Millennium, 1993, Pg. 54

 

The aff maintains its appeal by attributing disorder to alien objects – this process demands the elimination of the alien influence only by applying  a psychoanalytic method can we avoid utopia gone wrong

Stavrakakis, 1999, Pg. 107-8

 

 

T- Ospec (congress)

T- consumption (could use scrubbers, etc)

Case args

 

Redlands

 

Redlands PT

            Round 6 Kentucky

            Vs. aff: Wake AL

            Judged by:

                Scotty Gotbreit

 

            Capitalism Bad – Zizek

 

Subpoint A

 

Ethical obligation to reject bourgeois state apparatus. Zizek 2004 “revolution at the gates” pg. 4-11

 

Ethical obligation.  Capitalism accounts for actual suffering Daly “Conversations with Zizek” pg 14-16

 

Subpoint B

 

Capitalism contains an inherent antagonism between use and exchange value.  While exchange value wildly oscillates, the real needs of people are ignored.  As capital grows, this gap grows ever wider, creating a permanent escalating of condition of economic crisis.  Zizek, 1004, “Revolution at the Gates” pg. 277-8

 

The aff insulates liberal democratic order from radical revolutionary social change by upholding the notion that the democratic bourgeois state can combat the very ecological destruction that it is itself responsible for.  Zizek 2004”rev at gates” 167-71

 

Permits link – permit trading is a capitalist scheme for environmental protection which is doomed to result in failure.  The Socialist 2003 “How Capitalism Puts Our Planet at Risk” 11/15/2003 online  “all the governments that support the aim of cutting greenhouse gases”

 

The harms of the 1ac are but one facet of an impending global ecological crises. We cannot afford to pretend that one reform can save us – the machine of capital is doomed to recreate ecological disaster until all life on earth is extinguished.  Kovel 2002 “The Enemy of Nature: The End of Capitalism or the End of the World?” pg. 19

 

Capitalism slammed the breaks on effective global environmental reform.  Foster, 2003 “A planetary defeat: the failure of global environmental reform” Monthly Review proquest

 

Reject the best example of capitalism – leap of faith.  Zizek, 2004 iraq: the borrowed kettle pg. 83-6

 Regis

 

 

Negative

 

On the negative we begin with an investigation of the ways in which debate fossilizes us as competitors and judges.  We then talk about the importance of literature and how current limits placed on debate ruin our interaction with meaningful lit.  We read from the same interview with Pelevin cited above and make similar arguments with it.

 

We then offer and alternative for reading the topic politically.  This changes from round to round.  An example would be undermining the text of the resolution to make it less political.

 

We then read from Paul Mann (Masocriticism 1999, p. 17) and talk about the ways in which our undermining of the affirmative’s approach to the rez is effective.

 

Finally we read the same section of Koba the Dread cited above and use it in a similar way – to indict the political as a pervasive object of discussion.

 

 Richmond

            1nc Positions

Gas Tax CP

 

Mandates: The USFG should phase in a 0.46 per gallon federal gas tax as per the recommendations of our solvency evidence. We reserve the right to clarify our intent.

 

Gas tax solves better than CAF – lowers driving, improves safety, provides less of a hit to the economy

Dinan and Austin 3-9-04

www.cbo.gov/showdoc.cfm?index=5159&sequence=0

Opponents argue that AND not pass a benefit-cost test

 

Phased-in tax solves without economic effect

Carey, covers science and environment, 2002

Business Week 9-9 Number 3798, p. 96

A better approach AND safer for everyone

 

AT: perm

 

  1. links to das
  2. disad to perm and the case – trust fund
  1. raising the gas tax would increase revenue, while increasing CAF standards would lower receipts – the CP is net-beneficial

CBO Nov 2002

Raising the gasoline tax AND met the higher standards

b. maintaining current funding levels inadequate

ARTBA 5-6-03 American Road and Transportation Builders Association “Financing our nations roads”

Significant new investment in transportation AND federal government itself quantified

 

  1. Perm still links to the economy DA

Gas tax alone has the least cost to the economy

CBO

Finally, the three policies AND changes in fuel economy

  1. link to turns that are driving dependent – safety and pollution net-benefit

Gas tax effective way to reduce all manners of gas consumption – CAF isnt’

CBO

A cap-and-trade program or a well-designed increase AND improvement in fuel economy

 

Gas tax solves more quickly than CAF

Dinan and Austin, 2004 (CBO, above)

The advantage of the gasoline tax AND existing vehicles at all

 

Gas tax solves for fuel efficiency

D+A, 2004

A Gasoline Tax Increase AND buy more-fuel-efficient vehicles

 

Gas tax is the most economical and effective way to reduce consumption

Stempeck 1-7-04

CBO analysts said the cheapest AND immediately in response to the tax

 

Freedom K

Human beings are fundamentally alone – one can’t count on or blame others, you are radically free

 

JP Sartre, The Writing of Jean-Paul Sartre, 1974

Man cannot will unless AND good of all p. 159

 

You shouldn’t live in the world of possibilities – as a radically free individual you should confine yourself to that which depends on your will

Sartre, Existentialism and Human Emotions, 1957

As for despair AND essentially the same thing

 

Freedom is the only end – one must always reject the urge to will the freedom of others

 

Sartre, Existentialism from Dostoevsky to Sartre, 1956, p. 308

For I declare that freedom AND will the freedom of others

 

Current debate is little more than abstract coffee talk – such fine-tuned political irresponsibility, in which we offer hypothetical plans but take no action, make us accomplices in the death of the oppressed.

 

Gordon and Gordon, Sartre and evil, 1995, p. 181?

Evil is the irresponsible talk that creates AND in the death of the oppressed

Negative Citations

 

 

CO 2Ag. DA  A. Fossil Fuel emissions are critical to increasing CO 2levels which solve global food wars. Idso 99 co2science.org/edit/v2_edit/v2n19edit.htm

B. Additionally, increased CO 2emissions and increased land productivity are key to preventing the massive overuse of farmland that will collapse the biosphere - turns the case idso 01 www.co2science.org/editv4_edit/v4n43edit.htm

 

 

Saudi Arabia Oil DA - Oil revenues are the only thing preventing the collapse of the Saudi regime. The Scotsman11 /28/01

Saudi Collapse Kills the global economy. Steven R. David Jan/Feb 99 Foreign Affairs

 

 

States CP - The 50 states, the District of Columbia, and all territories of the United States of America will _________(the Aff. plan)

It solves the case - states are the green labs of democracy Johanthan Adler 98 (George Mason Law Review)

 

 

Russian LNG DA - Gazprom has big deal to sell U.S. LNG - Moscow Times7 /17/03

That's key to their economy Moscow Times9 /15/04

Russian economic downturn = nuclear and environmental disaster Steven R. David Jan/Feb 99 Foreign Affairs

 

 

Normativity Critique A. Our Framework - Before engaing in a debate about what we should do,we believe that this debate should center around an exploration of what we are doing. We are calling theh basic approach of the Aff. into question

B. Normative thought locks us into a world of pain and death - the Aff.'s representations are merely a surrealist normative fantasy. Pierre Schlag 90 Stanford Law Review

C. This turns and takes out the case - no solutions are possible until we break the chains of normative thought and learn a new way of knowing and acting.  Pierre Schlag 90 Stanford LR

 

 

Executive Order CP

Executive orders have the force of law and have empirically been used to reduce fossil fuel consumption. Mayer2001 , With the Stroke of a Pen pg. sorry, don't have it

XOs boost presidential power Woodward 90 Legal References Quarterly "established who was in charge"

Each increase in presidential power is vital to prevent nuclear annihilation Paul 98 California LR "the risk of nuclear annihilation"

 

 

Federalism DA - Federal environmental regulation destroys federalism - Adler 98 (George Mason Law Review)

U.S. Federalism Solves Global Ethnic Conflicts - Steven Calabresi 95 Michigan Law Review

 

 

Social Ecology Critique - A. The environmental crisis is now - we are on the brink of an ecological apocalypse. Murray Bookchin   1971 Post-Scarcity Anarchism

Links - Cosmetic environmental solutions only gloss over the environmental crisis and preclude the possibility of  more radical change. Murray Bookchin 1982 The Ecoolgy of Freedom

C. Only rejection of the state and embracing a radical rejection of capitalism and consumption can solve - Vote Neg. Bookchin 71 Post-Scarcity Anarchism

 

 

Ecofeminism Critique - A. Treatment of nature as a passive object embraces patriarchial ideologies of control. Karen Warren 2000 Ecofeminist Philosophy

B. This ideology pervades the info. the Aff. relies on, making it hollow and meaningless. Joni Seager 93 Earth Follies

C. Failure to acknowledge the gendered nature of power dynamics will cause a nuclear holocaust of ecological catastrophe.

 

 

S 02Screw DA

A. Air Pollution blocks sunlight and causes dimming Melissa Fyfe5 /17/ 04The Age "Hence the word dimming"

B. This reduces warming by75 % Fred Pearce6 /4/ 03"reduced global warming by as much as three-quarters"

C. Particulates wash out of the air in a matter of days, but GHGs stay around a long time, proves plan causes rapid warming in the short run William Booth90 , Washington Post

"counterbalancing the greenhouse effect"

 

 

Exclude the tribes CP

Text: Changes per the round, but something like the USFG will implement the mandates of the plan while exempting Indian nations from its provisions.

A. Federal energy policy applies to native american lands Gable4 /30/ 03Greenwire Vol. 10 No. 9 "still apply to the tribes"

B. This is racist environmental colonialism Peter Jacques 2003 Environmental Law and Litigation L/N "racial discrimination against Indian tribes"

C. This destruction of culture imperils global survival Lilian Friedburg 2000 American Indian Quarterly "What is at stake is the very future of the human species"

 

 

Backstopping Disadvantge A. High oil prices will inevitably drive a shift to renewables, its the key stimulant for the market transition. Bob Williams Oil & Gas  Journal9 /18/ 03"ensure that governments will not intervene"

B. A drop in oil prices will crush renewables, market forces are always more powerful than command and control - John Cassidy10 /11/ 04The New Yorker "higher fuel prices might well be just what the country needs"

Wake GM

Luke Kritik (ran against Permits teams mostly, also some other teams that read warming/pollution advantages)

Ecological capital becomes the ultimate basis upon which life is sustained, environmental surveillance.

Timothy W. Luke March 18-22 1997 “The (Un)Wise (Ab)Use of Nature: Environmentalism as Globalized Consumerism?”  Presented at the annual meeting of the International Studies Association, http://www.cddc.vt.edu/tim/tims/Tim528.htm

“All of these environmentalizing initiatives reveal” and “order of social normalization”

 

Biopower is bad

Foucault 1984 The Foucault Reader, ed Rabinow, pg. 259-260

 

Alt text is green resistance through permanent criticism

Eric Darrier 1999 Discourses of the Environment, Foucault Against Environmental Ethics, pg. 233-234

 

Kidner Kritik

Mastering nature means our consciousness is tied down and not only divorced from, but set in opposition to our unconsciousness. This destroys the natural world and our psyche.

David W. Kidner 2001 Nature and psyche: Radical Environmentalism and the Politics of Subjectivity, pg. 264

 

Reducing consumption of fossil fuels does nothing to solve the real problem. Extinction is inevitable, the only hope is the alt

Kidner, pg 4-5

 

Impact is loss of human value and slow extinction, divorcing the human from the natural shatters the self, and the meaning of life.

Kidner pg. 30-33

 

Alternative is resonance

The aff operates under the assumption that energy is another problem we can think through—that perhaps our relationship to the env is flawed but only because we are thinking about it the wrong way.  But the problem IS thinking, pushing forward as if the world is a riddle that we can solve with more meditation and reform.  The env isn’t screwed up because we don’t understanding something about it but because we try to understand everything aobut it.  you don’t know why you tap your foot to music- similarly nature produces rhythm that can resonate with us if we play along instead of trying to record every note that has been played

Kidner, pg. 293-4

 

Zizek Kritik

Framework- we view the debate round as a site for political experimentation.   The question of ontology, or how we understand ourselves, is a prior question to politics and must be taken into account.

Michael Dillon april 1999 Another Justice, vol 27, number 2, p. 158

 

Political rhealm is in crisis- post politics, or just doing “what works” well within the current frame of politics is very flawed and buys into the fantasy of solving ideologies

Slavoj Zizek 1999 The Ticklish Subject pg. 198-200

 

We have entered into the risk society- low probability and high consequence impacts like global warming are forcing everyone to take the middle road and try to avoid both extremes, this is yet another example of flawed ideologies

Zizek 99 Ticklish Subject, pg. 334-340

“The fundamental deadlock” and “although they are not publicly recognized”

 

Aff’s claims of ecological or economic disaster are not something that can be eliminated by policy, disaster is part of the system

Brian Donahue 2002 Marxism, Postmodernism, Zizek, PMC 12.2, project muse

“are underwritten by the belief that with the correct” and “which empirical studies may be”

 

Alt: we must withdraw from the traditional form of politics in order to open up space for a different kind of activity

Zizek 2004 Iraq: The Borrowed Kettle, Verso: New York, pg. 71-2

 

Empire Kritik

Use of the state makes us its commodities—the state can no longer be trusted with liberatory intentions given its track record of horrific violence and destruction—aff only reforms biopolitics, turning the case

Hardt and Negri, Empire 2000 http://www.zaratustra.it/empire.htm

“Big government is over” and “whole capable of constituting itself in government”

 

Biopower is really really really bad

Hardt and Negri 2004, Multitude, pg. 18-19

 

Alternatives we have claimed (not all in the same debate)

1. love- politicizing love and abandoning the nation state as a means of doing so.   Situating love as a political concept divorced from the nation state is essential to overcoming the atrocities Empire and the aff impact claims

Hardt and Negri 2004 Mult. Pg. 49-51

 

2. Patriotism: embrace patriotism as a desire of the multitude—patriotism or a love of humanity is a way to oppose mercenary warfare in all its forms

H/N 2004, Mult pg. 49-51

 

3. Exodus- evacuate places of power, abandon your post

Hardt and Negri 2000

“This recognition takes us back” and “authors up to Polanyi”

Case cards:

Capitalism loves the plan- empire adapts to decreases in consumption by switching to renewables

H/N 2000 pg. 270-2

“At the time of the First World War” and “informatization of production”

 

Nuke war won’t happen- aff impacts mask perpetual war like iraq, Afghanistan and the way conflicts occur today

h/N 2004 pg. 37-40

 

multilateralism doesn’t solve conflict- empire defies this, making theoretical mult. Impossible

H/N 2004, pg. xii-xiii

 

Total Heg control is impossible- they only replicate biopower

H/N 2004 pg. 53-4

 

Can’t decapitate terrorism, plan makes it stronger

H/N 2004 pg. 57-8

 

Free trade isn’t free- its just the rich stealing from the poor

H/N 2004 pg. 167-8

 

Military action isn’t just for oil, but more general economic order

H/N 2004 pg. 176-7

 

Can’t find the lynchpin of capitalism- small arms sales

“the military-industrial complex” and “nuclear devices nor let them have no access to”

CP-it has three parts

1.  threaten to do the affirmative plan

2.  procure 8 million hydrogen vehicles, spend 50 million on hydrogen development, and procure 15% of govt energy from renewables by 2020

3.  have third party monitoring enforce the plan

CP-solvency

1.  procurement of hydrogen solves

San Antonio Express-news, 11/3/2004

“but by 2005, Frois said, all of the…..portable fuel cell power, he said.”

 

2.  procurement of renewables solves

Joel Stronburg and Viridner Singh, 2001, renewable energy project, Government Procurement to expand PV markets, http://solstice.crest.org/repp_pubs/articles/pv/4/4.html

 

3.  threatening to do the plan solves

Virginia Haufler, 2001, A public role for the private sector: industry self-regulation in a global economy, p. 105

Whitman  -- GM

Negative: the Wake caselist contains the cites for our Zizek and Agamben
negative positions. We go for one of these in about 95% of our negative
debates.

 

Their negative is always K, but they have a ton of different arguments they will put together for different situations.  The most common negative earlier in the semester was either Zizek or Agamben, but I haven't seen them recently and so they may have some new stuff.

1NC

 

Agamben: Virtually the same and the Wake Forest Case book with one two new pieces of evidence

 

Their criticism of capitalism places people into distinct categories. This type of logic reifies the state of exception – example of the Jews in Germany. This results in civil war

Agamben 2000 Means without End pg 38.9-44.5

 

The state of Exception manifests itself in the sovereign ban in which a relation of non-relation is created between a subject and the law this sets the individual outside the real f politics and into a space of indecision where they are no longer politically productive and can be killed without impact-homo sacer

Agamben 1998 Homo Sacer: Sovereign Power and Bare Life pg 28-29

no consensus was reached"
